It then quickly formed a cup-with-handle base with a 49.85 entry,…

Growth in 3D printer sales decelerated in 2016, hampered by a slowdown at 3D Systems (DDD) and Stratasys (SSYS), the two industry leaders by revenue.According to Wohlers Report 2017 by Wohlers Associates, 3D printer sales grew 17.4% to $6.06 billion in 2016, year over year. That's down from 26% growth in 2015.Much of the downturn came from declines by 3D Systems and Stratasys, which together represented $1.31 billion, or 22%, of industry sales last year. Excluding Stratasys and 3D Systems, industry sales rose 25%, Wohlers said.3D Systems stock dipped 2 cents to close at 14.94 on the stock market today. Stratasys lost 1.2%, finishing at 20.25.IBD'S TAKE: Both 3D Systems and Stratasys are far off their highs from 2014, and have weak performance ratings, based on a variety of IBD metrics. IBD's Stock Spotlight lists 16 stocks with top fundamentals that could be getting ready to break out.Stratasys and 3D Systems face increased competition from giants such as General Electric (GE) and HP Inc. (HPQ). HP made its long-awaited entry into the 3D printer market last year. Also last year, General Electric purchased two European 3D printing companies; it also has developed jet engine technology via 3D printing.Wohlers said the number of manufacturers that produced and sold 3D printers reached 97 in 2016, up from 62 in 2015"This wave of development and commercialization is putting pressure on the established producers of additive manufacturing systems," the report said.RELATED:Stratasys Stock Plunges As 3D Printer Maker's Outlook Falls Short3D Systems Sales Fall Most In Years; Revenue Outlook Is Light3D Printing Taps 4th Industrial Revolution; HP Discusses Big AmbitionsGE Rival Siemens, In 'Breakthrough,' Tests 3D-Printed Turbine Blades

Shares of Stratasys (SSYS) jumped Tuesday after the 3D printer maker was upgraded to overweight from neutral at Piper Jaffray, based on the view that industry demand trends are improving after a long slowdown."We believe it is time for investors to revisit the 3D printing space," wrote Piper Jaffray analyst Troy Jensen.Jensen, in a research note Tuesday, said Stratasys is outperforming 3D Systems (DDD) and other 3D printer manufacturers.Based on a Piper survey of 3D printer resellers, Stratasys experienced "a meaningful uptick in system demand for the second consecutive quarter," Jensen wrote. He said many resellers say they are entering 2017 with a solid pipeline, "and are upbeat that this year will be a better one for system sales vs. 2016."In addition to the overweight rating on Stratasys, Jensen raised his price target to 28 from 21.Stratasys stock jumped 11.6% to 23.77 in the stock market today. 3D Systems was up 2.7% at 15.28.Jensen thinks the 3D printing industry saw an uptick in product demand during the last two quarters and that improvements at Stratasys are "one of the underlying reasons for the demand."The improving demand environment seems to be benefiting Stratasys more than 3D Systems, he wrote."But we also believe companies like Materialise (MTLS), Proto Labs (PRLB), Voxeljet (VJET) and a host of emerging startups are also seeing better demand trends," Jensen wrote.Of 3D Systems, Jensen wrote, "While 3D Systems is making some improvements, we believe the challenges are still significant and competition is intensifying." He reiterated an underweight rating on 3D Systems."We do not believe the uptick in demand was consistent across all vendors or 3D printing technologies," he said.3D printer sales decelerated in 2016, hampered by a slowdown at 3D Systems and Stratasys , the two industry leaders by revenue.IBD'S TAKE: Both 3D Systems and Stratasys are far off their highs from 2014, and have weak performance ratings, based on a variety of IBD metrics. IBD's Stock Spotlight lists 16 stocks with top fundamentals that could be getting ready to break out.According to Wohlers Report 2017, 3D printer sales grew 17.4% to $6.06 billion in 2016. That's down from 26% growth in 2015.Regarding HP (HPQ), the industry was expecting the tech giant to begin mass shipping of systems in the fourth quarter of last year."But we believe this launch date has been pushed out until the second half of 2017," said Jensen.Stratasys and 3D Systems face increased competition from giants such as HP and General Electric (GE). HP announced it would make its long-awaited entry into the 3D printer market last year. Also last year, General Electric purchased two European 3D printing companies; it also has developed jet engine technology via 3D printing."Although HP's launch date has likely been pushed out, we believe HP and their Jet Fusion technology will have a big impact on the industry, as well as on Stratasys' and 3D Systems' channels," Jensen wrote.RELATED:3D Printing Taps 4th Industrial Revolution; HP Discusses Big AmbitionsGE Rival Siemens, In 'Breakthrough,' Tests 3D-Printed Turbine Blades

Computer hardware giant Dell Technologies (DVMT) on Thursday reported strong fiscal fourth-quarter results that have positive implications for peers like HP Inc. (HPQ) and NetApp (NTAP) as well as other tech firms.Round Rock, Texas-based Dell said its sales in the quarter ended Feb. 3 were $20.1 billion, up 53% from the year-earlier period, which was before Dell purchased data storage tech firm EMC. It reported adjusted net income of $1.1 billion for the quarter.Dell Technologies describes itself as the world's largest privately controlled technology company. PC and server maker Dell, which went private in October 2013, purchased EMC last September to create Dell Technologies. At the same time, it issued a tracking stock for its stake in EMC spinoff VMware (VMW).Revenue in Dell's client solutions group, which includes PCs and displays, rose 11% year over year to $9.8 billion. That is its best performance in more than eight quarters, RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani said in a report Thursday."While the company did not provide April-quarter guidance, we think January-quarter's results have better implications for the PC businesses of PC-exposed companies," Daryanani said. He listed PC maker HP, chipmaker Intel (INTC), tech reseller CDW (CDW) and hard-disk-drive makers Western Digital (WDC) and Seagate Technology (STX) as benefiting from improving industry conditions.IBD'S TAKE: Dell Technologies stock has been forming a flat base for four weeks with a buy point of 65.88. The stock recently was added to IBD's Leaderboard list of stocks with potential for big gains.Dell shipped 11 million PCs in the fourth quarter, its largest volume since the fourth quarter of 2011. Its personal computer shipments were up 8.2% year over year.Dell's infrastructure solutions group generated $8.4 billion in revenue in the fourth quarter. That included $3.6 billion from servers and networking and $4.8 billion from storage. VMware revenue for the fourth quarter was $1.9 billion, Dell reported."Dell's server and networking performance should also have positive implications for the server/data center segments of Intel, Western Digital, Seagate and CDW," Daryanani said. NetApp should benefit from the same trends helping Dell's storage business, he said.

OK, we get it: The robots are coming. From drone warfare to self-checkout lines at the grocery store, the change is clear. Sales of automated industrial "robots" rose 15% year-over-year in 2015, to reach an annual record of 253,748 units, according to the International Federation of Robotics. Those units were valued at $11 billion, 9% more than the year before.…

Some of America's most venerable tech companies aim to renew growth by breaking up.The jury is still out on whether that will work for Conduent (CNDT), which has a long road ahead, analysts say. Separated from Xerox (XRX) in January, Conduent helps other companies get their financial house in order in the field known as business process outsourcing.Some analysts say Conduent aims to build a more competitive business. Others contend it could be a more attractive takeover target down the road. Its results have been lackluster of late, though the company's outlook indicates a growth path ahead.Complicating matters is activist investor Carl Icahn, who has a piece of Conduent. The big question is what will happen if its turnaround starts clicking."We think Conduent is an unlikely (merger) target," Keith Bachman, a BMO Capital Markets analyst, said in a recent report. "We don't think any of the established BPO leaders, such as Accenture (ACN), IBM (IBM) or Genpact (G), have any interest in acquiring Conduent, given its focus on the low end of the market."But others say a sell-off could come piecemeal."(Chief Executive Ashok) Vemuri may choose to divest/sell portions of the business that are either 'noncore' or less profitable," said Frank Atkins, a SunTrust Robinson Humphrey analyst, in a recent note to clients. "While this would have impact on top-line trajectory on a reported basis, it is a quick way to drive margin as well as restore balance-sheet powder for strategic investment. In our view, this could be in low-margin, more commoditized work, or in certain geographies which may not be of adequate scale."In investor meetings, Vemuri has outlined plans to increase its sales force, invest in digital technologies such as data analytics, and focus on North America and Europe as core markets.What the company also wants to do is exit low-margin contracts and pursue new deals with better pricing. It aims to migrate toward higher-value-added work rather than being a soup-to-nuts services provider."The core philosophy now is to drive a more repeatable, scalable and predictable business," Vemuri said on Conduent's fourth-quarter earnings call in February.  "We are not in the business of trying to capture a headline by doing a big deal that we do not even understand how to start working on."Regardless of what awaits the company, the split/merger strategy isn't unfamiliar. Silicon Valley stalwart Hewlett-Packard in 2015 split into two publicly traded companies: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) to focus on services and products for businesses, and HP Inc. (HPQ) to focus on PCs and printers.HPE in early April took a step further, spinning off its enterprise services businesses. But that entity merged with IT consulting firm Computer Sciences to create DXC Technology (DXC), now a rival of Conduent.Whether Conduent pursues a strategic direction similar to HP's remains to be seen. Xerox stock gapped up on Jan. 3, the day the spinoff was completed, and is up about 8% this year. Xerox is set to launch a slew of new products, aiming to spur revenue growth in the back half of 2017, analysts say.The move to split from Xerox was endorsed by Icahn, who built up a stake in the copy machine maker.Icahn now holds a nearly 10% stake in Conduent and picked three members of its board of directors. So he figures in whatever strategic options Conduent is looking at, analysts say.IBD'S TAKE: Conduent hasn't been a publicly traded company for long, but it's already is forming a cup-with-handle base that could lead to higher stock gains. Read here for more information on stocks forming cup bases.As its own entity, Florham Park, N.J.-based Conduent handles such services for businesses as state Medicaid payments, tollbooth collections, and other transactions.Along with Accenture, IBM and Genpact, a number of other business process providers compete with Conduent. They include Convergys (CVG), ExlService (EXLS) and WNS Holdings (WNS), as well as large multinational tech service providers including Automatic Data Processing (ADP), Cap Gemini (CGEMY), and the new DXC Technology.The worldwide BPO market is growing about 5% annually, says Citigroup. In 2018, it's expected to reach $197 billion, from $188 billion in 2017.As it grows, CEO Vemuri aims to provide multiple services to customers rather than spread out too thinly."The thing we have to work on is to take various service capabilities, find the common thread between them, and sell (services) as a bundled solution," he said on Conduent's earnings call.Prior to joining Conduent last year, Vemuri was chief executive of iGate, an information services firm. France-based Cap Gemini acquired iGate for roughly $4 billion in 2015. Vemuri earlier worked at Infosys (INFY), an India-based consulting and tech services firm.Current results may not bode well for a takeover, though. Conduent's 2016 revenue fell 4% to $6.4 billion. Adjusted revenue in the December quarter fell 6.5% to $1.6 billion, below estimates.Conduent posted a fourth-quarter loss of $4.69 a share, compared with a year-earlier loss of 3 cents. Excluding a goodwill impairment charge and restructuring-related costs, Conduent said it earned an unadjusted profit of 29 cents per share vs. analysts' estimate of 23 cents. Analysts estimate that Conduent profit will rebound to 95 cents in 2018 from 75 cents this year. But it notched $1.06 in unadjusted profit last year.With a market valuation of some $3.2 billion, Conduent does not plan to repurchase shares or issue a dividend in the near term. Conduent has told analysts that if cost-cutting generates more free cash flow it could start making small acquisitions in 2018 to expand into new areas.Conduent has moved quickly to reduce its worldwide workforce to 91,000 as of Feb. 15, down from 96,000 at the end of 2016.While shares in Conduent are up about 7% since its spinoff from Xerox, Citigroup says one drag on Conduent stock has been that the company was not added to either the S&P 500 or midcap S&P 400 index post-spinoff, limiting its exposure to index investors.RELATED:Analysts Shoot Down Oracle-Accenture Deal; 'Why Buy The Cow?'

Dell Technologies (DVMT) and other PC makers are gaining momentum after years of contraction as users update their systems. The Round Rock, Texas-based PC and server maker went private in October 2013. It created Dell Technologies after buying data storage firm EMC in September. The stock began trading in September, cleared a cup-with-handle base in November and rallied more than 30%…

Microsoft's (MSFT) ambitions in augmented and virtual reality are going to get a big lift from the "Project Scorpio" Xbox gaming console due out this fall, says Loup Ventures."Typically, when we talk about the future of AR and VR, the first companies that come to mind are Apple (AAPL), Google (GOOGL), Facebook (FB), and Snapchat (SNAP); however, Microsoft does not receive enough credit for the strong positioning it has already built," said Loup managing partner Gene Munster, in a blog.While virtual reality immerses a user in an imagined or replicated world such as video games, augmented reality overlays digital imagery onto the real world.Microsoft's gaming platform is key, says Munster, formerly an Apple analyst at Piper Jaffray."Of all of the companies vying to own VR and AR platforms of the future, Microsoft is the only one to have a gaming console," he said.Digital Foundry, a gaming website, disclosed Xbox Project Scorpio specifications last week. Microsoft announced the gaming system at the Consumer Electronics Show in January.IBD'S TAKE: After a 12% gain last year, Microsoft stock is up about 5% in 2017. It has formed a flat base, with a buy point of 66.01. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.At CES, Microsoft said that it had reached 55 million monthly active users on its Xbox Live platform, up 15% from the previous year.In addition to VR gaming capabilities, the new Xbox will feature 4K video. Microsoft's main competition in VR gaming is Sony (SNE), says Munster. Sony released a PlayStation VR system in November. Sales reached 915,000 in late February, Sony said."While Microsoft doesn't produce any VR hardware, it sells (Facebook's) Oculus Rift headset in its stores and has included the Xbox controller in Oculus Rift bundles," said Munster. "Oculus seems like the logical choice for a VR headset partner for Project Scorpio."Microsoft's next gaming console will also support headsets expected out in 2018 from Lenovo, Dell, Acer and HP (HPQ).Microsoft shares ended trading Monday down 0.2% to 65.53.RELATED:Video Game Publisher Activision Posts High Score On Bullish ReportNetEase Game Business Weakens; First-Quarter Targets In DoubtNintendo Unveils Versatile Video Game Console: Nintendo Switch

Shares in Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) edged down on the first day of trading following the spinoff of its enterprise services businesses, which merged with Computer Sciences (CSC) to create DXC Technology (DXC).HPE stock closed down 1% to 17.57 in the stock market today. The stock opened at 18 on Monday after closing at 23.70 on Friday. Accounting for the difference between Friday's close and Monday's open were terms of the spinoff: HPE stockholders received about 0.086 shares of DXC common stock for each HPE share.Shares in DXC Technology fell 1.8% to 67.95 on Monday.HPE updated its financial outlook to reflect the spinoff, "which was largely in line with expectations," and consistent with earnings-call commentary,  said Tim Long, a BMO Capital Markets analyst in a report.HPE forecast second-quarter unadjusted earnings in a range of 33 cents to 37 cents a share vs. its earlier outlook of 41 cents to 45 cents. HPE forecast full-year 2017 earnings of $1.46 to $1.56 a share, down from the company's prior guidance of $1.88-$1.98.DXC assumed $600 million of HPE's net pension liabilities and $400 million of HPE's existing debt, while also paying a cash dividend of $3 billion, of which $1.5 billion will be used to pay down existing HPE debt.IBD'S TAKE: To learn about stocks that are breaking out or nearing buy points, try a free trial of IBD's MarketSmith premium charts and stock-screening service, accessible via the home page of Investors.com.About 50.1% of the outstanding shares of DXC common stock is now held by pre-merger HPE stockholders, with pre-merger CSC stockholders holding 49.9% of shares.HPE also plans to spin off its software business, which will be acquired by U.K.-based Micro Focus International. Jim Suva, analyst at Citigroup, said he expects a $3-per-share value to HPE shareholders from the software spinoff, expected to close in the fourth quarter.Hewlett-Packard Inc. split into two publicly traded companies in November 2015, with its printer and PC business becoming HP Inc. (HPQ) HPE will still sell networking, data storage and servers to corporate customers.RELATED:Computer Sciences To Join S&P 500, Stock JumpsHPE Snaps Up Nimble, Lifting Shares In Sector; Cisco Lurking?Hewlett Packard Enterprise Near-Breakout Fails On Weak Guidance

PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) late Wednesday delivered fiscal first-quarter results that came in above Wall Street's targets thanks to solid personal computer sales.HP stock rose a fraction in after-hours trading following the earnings news release. During the regular session, HP rose 0.4% to 16.20.Results: HP earned 38 cents a share excluding items, up 6% year over year, on sales of $12.68 billion, up 4%, in the quarter ended Jan. 31. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 37 cents EPS and $11.84 billion in sales.Guidance: For the current quarter, HP expects to earn 39 cents a share ex items, down 5%, but in line with forecasts, based on the midpoint of guidance. It did not give a sales target for fiscal Q2. Wall Street had been modeling for HP's sales to fall 2% to 11.4 billion.Stock Action: HP shares have been building a cup base with a buy point of 16.35 over the past nine weeks. HP hit that buy point intraday on Feb. 14, but shares retreated."In Q1, we delivered earnings at the high end of our outlook range with strong free cash flow, driven by relentless execution and innovation," HP CEO Dion Weisler said in a statement. "We are confident in our ability to manage our business and deliver our fiscal 2017 financial commitments."HP's PC revenue rose 10% year over year in Q1 to $8.22 billion, with consumer revenue up 15% and commercial revenue up 7%. Notebook PC unit sales were up 12% while desktop unit sales were flat.HP's printer and ink revenue fell 3% year over year to $4.48 billion. Total printer unit sales were up 6%. Supplies revenue fell 3%.RELATED:PC Market Consolidates Around Lenovo, HP, Dell; Apple Fades

Stratasys (SSYS) reported fourth-quarter earnings Thursday morning that beat estimates on the top and bottom line but the 3D printer maker gave guidance that fell short, causing shares to plunge.Revenue rose 1% to $175.3 million, above the consensus estimate of $169.3 million. Stratasys reported adjusted earnings of 15 cents a share, well above the consensus estimate of 5 cents and compared with a 1-cent loss in the same quarter a year ago.For 2017, however, Stratasys guided revenue in the range of $645 to $680 million. That's below the estimate of $693 million. It expects adjusted earnings in the range of 19 cents to 37 cents. The consensus is 49 cents.Stratasys stock tumbled 9.4% to 18.17 in the stock market today, crashing below its 50-day line.Stratasys and fellow pure-play 3D printer maker 3D Systems (DDD) face increased competition from giants such as General Electric (GE), HP Inc. (HPQ) and others. Stratasys and 3D Systems are the largest 3D printer makers by revenue, but both have found demand failing to live up to the early hype of a 3D print revolution.HP made its long-awaited entry into the 3D printer market 15 months ago. General Electric last year purchased two European 3D printing companies, and has developed jet engine technology via 3D printing. Boeing (BA) has used the technology, also known as additive manufacturing, to make tools and parts.Stratasys generated $26.0 million in cash from operations during the fourth quarter and ended the period with $280.3 million in cash and cash equivalents.RELATED:3D Printing Taps 4th Industrial Revolution; HP Discusses Big AmbitionsGE Rival Siemens, In 'Breakthrough,' Tests 3D-Printed Turbine Blades3D Systems, Stratasys, Show Signs Of Turnaround In 3D Printer Market

PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) and outdoor- and fitness-device maker Garmin (GRMN) received stock upgrades Monday, while action-camera maker GoPro (GPRO) was downgraded to sell.Wells Fargo Securities analyst Maynard Um turned positive on HP stock Monday, raising his rating to outperform from market perform. He said HP's core business has stabilized and its growth opportunities are shaping up nicely.Um raised his valuation range on the stock to 20-to-22, from 15-to-16.50.HP stock was up a fraction, to 17.30, at the closing bell on the stock market today. The stock broke out of a cup base with a buy point of 16.35 on Feb. 14.IBD'S TAKE: HP stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 67, meaning it has outperformed 67% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. But it ranks No. 5 out of 14 stocks in IBD's Computer-Hardware & Peripherals industry group. To see which company leads the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Elsewhere among personal technology stocks, Goldman Sachs upgraded Garmin to neutral from sell and downgraded GoPro to sell from neutral.Goldman Sachs analyst Simona Jankowski raised her 12-month price target on Garmin to 52 from 48.Garmin stock was up 0.5% to 51.76 at the close Monday."A key part of our thesis — deceleration in the fitness business — has now played out, with the company guiding for fitness growth to decelerate to 5% in 2017 after 24% growth in 2016," she said. "We no longer see downside to consensus estimates, and expect a return to growth in 2018."Garmin posted strong holiday-season results, helped by a weak performance by fitness device rival Fitbit (FIT). Unlike Fitbit, Garmin has a diversified business. In addition to making activity trackers like Fitbit, Garmin makes sports watches, gadgets for outdoor enthusiasts, and navigation devices for the automotive, maritime and aviation markets.Fitbit on Monday introduced an upgraded version of its Fitbit Alta fitness band that now includes heart-rate tracking. It described the Fitbit Alta HR as "the world's slimmest wrist-based, continuous heart-rate tracking device." It also features automatic exercise recognition, sleep tracking, battery life of up to seven days and smart notifications. The device will be available in early April and retail for $149.95.Fitbit stock lost 1.2% to end the day at 6.Jankowski turned bearish on GoPro, slashing her price target on the stock to 6 from 9.50.GoPro tumbled nearly 8% to finish the regular session at 8.14. Intraday, its shares hit an all-time low of 7.95."GoPro faces significant challenges following saturation of its core action cameras market, product rollout issues in the holiday season, and a disappointing entry into the drone market," Jankowski said in a report. "We expect GoPro to continue to struggle fundamentally."RELATED:HP Breaks Out On Q1 Beat; Fitbit Up On In-Line Q4Garmin Beats Q4 Targets On Strong Fitness, Outdoor Device SalesGoPro Stock Goes Lower On Q4 Sales Miss, Weak Guidance

President Trump has visions of a massive Apple (AAPL) factory opening in the U.S. to churn out the latest iPhone. The idea is not completely far-fetched, but one thing seems clear: If it happens, most of the new jobs will go to robots.Even in lower-cost China, Foxconn, which assembles the iPhone there, reportedly replaced 60,000 workers with robots at one facility. That's more than half the facility's workforce. Foxconn says it is adding 10,000 "Foxbots" per year.China has seen its cost advantage wither away due to wage gains. It's investing more than $3 billion a year in robots — up from next to nothing before 2009 — to keep from losing its manufacturing base to lower-cost developing nations, Bernstein analysts Michael Parker and Alberto Moel wrote in a December report.Trump has vowed to rewrite or walk away from trade deals and cut corporate tax rates to level the playing field for U.S. companies. He told Congress on Feb. 28 that he'll "bring back millions of jobs."Although economists concur that North American Free Trade Agreement and China's admission to the World Trade Organization have taken a toll on U.S. manufacturing jobs, Trump's battle plan seems geared to fight the last war.If China must shrink its costs with a massive deployment of robots, U.S.-based manufacturers that pay much higher wages and benefits will face the same pressures.A 2015 study by Boston Consulting Group found that an automotive industry welder earned about $25 an hour, including benefits, while a robot could do the job for $8 an hour, including installation, maintenance and operating costs. The gap is expected to widen sharply as technology improves."It is still possible to force the relocation of production" by restricting trade via tariffs or applying political pressure, wrote Bernstein's Parker and Moel. "However, if the point of the exercise is to restore well-paying, middle-class jobs in manufacturing in the process, the result is going to disappoint. Mandating a physical task be carried out in a high-cost labor market in 2017 is simply going to increase the chances the task is automated."Trump relentlessly bashed air conditioning company Carrier during the campaign for its plan to close an Indiana factory and move the work to Mexico. He intervened in December, saving about 800 jobs — for now. But Carrier's parent, United Technologies (UTX), which is getting $7 million in tax incentives from Indiana to stay, said it would invest $16 million to automate the factory "to drive the cost down."Like Apple, United Technologies is a member of Dow Jones industrial average.United Technologies CEO Greg Hayes told CNBC that while moving to Mexico would have been cheaper, the company will "make that plant competitive just because we'll make the capital investments there, but what that ultimately means is there will be fewer jobs."Mondelez (MDLZ), the maker of Oreos, was another regular Trump campaign target for its decision to cut 600 jobs from a Chicago factory and move the work to Mexico. The company said it considered installing new production lines at its Chicago Nabisco plant but chose to do the work in Salinas, Mexico, because of a $46 million cost differential. Mondelez noted that even if the project had gone forward in Chicago, half the jobs would have been eliminated because of new labor-saving technology.IBD'S TAKE: Since taking office, President Trump has talked less about the sticks he'll use against U.S. trading partners and more about the carrots he'll offer to manufacture in the U.S. via tax reform. But, for now, Trump's economic agenda and his tax cuts for business are stuck in line behind the ObamaCare repeal effort.The food and beverage industry is expected to be among the bigger adopters of industrial robots in coming years, says Boston Consulting Group, with automakers and electronics firms continuing to lead the way. Metals and machinery, rubber and plastics, and pharmaceuticals and cosmetics are also seen ramping up robot use. A 2016 McKinsey & Co. study concluded that 59% of manufacturing activities could be automated.Foxconn said in January that it's mulling a $7 billion highly automated factory for making displays, including flat-panel TVs and monitors, in the U.S. in partnership with Apple. Transportation costs for ever-larger displays, which aren't shipped by plane like the iPhone, are a driving force behind the plan. Foxconn Chairman Terry Gou said March 1 that such plans are on hold as the company waits to see what bills are passed and what incentives are offered.Pegatron, another Apple contract manufacturer that does assembly for Dell and HP Inc. (HPQ) out of plants in California and Indiana, reportedly said after Trump's election that it could expand its U.S. capacity fourfold, relying on automation and with a minimal increase in labor. The tech industry began formulating its response last year in the event that Trump was elected and turned out to be serious about imposing 35% tariffs on imports from China.Trump hasn't threatened such hefty tariffs in recent weeks. The focus has shifted to House Republicans' plan to slash the corporate tax rate to 20% and make export revenues tax-free. The 20% rate would apply to the full value of imports, raising $1 trillion over a decade that would effectively pay for the corporate tax cut. Still, economists who back the idea say that the dollar would rise 25%, offsetting any trade advantage. Major importers like Wal-Mart (WMT) hate the idea and trade experts warn that the WTO would likely find the import tax to be illegal.Some companies haven't needed new tax deals or threats to open factories in the U.S., but automation is key to their strategies.Adidas is a prime example. The maker of athletic shoes, which has long done its labor-intensive manufacturing out of China, Indonesia and Vietnam, last year piloted what it's calling a Speedfactory in Germany, making shoes almost entirely by robots. This year, the second Adidas Speedfactory is slated to open in Atlanta, where it's expected to employ 160 people facilitating the production of a half-million shoes.The high-tech operation, Adidas says, won't just eliminate the drudgery in manufacturing (along with a lot of the workers). It also will enable the company "to make product for the consumer, with the consumer, where the consumer lives in real time, unleashing unparalleled creativity and endless opportunities for customization."Meanwhile, Nike (NKE), another Dow industrials component, and Under Armour (UAA) are both developing strategies for manufacturing in the U.S., close to their customers. It's a safe bet that robots will be doing most of the work.The implications for workers are clear, says Boston Consulting Group. "As U.S. factories adopt advanced manufacturing technologies, demand will surge for higher-skilled, white-collar workers who can quickly adapt to new technologies and processes, and demand will lessen for blue-collar workers who are trained in specific skills."Despite his vow to bring back millions of jobs, Trump isn't oblivious to the job threat posed by robots. In a postelection interview, the New York Times asked Trump whether he was worried that companies will keep their factories in the U.S. but automate their workers out of jobs."They will, and we'll make the robots too," Trump said. He added: "Right now we don't make the robots. We don't make anything. But we're going to. I mean, look, robotics is becoming very big and we're going to do that."Trump is more right than wrong about the U.S. ceding an opportunity, writes Frank Tobe, publisher of the Robot Report. "Two-thirds of the robotics industry and 100% of industrial robots are manufactured outside of the U.S. by non-U.S. companies."China's leadership has fully embraced the adoption of robots as part of its "Made in China 2025" strategy. The plan reflects not only wage pressures but demographics, as its working-age population shrinks. Whether the U.S. will avoid committing to robots for fear of displacing workers is a real question with serious competitive implications.Academics and industry leaders made the case in "A Roadmap for U.S. Robotics" last fall that robots have been a plus for manufacturing jobs. "Over the last 5-6 years we have seen introduction of 600,000 new jobs in manufacturing. During the same period, we have seen significant growth in adoption of robot systems in industry," they wrote.Yet their upbeat predictions come with some uncertainty. The auto industry has been the biggest adopter of robotics, but that's happened as sales rebounded from just 10.4 million in 2009 to a record high 17.5 million in 2016. But if demand has peaked, as industry players suspect, then increasing automation may not be quite so positive for employment in auto manufacturing in the future.RELATED:U.S. Manufacturing Gears Up As 'America First' Trump Takes OfficeThe Top 10 Jobs Robots Could Steal From Humans By 2025Forget The Doomsday Clock, There's Now A Robot Fear IndexThe Trump Economy: Jobs, Regulations, Taxes And Trade

3D printer maker 3D Systems (DDD) will report fourth-quarter earnings before the market open Tuesday, and it's expected to show continued struggles as the company undergoes a turnaround and faces increased competition.Wall Street expects Q4 revenue of $176.76 million, down 3.5% from Q4 2015 but up 13% from Q3. Earnings per share minus items are expected to fall to 17 cents from 19 cents in Q4 2015.Rock Hill, S.C.-based 3D Systems is under growing pressure from General Electric (GE), HP Inc. (HPQ), Siemens (SIEGY) and other companies that are pumping up their strength in 3D printers. The 3D print trade faces an array of challenges, ranging from the type and price of potential materials, to rethinking entire supply chains for portions of the industrial landscape.3D printer maker Stratasys (SSYS) reports its Q4 results before the market open March 9.IBD'S TAKE: Both 3D Systems and Stratasys are far off their highs from 2014, and have weak performance ratings, based on a variety of IBD metrics. IBD's Stock Spotlight lists 16 stocks with top fundamentals that could be getting ready to break out.3D Systems stock was up 2.7% to 16.94 in the stock market today, while Stratasys was up 2.5% to 20.94.The companies are the two largest 3D printer makers by revenue, but both have found demand failing to live up to the early hype of a 3D print revolution.Last April, 3D Systems announced that it had recruited Vyomesh Joshi to be its new CEO. Joshi had been executive vice president of the imaging and printing business of HP Inc.The 3D printer market stirred an investor and media frenzy in the three years through 2014. At that time, 3D printers were just taking hold in consumer markets and developing critical mass in some commercial and industrial settings. Big names, including General Electric and Boeing (BA), had begun to embrace the tools.HP made its long-awaited entry into the 3D printer market 15 months ago. General Electric last year also purchased two European 3D printing companies, and has developed jet engine technology via 3D printing. Boeing has also used the technology, also known as additive manufacturing, to make tools and parts.RELATED:3D Printing Taps 4th Industrial Revolution; HP Discusses Big AmbitionsGE Rival Siemens, In 'Breakthrough,' Tests 3D-Printed Turbine Blades3D Systems, Stratasys, Show Signs Of Turnaround In 3D Printer Market

It's the biggest year-over-year sales decline in several years.It reported earnings per share minus items of 15 cents, down 21% vs. 19 cents a year earlier but beating the consensus for 13 cents.3D expects 2017 revenue of $643 million to $684 million with non-GAAP EPS of 51-55 cents. The 3D print trade faces an array of challenges, ranging from the type and price of potential materials, to rethinking entire supply chains for portions of the industrial landscape.3D Systems shares fell 10% on the stock market today, tumbling through their 50-day line. 3D shares have been consolidating since mid-April 2016.Stratasys (SSYS) stock lost 5.6% to 19.77, undercutting its 200-day.Stratasys reports its Q4 results before the market open March 9. Joshi had been executive vice president of the imaging and printing business of HP Inc.The 3D printer market stirred an investor and media frenzy in the three years through 2014. At that time, 3D printers were just taking hold in consumer markets and developing critical mass in some commercial and industrial settings. Big names, including General Electric and Boeing (BA), had begun to embrace the tools.HP made its long-awaited entry into the 3D printer market 15 months ago. General Electric last year also purchased two European 3D printing companies, and has developed jet engine technology via 3D printing. Boeing has also used the technology, also known as additive manufacturing, to make tools and parts.RELATED:

Tesla (TSLA) had its price target raised Thursday after saying its Model 3 was on track late Wednesday, Nvidia (NVDA) got a pair of downgrades, while Square (SQ) and HP (HPQ) also saw their price targets raised after strong earnings reports.RBC Capital raised Tesla's price target to 314 from 245, and RW Baird raised its price target on the electric automaker to 368 from 338.Elon Musk's company reported mixed Q4 results as profit fell short of Wall Street views. Tesla said limited production of its Model 3 is on scheduled to start in July and hit 5,000 vehicles per week in Q4 and 10,000 vehicles per week next year. Musk said Tesla may raise more capital with cash levels on the "edge."Shares fell 6.4% to 255.99 on the stock market today, undercutting its recent breakout from a 258.57 buy point.RELATED:BMO Capital downgraded the graphics chipmaker, whose customers include Tesla, BMW and makers of gaming consoles, to underperform. BMO cut its price target to 85 from 100. Instinet downgraded Nvidia to reduce from buy, slashing its price target to 90.The downgrades come as other analysts are bullish on the stock. Rosenblatt Securities analysts have a buy rating on Nvidia along with IBD 50 companies Broadcom (AVGO) and Microchip Technology (MCHP).Nvidia shares tumbled 9.3% to 100.49, knifing through its 50-day moving average. Nvidia had tested its 50-day several times in its huge run but hadn't closed below that key support level in a year.Square's price target was raised to 20 from 17 at Needham and to 19 from 16 at Mizuho. Both firms have a buy rating on the mobile payments firm.Late Wednesday, Square reported Q4 results above analyst views and gave bullish Q1 guidance.Shares soared 14% to 17.15, breaking out past a 15.59 buy point. Square shot up intraday to 17.75, an all-time high.Cowen & Co. cut Fitbit's (FIT) price target to 7 from 9.The wearable fitness device maker reported worse-than-expected Q4 results late Wednesday, even after warning investors of a weak holiday season. It also gave Q1 guidance below Wall Street views.Shares rose 3.2% to 6.07.HP's price target was raised to 15 from 14 at Mizuho, which kept a neutral rating on the stock. On Wednesday, HP reported Q1 results above analysts' views on strong personal computer sales.Shares rose 8.6% to 17.60, clearing a 16.35 buy point and hitting a two-year best.RELATED:

Personal computer and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) on Thursday saw its shares spike after beating Wall Street's fiscal first-quarter targets. Meanwhile, wearable fitness device maker Fitbit (FIT) appeared to calm investors with Q4 results that came within its lowered guidance range.At least seven Wall Street analysts raised their price targets on HP stock after the company's Q1 report late Wednesday. But of those seven, five reiterated neutral or equivalent ratings on the stock. Two were bullish: FBN Securities and Morgan Stanley.FBN analyst Shebly Seyrafi upgraded HP stock to outperform from sector perform and raised his price target to 19 from 15. Morgan Stanley analyst Katy Huberty reiterated her overweight rating on HP stock and upped her price target to 19 from 16.IBD'S TAKE: HP stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 67, meaning it has outperformed 67% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. But it ranks No. 5 out of 14 stocks in IBD's Computer-Hardware and Peripherals industry group. To see which companies lead the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.HP broke out of a nine-week cup base with a buy point of 16.35 on Thursday. Shares of the Palo Alto, Calif.-based company rose as much as 9.9% to a two-year high of 17.80 in intraday trading on the stock market today. HP stock closed the session at 17.60, up 8.6%.Seyrafi turned positive on HP because of the company's solid execution and "excellent free cash flow metrics." HP PC sales are benefiting from innovative products and its printer supplies business is showing signs of stabilization, he said in his research report.Patrick Moorhead, an analyst with Moor Insights & Strategy, said HP's PC business is benefiting from consolidation in the market, which has left three big vendors: Lenovo, HP and Dell Technologies (DVMT). HP also was smart to shift to premium Windows PCs in the consumer and commercial markets, he said in a report.Fitbit stock rose on Thursday after its December quarter report was better than feared. Fitbit shares rose 3.2% to 6.07 Thursday.Most analysts maintained a cautious tone on the stock, which has been hammered by slowing sales of wearable fitness devices.Cowen analyst John Kernan reiterated his market perform rating on Fitbit, but cut his price target to 7 from 9."Guidance for 2017 implies weak sales, down 26% year over year at the midpoint, additional gross margin contraction and expense management," Kernan said.While Fitbit leads the fitness tracker market, it has been ceding share to Garmin (GRMN) and other brands, he said in a report.On Wednesday, Garmin reported better-than-expected Q4 results thanks to strong wearable device sales.Fitbit management is focused on entering the smartwatch market now, leveraging its learnings from the Fitbit Blaze fitness watch and its recent acquisitions, including Pebble. But the company will face tough competition from Apple (AAPL) and others in the smartwatch business, Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy said in a report. She rates Fitbit stock as underweight with a price target of 5.RELATED:Stocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth Stocks

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) said Tuesday it is paying $1.09 billion for data storage provider Nimble Storage (NMBL), which was also viewed as a takeover target of rival Cisco Systems (CSCO).HPE offered $12.50 per share for Nimble, a 45% premium to its closing price on Monday. That catapulted Nimble shares by more than 46% as they closed the regular trading session at 12.58. HPE stock was down 1.1% to 22.82, while shares in Cisco ticked up a penny to 34.20.Both HPE and Cisco aim to acquire technologies for next-generation data centers designed for cloud computing. HPE said in January it would buy privately held cloud software company SimpliVity, a rival of Nutanix (NTNX), for $650 million in cash. Nimble Storage, Nutanix, and Pure Storage (PSTG) are among smaller companies that analysts have speculated could be targets of Cisco.Pure Storage stock surged more than 11% to 10.47 on the stock market today. Shares in Nutanix surged nearly 3% but settled back for a gain of 0.4% to 21.39 at the close. Nutanix stock was slammed last weak after guidance disappointed.IBD'S TAKE: HPE stock formed a cup pattern from November to late February and rose to an all-time high of 24.78 on Feb. 22 Shares fell after the company missed analysts' fiscal Q1 estimates and cut its forecast for this year's profit. Learn more about HPE at IBD Stock Checkup.Both Nutanix and SimpliVity sell software that manages network, storage and server infrastructure in private cloud platforms, an emerging market called "hyperconvergence." Aside from HPE and Cisco, VMware (VMW) and Dell Technologies (DVMT) aim to be players in the converged infrastructure market, analysts say.Silicon Valley pioneer Hewlett-Packard split into two publicly traded companies in November 2015. It formed HPE to focus on products and services for large businesses, and printer/PC maker HP Inc. (HPQ)In May, HPE said it would spin off and merge its enterprise-services division with Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC) Then in September, HPE said it would spin off its software business and merge it with U.K.-based Micro Focus International. When those deals close in 2017, HPE could take one-time charges in financial results, analysts say.RELATED:How Cisco's AppDynamics Buy Could Impact New Relic, Splunk, IBM, HPECould HPE Go Shopping For Cisco Rival Arista Networks?HPE Targets Nutanix, Dell, Cisco With SimpliVity BuyCisco Systems Requires 'Needle-Moving' M&A, Says Analyst

Enterprise technology giant Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) crashed Friday after the company's fiscal year earnings guidance fell well short of views.HPE stock plunged as much as 10% in the stock market today, and ended the regular session down nearly 7% to 22.96. The drop resulted in a failed near-breakout. Hewlett Packard Enterprise stock had formed a cup base with a buy point of 24.89, and shares came within a penny of that price on Wednesday. But Friday's fall of more than 8% below the buy point triggers a sell signal, in any case.The technology company — half of the former Hewlett-Packard that was split into HPE and PC/printer company HP Inc. (HPQ) in 2015 — beat expectations with its earnings per share minus items and revenue for its fiscal Q1 ended Jan. 31. But its EPS ex items outlook for the current quarter and fiscal year fell well short.In its earnings release, HPE cited three factors for the guidance shortfall: "increased pressure from foreign exchange movements, higher commodities pricing, and some near-term

execution issues."IBD'S TAKE: HPE barely fell short of a record high on Wednesday, but plenty of companies have been hitting 52-week highs during the current uptrend. IBD's New Highs list, though, ranks record-setters by other performance metrics.HPE is spinning off its services unit to Computer Sciences (CSC) and merging its software unit with U.K.-based Micro Focus, with the former slated for completion by April 1 and the latter by Sept. 1. But the "key areas of weakness were servers and storage" which is "worrisome as these segments will be part of 'RemainCo' after the company completes" the CSC and Micro Focus moves, FBN Securities analyst Shebly Seyrafi said in a research report.Seyrafi cut his price target on HPE stock to 25 from 26, but he maintained an outperform rating, saying "we believe that multiple negative factors hit the company all at once," including a constrained supply of needed Nand flash storage."While HPE shares benefited in 2016 from a strong capital allocation program and an aggressive plan to separate business units, core execution issues may cause worry about the pro forma EPS outlook, now $1.13-$1.23," Pacific Crest analyst Alex Kurtz wrote in a research note, maintaining a sector weight rating on the stock.RELATED:HPE Keeps Slimming, But Where's The Beef?Universal Display Hits Record High On Earnings Beat

Acacia Communications (ACIA), Nordstrom (JWN), Gap (GPS), Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and MercadoLibre (MELI) reported earnings after the close.Estimates: Wall Street expects the fiber-optic gear maker to report fourth-quarter earnings per share of 90 cents on revenue of $139.72 million.Results: EPS of 94 cents on revenue of $142.4 million.Outlook: Q1 EPS of 63-70 cents, below consensus for 78 cents, on revenue of $108 million-$114 million, below views for $137.4 million.Stock: Acacia sank 18% late. Shares closed up 1.9% at 63.43 in the stock market today, reversing higher and retaking their 50-day moving average.The company, which went public in May, makes silicon circuits, digital signal processors and other equipment to help data flow more freely through the nodes that connect a fiber-optic network.Acacia has grappled with an explosion of demand as the U.S. and China upgrade their communications infrastructure and big tech companies try to strengthen connections between massive data centers. However, Acacia's shares fell in November after the company forecast fourth-quarter sales that were only modestly above expectations.Estimates: Fiscal Q1 EPS of 44 cents, up 7% on revenue of $12.068 billion, down 5%.Results: EPS of 45 cents on revenue of $11.4 billion.Outlook: Full-year EPS of $1.88-$1.98, below consensus for $2.05.Stock: HPE tumbled 6.5% late. Shares finished 0.5% lower at 24.66, close to a 24.89 buy point of a cup base.Hewlett Packard Enterprise was created after Hewlett-Packard in 2015 split into two companies, the other being HP Inc. (HPQ), whose fiscal Q1 beat late Wednesday was helped by PC sales. HPE focuses on selling hardware and services for businesses transition to the cloud.RELATED:Splunk Q4 Earnings Easily Beat, But Stock Dives On Q1 OutlookEstimates: Fourth-quarter EPS of $1.15, down 2%, with revenue rising 4% to $4.35 billion.Results: EPS of $1.37 on revenue of $4.2 billion, and same-store sales fell 0.9%.Outlook: 2017 EPS of $2.75-$3.00, below consensus for $3.06, on a 3%-4% rise in net sales, with comp sales roughly flat.Stock: Nordstrom rose 2.7% late. Shares finished 3% lower at 43.94. The upscale apparel retailer's 50-day line undercut its 200-day line in recent days, a bearish cross.Nordstrom has been among the companies that President Trump has attacked since his election. Earlier this month, he accused the company of treating his daughter, Ivanka, "so unfairly" after the company opted not to sell Ivanka Trump-branded merchandise for now. Nordstrom said the decision was about weak sales, not politics.Politics aside, the company — like many middle-end and higher-end retailers — has foundered as Amazon (AMZN) drains the life from the U.S. mall and retail landscape.A JPMorgan analyst last year said that during talks with management, the company "cited full-line brick and mortar traffic levels as the worst since 1972 with the accelerating model shift from brick and mortar to online yet to reach equilibrium citing 'no easy answer' to restimulating foot traffic."Kohl's reported holiday earnings early Thursday, following Macy's on Tuesday.RELATED:Estimates: Fourth-quarter EPS of 51 cents, down 10.5%. Revenue is seen inching up to $4.394 billion.Results: EPS of 51 cents on revenue of $4.43 billion. Same-store sales rose 2%.Outlook: 2017 same-store sales to be flat to up slightly.Stock: Gap edged up 0.5% late. Shares ended down 3.6% at 23.97 as Gap consolidates above its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.The apparel retailer has also struggled with more vacant malls and thriving e-commerce, but has had a less contentious public relationship with Trump. CEO Art Peck was among those who attended a meeting last week at the White House between the president and retail executives.Retailers say border tax of some kind backed by the president could force them to raise prices, potentially hurting sales.Estimates: Wall Street expects the Latin America online marketplace to grow fourth-quarter EPS by 6% to 93 cents. Revenue is seen jumping 38% to $248.92 million.Results: EPS of $1.16 on revenue of $256.3 million.Stock: MercadoLibre rose 2% late. Shares closed down 0.3% at 199.82 after hitting a record high intraday. MercadoLibre broke out of a base on Jan. 24, continuing to climb steadily since then.RELATED:

Frances Hesselbein was an unlikely candidate to lead a revolution at the Girl Scouts.Her only child was a boy of 8 when a church-based troop in Johnstown, Pa., asked her to fill in as the leader for six weeks while they found a replacement for the woman who had left on a mission to India. Finding the work with girls exciting, she stayed on for eight years and in 1970 was recruited to be the executive director of the Girl Scouts of Western Pennsylvania.She began implementing the principles of the father of modern business management, Peter Drucker, and the results caught the attention of the national board, which invited her to be interviewed as a candidate to lead the Girl Scouts of the USA in 1976."I knew that since its founding in 1912, they'd always brought in some distinguished leader from the outside, but my husband insisted I apply," Hesselbein told IBD. "Figuring I had no chance, I bluntly told them they needed to go through a radical transformation to be relevant. I was shocked when two days later they offered me the job, and for the next 13 years I never had a bad day!"By the time she stepped down, the makeover had turned the Girl Scouts into a growing and vibrant organization. Today, at the start of her own second century, she heads the prestigious Frances Hesselbein Leadership Institute.Born Frances Richards on Nov. 1, 1915, in Johnstown, she had just started at the University of Pittsburgh, hoping to become a playwright, when her father died of malaria contracted while serving the Army overseas. She dropped out to help provide an income for the family. Four years later, at 22, she married John Hesselbein and they worked hard to build a small photography and advertising company.When Hesselbein was asked to lead the troop of 30 10-year-olds, she taught them not only how earn money, but to save and invest it, and took them on field trips to expand their horizons "during those eight glorious years," she said.In 1970, three business leaders she worked with on United Way fundraising urged her to take the job of executive director for the regional Girl Scout council, which was having serious financial difficulties. She agreed to do it only for six months to straighten things out. On her first day, she brought in six copies of Drucker's "The Effective Executive" for the staff to read."There was a magic about Peter's writing," she wrote in "My Life in Leadership." "He spoke to us in elegant, spare language that connected and inspired us, and moved us into the future. The vision he held before us embraced us; we made it our own. His philosophy gave us the courage to launch a quiet revolution. … Gone was the cold, austere command-and-control style of the old hierarchy. Alive and passionate were mission, values, people, accountability, and performance."Four years later, she was asked to helm the much larger regional office in York in Eastern Pennsylvania, and her husband began working for the state council for the arts in nearby Harrisburg.When Hesselbein was made CEO of the national organization, membership had been in decline for eight years and was below 2 million, with 650,000 adult volunteers and staff. She instituted Drucker's "circular management" of widely distributed responsibility. The results included:"We focused on our mission, which was to help every girl reach her potential," Hesselbein said.By the time she stepped down, membership had climbed to 2.25 million, led by 788,000 adults.Hesselbein had attended a Drucker seminar in 1981 and often turned to him for advice. He told everyone that she was the best leader he had ever met ("she could run any company"). When she stepped down from the Girl Scouts in 1990, he recruited her to head his new Foundation for Nonprofit Management in New York City, which now bears her name.So what is the difference between leadership and management?"Leadership flows from inner character and integrity of ambition, which inspires others to lend themselves to your organization's mission," she said. "Management is the set of skills that can help get things done. Unfortunately, its practice is too often a bag of manipulative tricks to advance someone's own interests, which creates cynicism."Business can learn from the social sector how to define a mission that mobilizes talents and aspirations, Hesselbein said. Overall, corporations have been improving their leadership in the past decade as they have seen the results — in better morale and connection with communities — when employees volunteer their time. She cites MetLife (MET) and Mutual of America as two outstanding examples. She has done coaching for numerous Fortune 500 clients, including Wal-Mart (WMT), HP (HPQ), Boeing (BA) and IBM (IBM).Hesselbein said women should see themselves as leaders with special experiences who can help a company achieve its goals and play a vital role in society. They could prepare to assume the responsibilities of corporate governance by sharing their talents on the boards of nonprofit organizations.She has donated her archives to the University of Pittsburgh, which now has the Hesselbein Global Academy for Student Leadership & Civic Engagement. Kevin Kearns, a professor of public and nonprofit management at the graduate school of public and international affairs, said, "Frances shares her key principles and invaluable insights about purpose, values, and ethics with a group of select students in our 18-month leadership development program. She holds an honorary doctorate not only from our university, but 20 others which have recognized her outstanding contribution and regard her as a national treasure."Hesselbein's ancestors on both sides served in the armed forces and she has been a frequent speaker at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point and other military institutions.In 1998 she was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor, as "a pioneer for women, volunteerism, diversity and opportunity." President George H.W. Bush also appointed Hesselbein to two commissions on national and community service.Hesselbein has spread the gospel of good leadership by editing "Leader to Leader," the Institute's free, award-winning quarterly journal, and traveling to 68 countries. She is now also using interactive online dialogues, Skype, YouTube, and Twitter.Asked how she thought the institute might be different in five years, Hesselbein responded, "There's a hunger for becoming better leaders all over the world, which is very exciting. We will be expanding our collaboration with powerful partners across the globe in all sectors, including free webinars for leaders at every level in poor countries."Unmentioned by the Energizer Bunny of leadership: any plan to retire.Revitalized the Girl Scouts of America and now heads a prestigious leadership training institute.Overcame: No training or experience in running a national organization.Lesson: Great leaders get their troops excited by inspiring them to contribute to decision-making."Pursuing a mission without achieving results is dispiriting; achieving results without a mission is meaningless.""Good leaders make people's strengths effective and their weaknesses irrelevant.""Communication is not saying something; communication is being heard.""You should be a living example of what you are preaching.""Dispirited, unmotivated, unappreciated workers cannot compete in a highly competitive world.""The leader for today and the future will be focused on how to be — how to develop quality, character, mindset, values and courage."MORE ABOUT SUCCESSFUL LEADERS:Nina Tassler Used Her Outsider's Insight To Succeed At CBS It's Been All Business For Packers Great, Entrepreneur Willie Davis Leaders Build Credibility On A Foundation of Integrity And Trust

In the personal computer industry, the big guys are getting bigger while the rest are shrinking.Among the major PC vendors, only the top three companies — Lenovo, HP (HPQ) and Dell Technologies (DVMT) — increased their PC shipments in the fourth quarter. The rest, including Apple (AAPL), declined significantly, research firm IDC said late Wednesday.Lenovo continued its reign as the No. 1 PC vendor worldwide in Q4, with 22.4% market share by unit shipments. The Chinese company shipped 15.7 million PCs in the fourth quarter, up 1.7% from Q4 2015, IDC said.HP was a close second with 21.7% market share in Q4. The Palo Alto, Calif.-based firm shipped 15.3 million PCs last quarter, up 6.6%.Dell was third with 15.7% market share, but posted the fastest growth among the top players in Q4. It shipped 11 million units, up 8.2%.Apple claimed fourth place with 7.5% market share in Q4, but its PC shipments fell 0.9%. Taiwan-based Asus was No. 5 with 7.4% market share, but its shipments tumbled 11.3%.Outside of the top five, the remaining PC vendors in aggregate saw their shipments fall 11.9%, IDC said.The total PC industry saw shipments fall 1.5% in Q4 to 70.2 million units.For the full year, PC shipments declined 5.7% to 260 million units, IDC said. PC sales were constrained earlier in the year by high inventories and free Microsoft (MSFT) Windows 10 upgrades."The fourth quarter results reinforce our expectations for market stabilization, and even some recovery," IDC analyst Loren Loverde said in a statement. "The contraction in traditional PC shipments experienced over the past five years finally appears to be giving way as users move to update systems. We have a good opportunity for traditional PC growth in commercial markets, while the consumer segment should also improve as it feels less pressure from slowing phone and tablet markets."The top three PC vendors — Lenovo, HP and Dell — accounted for 59.8% of total PC shipments in Q4, compared with 56% in Q4 2015.Also Wednesday, research firm Gartner estimated that global PC shipments fell 3.7% in Q4 to 72.6 million units. It measures the market in a slightly different way than IDC.RELATED:Strong Notebook PC Sales Give HP A Lift, But EPS Guide Misses
