Looking to push the legacy (i.e. old) giant tech stalwarts to use their cash piles to buy their way into faster growth, FBR analyst Daniel Ives issued a research report Thursday that praised Microsoft (MSFT) for its transition but kicked others — Cisco Systems, Oracle, IBM and Hewlett Packard — for their "treadmill approach" to expansion.And then he issued a wish-list of his top 10 tech tie-ups for 2016."It has been a choppy environment for tech players with a very bipolar IT spending backdrop," Ives said. "On the large-cap front, we have seen many changes from the HP split (into HP Inc. (HPQ) and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) to the largest tech merger ever in Dell/EMC (EMC)."Dell offered $67 billion in October to buy EMC."That said, it has been a tough road for many of these traditional tech stalwarts such as Oracle (ORCL), IBM (IBM), Cisco (CSCO) and HP, as investors have gotten used to seeing lackluster growth on a quarterly basis in light of the massive secular and company-specific challenges these mature tech vendors face," Ives said."The lone bright star in this cloudy large-cap enterprise tech space has been Microsoft, which is gaining momentum into 2016, as (CEO Satya) Nadella has made some tough decisions ('ripping the Band-Aid' off Nokia, cost cutting, free Windows 10 download strategy) to put (Microsoft) on the yellow brick road to the cloud."We believe the combination of the Dell/EMC deal, Amazon (AMZN) (Web Services') laser focus on the cloud and Nadella's 'golden child' success has put more heat in the kitchen for CEOs such as (IBM CEO Ginni) Rometty, (HPE CEO Meg) Whitman, (Oracle co-CEOs Safra Catz and Mark Hurd), and (Cisco CEO Chuck) Robbins to change from their 'treadmill approach' heading into 2016 and to focus on M&A and/or organic growth initiatives."FBR's top 10 merger-and-acquisition wish list for 2016, "in no particular order," Ives said, are:• (1) Cisco and NetApp (NTAP),• (2) Cisco and FireEye (FEYE),• (3) IBM and Splunk (SPLK),• (4) IBM and Qlik Technologies (QLIK),• (5) HPE and Box (BOX),• (6) HPE and Qlik,• (7) Oracle and Verint (VRNT),• (8) Oracle and NetSuite (N),• (9) Microsoft and Imperva (IMPV), and• (10) Microsoft and Qualys (QLYS)."... we believe EMC/Dell has disrupted the landscape and will force many of these mature tech stalwarts to finally be more aggressive in 2016 instead of fretting about valuations, as they need to focus on putting fuel back in their near-empty growth tanks," Ives said.

Employers in November announced plays to lay off 30,953 workers, the lowest since September 2014, even as 2015 cuts will likely hit a six-year high due to energy and factory job reductions.Announced layoff plans fell 39% from October, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas. Pink slips tend to fade near year-end, but plans were still down 13% vs. a year earlier.Still, the 12-month rolling total is high after spiking this summer amid a slew of job cuts, led by energy-related firms.Ailing tech titan Hewlett-Packard actually led the way with plans to cut 30,000 jobs. Hewlett-Packard has now split into two companies — printers-and-PC HP Inc. (HPQ) and corporate-focused Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE).But oil services firms Schlumberger (SLB), Halliburton (HAL) and Baker Hughes (BHI) have slashed tens of thousands of jobs, with Schlumberger recently saying it would shed more positions. Halliburton is buying Baker Hughes.Caterpillar (CAT) in September said it will cut 5,000 jobs. The company has seen weak global demand for its mining equipment.Microsoft (MSFT), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Procter & Gamble (PG) have also announced significant workforce reductions this year.However, initial jobless claims edged higher last week but remain near long-time lows, where they've been for several months.The Labor Department issues its November employment report on Friday, with economists looking for a gain of 190,000, with unemployment holding at 5%.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter @IBD_ECarson and on Facebook.

Closing the book on the 76-year legacy of Hewlett-Packard Co., Meg Whitman continued with Volume II Tuesday by chairing both successor companies and disclosing that the former company's final Q4 earnings missed Wall Street projections.
But she also guided one of the successor company's fiscal 2016 forecasts higher than Wall Street estimates.
Thus, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock was up 2.5% in after-hours trading, after the earnings release.

As of the Nov. 1 start of the fiscal year, Hewlett-Packard Co. split into two separate companies, HP Inc. (HPQ), the PC and printer business, and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, which sells systems and provides services for businesses and other enterprise clients.
Whitman is CEO of HPE.
Hewlett-Packard Co. earned 93 cents per share minus items in its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31, down 12%, on revenue of $25.7 billion, down 9%.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 97 cents on $26.35 billion.

Hewlett Packard Enterprise segment sales fell 4% to $14.1 billion, but was up 3% in constant currency, the company said. It was the second consecutive quarter of year-to-year constant currency revenue growth, the company said.
Analysts were expecting Enterprise to post pro forma Q4 revenue of $13.5 billion in Q4.
Analysts also estimated that it would earn 52 cents per share minus items in Q4.

The Enterprise company reaffirmed its fiscal 2016 outlook of $1.85-$1.95 in adjusted earnings per share, with the $1.90 midpoint higher than the $1.88 estimated by analysts on revenue of $50.81 billion.

"Hewlett Packard Enterprise is off to a very strong start," said Whitman in the earnings release. "The new company's business segments delivered a second consecutive quarter of constant currency revenue growth in Q4, and we believe that momentum will accelerate into fiscal '16."

Analysts and investors are still focused on "management's thoughts on the overall IT spending environment, cloud initiatives, restructuring/cost-cutting initiatives, and importantly comments around (Hewlett Packard Enterprise's) M&A strategy and how this could affect the rest of the tech space in 2016 and beyond," FBR analyst Daniel Ives wrote in a pre-release research note.Closing the book on the 76-year legacy of Hewlett-Packard Co., Meg Whitman continued with Volume II Tuesday by chairing both successor companies and disclosing that the former company's final Q4 earnings missed Wall Street projections.But she also guided one of the successor company's fiscal 2016 forecasts higher than Wall Street estimates.Thus, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock was up 2.5% in after-hours trading, after the earnings release.As of the Nov. 1 start of the fiscal year, Hewlett-Packard Co. split into two separate companies, HP Inc. (HPQ), the PC and printer business, and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, which sells systems and provides services for businesses and other enterprise clients.Whitman is CEO of HPE.Hewlett-Packard Co. earned 93 cents per share minus items in its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31, down 12%, on revenue of $25.7 billion, down 9%.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 97 cents on $26.35 billion.Hewlett Packard Enterprise segment sales fell 4% to $14.1 billion, but was up 3% in constant currency, the company said. It was the second consecutive quarter of year-to-year constant currency revenue growth, the company said.Analysts were expecting Enterprise to post pro forma Q4 revenue of $13.5 billion in Q4.Analysts also estimated that it would earn 52 cents per share minus items in Q4.The Enterprise company reaffirmed its fiscal 2016 outlook of $1.85-$1.95 in adjusted earnings per share, with the $1.90 midpoint higher than the $1.88 estimated by analysts on revenue of $50.81 billion."Hewlett Packard Enterprise is off to a very strong start," said Whitman in the earnings release. "The new company's business segments delivered a second consecutive quarter of constant currency revenue growth in Q4, and we believe that momentum will accelerate into fiscal '16."Analysts and investors are still focused on "management's thoughts on the overall IT spending environment, cloud initiatives, restructuring/cost-cutting initiatives, and importantly comments around (Hewlett Packard Enterprise's) M&A strategy and how this could affect the rest of the tech space in 2016 and beyond," FBR analyst Daniel Ives wrote in a pre-release research note.

Newly minted PC and printer company HP Inc. (HPQ) late Tuesday gave its first guidance as a publicly traded company — and it was a letdown. For the current quarter, HP Inc.'s fiscal Q1, it expects earnings per share minus items of 33 to 38 cents, vs. analyst expectations for 42 cents. On a GAAP basis, it is targeting EPS…
Apple (AAPL), HP Inc. (HPQ), Merck (MRK), IBM (IBM) and Intel (INTC) are among the U.S. stocks described as having the best value, as measured by free cash flow yield.

Assessing a company's value using free cash flow puts a greater emphasis on retained profit vs. earnings plowed back into capital expenditures, said Citigroup analyst Robert Buckland in a note cited by Barron's.
Among U.S. companies on the list, oilfield services provider Baker Hughes (BHI) leads with an estimated free cash flow yield of 21.7%, despite the ongoing slump in oil prices.
It's followed by Viacom (VIAB) and Whole Foods Market (WFM) with yields of 13.8% and 12.5%, respectively.

Also on the list is Apple, with an estimated yield of 10.5%. The company has had a tremendous run, and the iPhone 6, Apple Watch and Apple TV may keep the party going. Apple is expected to unveil the latest version of its smartwatch at an event in March.

Apple closed down 2.2% on the stock market today. Baker Hughes climbed 7.4% on reports Halliburton (HAL) may be closer to finalizing its acquisition of Baker Hughes. Viacom lost 1.5%, and Whole Foods climbed 1.6%.

HP has a yield of 11.4%, though PC sales have slowed for several years as mobile devices take market share. But "there's nearly 450 million PCs out there that are older than 4-1/2 years," HP Chair Meg Whitman said last month. "And at some point, our belief is that people are going to upgrade those PCs. And I think HP Inc. is well positioned when that happens."
HP stock closed down 0.7% Wednesday.
Drug giant Merck has a 9.2% yield, though it faces a growing number of generic drug rivals. Still, it has a strong pipeline of new drugs in various stages of development. Merck dropped 1.2%.
IBM has an estimated 8.9% yield, as it flexes the muscle of its powerful Watson supercomputer with the launch of the Cognitive Business Solutions unit. IBM fell 1%.
Intel, like HP, has been hit hard by the decline of the traditional PC. But prospects have perked up recently with the Internet of Things, and it enjoys an 8.2% yield. Intel shares edged up 0.2%.

Citi's value stock list also includes Las Vegas Sands (LVS) (8.8% yield), Macy's (M)(10.7%), and U.S. local telephone services provider CenturyLink (CTL) (10.3%).Apple (AAPL), HP Inc. It should be among the most unusual earnings conference calls in corporate history — certainly in Hewlett Packard Enterprise's (HPE) history, which by the time the company reports after the close Tuesday will have gone back, oh, 24 days since it became a company, though it's also 76 years old and could claim to be the pioneering Silicon Valley tech outfit.Reporting its fiscal Q4, which ended Oct. 31, Meg Whitman will hold court as both the new chairwoman and chief executive of Hewlett Packard Enterprise and as the continuing chairwoman and former chair and CEO of the former Hewlett-Packard, now known as HP Inc. (HPQ).HP Inc. kept the former Hewlett-Packard's ticker, HPQ. Hewlett Packard Enterprise got a new ticker, HPE.HP Inc. keeps the legacy computers and printer businesses. Hewlett Packard Enterprise takes the more ephemeral but — some analysts say — more promising enterprise services and cloud-enabled technologies businesses.In the past week, investors bid up Enterprise stock 6%, and 3% on Friday alone, to 14.21. That was its second best day of the month but still 5.5% off its open Nov. 2.Q4 might also be known as a clean-up quarter, a place to book some of the losses and charges related to the restructuring. Whitman said in September that the reorganization will impact cash by about $2.6 billion over three years starting in the current year, its fiscal 2016."These restructuring activities will enable a more competitive, sustainable cost structure for the new Hewlett Packard Enterprise," Whitman said in September. "We've done a significant amount of work over the past few years to take costs out and simplify processes, and these final actions will eliminate the need for any future corporate restructuring."Cost savings are coming, in part, from the elimination of as many as 30,000 jobs from Hewlett Packard Enterprise, three years after the old, combined Hewlett-Packard cut 55,000 jobs. At the time of the September Q3 earnings release, the combined company had about 302,000 jobs.For Q4 2015, the old Hewlett-Packard estimated that EPS minus items for the entire company would range from 92 to 98 cents. The estimate excludes 80 cents in separation costs and other charges.Analysts ascribed more than half of that income, 52 cents, to the future Hewlett Packard Enterprise. Thomson Reuters analysts estimated Q4 revenue at $13.5 billion.For Q1, ending Jan. 31, analysts expect Enterprise to earn 44 cents per share, minus items, on $12.77 billion in revenue.In Q3, ended July 31, the old Enterprise Group sales rose 2%, with a 13% operating margin, the old company said."While we have to wait for HP's Q4 results to see the first full post-split balance-sheet details, HPE's filings disclose a pro-forma cash and investment position totaled approximately $11.5 billion exiting Q3," wrote Stifel analyst Aaron Rakers in a research report. "HPE's total debt position stands at (about) $16 billion; however, it is important to note that this includes about $10.6 billion on HP Financial Services debt. This leaves HPE net operating cash at approximately $5.5 billion exiting Q3 (excluding about $615 million of reported HPFS cash)."We would note that prior conversations have suggested that HPE will be focused on maintaining an investment-grade debt rating or a debt-to-EBITDA in the 2.0x-2.5x range."We expect investors to focus on HPE's capacity to make strategic acquisitions."Stifel initiated Hewlett Packard Enterprise with a hold rating.

HP Inc. (HPQ) is making "Star Wars"-themed personal computers, but the Force definitely wasn't with the PC and printer maker late Tuesday when it reported fiscal-fourth-quarter earnings.HP's PC and printer businesses brought in revenue of $12.66 billion in fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31, down 14.2% year over year. The PC and printer businesses racked up earnings before taxes of $1.16 billion, down 18%.The Palo Alto, Calif.-based company also gave disappointing guidance.For the current quarter, its fiscal Q1, HP expects earnings per share minus items of 33 to 38 cents, vs. analyst expectations for 42 cents. On a GAAP basis, it is targeting EPS of 27 to 32 cents, vs. Wall Street's view of 38 cents.For fiscal 2016, ending Oct. 31, 2016, HP expects to earn $1.59 to $1.69 a share excluding items, where analysts were modeling for $1.71. On a GAAP basis, its EPS guidance was in line with forecasts, at $1.50 to $1.60 vs. expectations for $1.54.HP did not give sales guidance.HP stock plunged 14% Wednesday, to 12.64.Needham analyst David Rold downgraded HP stock to hold from buy on Wednesday.Wells Fargo Securities analyst Maynard Um on Tuesday cut his valuation range on HP stock to 14.50 to 16, down from 16.50 to 18, but he continues to rate HP stock as outperform.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brent Bracelin reiterated his sector weight rating on HP stock, which he said was fairly valued between 13.50 and 14.'Consolidating Markets'The PC and printer markets are likely to be challenging for several more quarters, HP CEO Dion Weisler said on the company's earnings conference call with analysts."Q4 was a difficult quarter and somewhat weaker than we expected," he said. HP remains a leader in two "large, consolidating markets," he said.The PC market has been tough, especially in the consumer segment, because of elevated sales channel inventory, Weisler said.Also, Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows 10 operating system has yet to spark a rebound in PC sales.But on the commercial side of the PC business, HP achieved its highest market share position ever at 23.7%, Weisler said."We believe that innovation and sprinkles of magic are key to differentiation as the PC market goes through consolidation," Weisler said. He pointed to the company's new lineup of enterprise and consumer PCs, including a Star Wars Special Edition Notebook PC made in partnership with Walt Disney (DIS) and Lucasfilm.The former Hewlett-Packard split into two companies on Nov. 1. HP Inc. sells personal computers and printers, while Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) sells information technology hardware, software and services to corporations and other enterprises. HP Inc. and HPE reported results together Tuesday, as Q4 was their last quarter together before their split."Both companies are off and running," Meg Whitman, chairman of HP Inc. and chairman and CEO of HPE, said on the call. "Each company has a clear, well-defined strategy and is well positioned to win in its respective market."In Q4, HP's PC unit sales were down 12% from the year-earlier quarter, with desktops down 17% and notebooks down 5%. HP has walked away from volume PC deals that don't meet its profit margin targets, Weisler said.HP's printer hardware unit sales were down 17%, with commercial units down 23% and consumer units down 14%. Supplies revenue was down 10%.Speaking on CNBC on Wednesday, Whitman said HP Inc. performed well in a "tough PC market."While Windows 10 hasn't provided a catalyst yet for PC upgrades, she still says that will happen."There's nearly 450 million PCs out there that are older than 4-1/2 years," she said. "And at some point, our belief is that people are going to upgrade those PCs. And I think HP Inc. is well positioned when that happens."Follow Patrick Seitz on Twitter @IBD_PSeitz and on Facebook.

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock jumped as much as 8.5% Wednesday after the company late Tuesday posted fiscal Q4 revenue that beat views and guided fiscal 2016 performance better than analysts expected.Hewlett Packard Enterprise stock ended the day at 14.12, up 3.1%."Our overall opinion on HPE remains unchanged" after the earnings call, wrote Needham analyst Richard Kugele in a research report. He said the stock "already reflects an anticipated stabilization in some of its most troubled areas."He said positives include growth in large, tier-one hyperscale servers, while negatives included a decline in services revenue."Overall, the outlook for FY16 is unchanged (albeit more back-end loaded) and the stock is likely range-bound at current levels," said Kugele, who maintained a hold rating on HPE stock.Responding to those who say HPE isn't selling enough services and products in the cloud, company CEO Meg Whitman told CNBC Wednesday that spending for private cloud products — networks and data centers that businesses keep in-house, which is HPE's focus — is growing as fast as public cloud. "Most people don't understand that," she said."Yesterday, we announced that we were partnering with Microsoft (MFST) Azure to provide the public cloud," she told CNBC. "And then we have this great cloud system automation that helps you orchestrate your clouds in your data center. So if you think about where the money is spent today, interestingly, still about 85% of the spend is in traditional I.T. ... The next-biggest segment is private cloud. And the next after that is public cloud. And private and public cloud are growing at about the same rate."So we are going right to the heart of what our customers are asking. And I feel really good about our strategy and excited about the partnership that we announced yesterday with Microsoft Azure."Microsoft Azure competes with market leader Amazon Web Services, a unit of Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and others in providing public cloud services.Needham's Kugele liked the Azure partnership and the fact that HPE was "abdicating" in the public cloud sector, but he pointed out that Azure is fighting against AWS, "and ultimate success is going to be a marathon and not a sprint."New Era BeginsEnterprise is roughly half — most analysts say the more promising half — of the Nov. 1 split of the legendary 76-year-old Hewlett-Packard Co. The other half, HP Inc. (HPQ), focuses on the PC and printer businesses, and it kept the old HPQ ticker.The Q4 report was the last for the old company, which Whitman also chaired. It earned 93 cents per share minus items in its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31, down 12%, on revenue of $25.7 billion, down 9%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 97 cents on $26.35 billion.Enterprise's pro forma portion of Q4 sales fell 4% to $14.1 billion but was up 3% in constant currency. Analysts were expecting Enterprise to post Q4 revenue of $13.5 billion.Enterprise reaffirmed its fiscal 2016 outlook of $1.85-$1.95 in adjusted earnings per share, with the $1.90 midpoint higher than the $1.88 estimated by analysts on revenue of $50.81 billion.Whitman told analysts in the conference call following Tuesday's earnings release that HPE "will double down on our private and managed cloud (efforts), and sunset our public cloud." Of "the move to a hybrid cloud environment ... you can expect to hear more."Needham analyst Kugele said that with HPE still on its way to 30,000 layoffs, and the service business determined to "drag its margins higher through careful contract signings, we are most focused on the storage and server opportunity for HPE. In servers, the lumpy buying pattern of tier-1 hyperscale customers helped them in the quarter but is hardly consistently reliable."Nevertheless we expect the segment to show slight growth in fiscal '16."He said storage has benefited from "aggressive pricing," but he sees more competition from rivals such as NetApp (NTAP) and Pure Storage (PSTG)."Bottom line, there are more puts and takes and caveats than investors should accept in a long thesis," Kugele wrote. "Staying on the sidelines."

Stocks pared intraday gains to close narrowly mixed ahead of Thanksgiving Day. The Nasdaq led with a 0.3% gain, the Dow Jones industrial average was fractionally higher and the S&P 500 was slightly lower. Volume was sharply lower across the board vs. Tuesday, according to preliminary data — not surprising for the day before Thanksgiving.
Winners topped losers by a 3-2 margin on the NYSE and 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.

Automakers were among top gainers in the stock market today, thanks to Tesla's (TSLA) 5% move sparked by a bullish Credit Suisse report. IBD 50 stock Monster Beverage (MNST) rose 3% to clear a 154 cup-with-handle buy point and boost the nonalcoholic beverage group.

Among other IBD 50 stocks, Universal Display (OLED) led gainers with a 7% pop in heavy volume as it builds the right side of a steep, cup-shaped base with a 55.93 buy point. Shares surged 22% last week on comments by CFO Sidney Rosenblatt that Apple (AAPL) supplier Foxconn ordered OLED manufacturing equipment for 2017. He also said he thinks "it's only a matter of time" before Apple starts using OLED technology in its products.

Foreign banks lagged as Argentine bank holding company Grupo Financiero Galicia (GGAL) sank 5% in heavy volume for a third straight down session. It triggered a sell signal Monday after giving up a double-digit gain from a 26.23 buy point.

HP (HPQ) gapped down and fell 13% in fast trade after the PC and printer maker late Tuesday reported quarterly results and issued weak guidance. It was its last report as a combined company with Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), which was spun off earlier this month. The spinoff's shares gained 3%.

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock jumped as much as 8.5% Wednesday after the company late Tuesday posted fiscal Q4 revenue that beat views and guided fiscal 2016 performance better than analysts expected.Hewlett Packard Enterprise stock ended the day at 14.12, up 3.1%."Our overall opinion on HPE remains unchanged" after the earnings call, wrote Needham analyst Richard Kugele in a research report. He said the stock "already reflects an anticipated stabilization in some of its most troubled areas."He said positives include growth in large, tier-one hyperscale servers, while negatives included a decline in services revenue."Overall, the outlook for FY16 is unchanged (albeit more back-end loaded) and the stock is likely range-bound at current levels," said Kugele, who maintained a hold rating on HPE stock.Responding to those who say HPE isn't selling enough services and products in the cloud, company CEO Meg Whitman told CNBC Wednesday that spending for private cloud products — networks and data centers that businesses keep in-house, which is HPE's focus — is growing as fast as public cloud. "Most people don't understand that," she said."Yesterday, we announced that we were partnering with Microsoft (MFST) Azure to provide the public cloud," she told CNBC. "And then we have this great cloud system automation that helps you orchestrate your clouds in your data center. So if you think about where the money is spent today, interestingly, still about 85% of the spend is in traditional I.T. ... The next-biggest segment is private cloud. And the next after that is public cloud. And private and public cloud are growing at about the same rate."So we are going right to the heart of what our customers are asking. And I feel really good about our strategy and excited about the partnership that we announced yesterday with Microsoft Azure."Microsoft Azure competes with market leader Amazon Web Services, a unit of Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and others in providing public cloud services.Needham's Kugele liked the Azure partnership and the fact that HPE was "abdicating" in the public cloud sector, but he pointed out that Azure is fighting against AWS, "and ultimate success is going to be a marathon and not a sprint."New Era BeginsEnterprise is roughly half — most analysts say the more promising half — of the Nov. 1 split of the legendary 76-year-old Hewlett-Packard Co. The other half, HP Inc. (HPQ), focuses on the PC and printer businesses, and it kept the old HPQ ticker.The Q4 report was the last for the old company, which Whitman also chaired. It earned 93 cents per share minus items in its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31, down 12%, on revenue of $25.7 billion, down 9%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 97 cents on $26.35 billion.Enterprise's pro forma portion of Q4 sales fell 4% to $14.1 billion but was up 3% in constant currency. Analysts were expecting Enterprise to post Q4 revenue of $13.5 billion.Enterprise reaffirmed its fiscal 2016 outlook of $1.85-$1.95 in adjusted earnings per share, with the $1.90 midpoint higher than the $1.88 estimated by analysts on revenue of $50.81 billion.Whitman told analysts in the conference call following Tuesday's earnings release that HPE "will double down on our private and managed cloud (efforts), and sunset our public cloud." Of "the move to a hybrid cloud environment ... you can expect to hear more."Needham analyst Kugele said that with HPE still on its way to 30,000 layoffs, and the service business determined to "drag its margins higher through careful contract signings, we are most focused on the storage and server opportunity for HPE. In servers, the lumpy buying pattern of tier-1 hyperscale customers helped them in the quarter but is hardly consistently reliable."Nevertheless we expect the segment to show slight growth in fiscal '16."He said storage has benefited from "aggressive pricing," but he sees more competition from rivals such as NetApp (NTAP) and Pure Storage (PSTG)."Bottom line, there are more puts and takes and caveats than investors should accept in a long thesis," Kugele wrote. "Staying on the sidelines."

Workday (WDAY) got price target hikes from at least three investment banks after its Q2 earnings late Wednesday beat expectations, but the company remains firmly in the red as its rising costs outpace its fast revenue growth.
Workday stock was down more than 2% in early trading in the stock market today, near 88.

The maker of HR, financial and recruiting software delivered via the Internet cloud posted a 74% jump in year-over-year revenue for its fiscal Q2 ended July 31, to $186.8 million. But total costs rose 78% to $248.5 million.

The company's revenue guidance for the current quarter also beat Wall Street expectations. But analysts are modeling a 14-cent per-share loss minus items for the quarter, up from a 12-cent loss in the year-ago quarter. Workday doesn't give profit guidance. Its Q2 loss minus items of 11 cents a share beat the 14 cents analysts had forecast, however.
Analysts remain upbeat.

In a report Thursday, Steve Koenig, an analyst for Wedbush Securities, says Workday likely has about a 10% to 12% share of the human capital management software market and less than 5% of the combined HCM software and payroll outsourcing market, "leaving plenty of room to expand there." He rates Workday stock outperform and raised his price target to 106 from 96.

"The company has gained rapid momentum in the global HR market dominated by Oracle (ORCL) and SAP (SAP) and it's poised to make a dent in financial management applications for the mid-market and increasingly larger enterprises," Koenig wrote. "Our checks with integrators suggest Workday has the most complete HR functionality in the software-as-a-service market and is well-positioned to lead the adoption of SaaS financials, as a result of its first mover advantage and rapid product cycles."

Steven Ashley, an analyst for Robert W. Baird & Co., raised his price target to 100 from 95 after the company reported billings growth of 56%, and said it had signed up its largest customer yet last quarter, Bank of America (BAC), and its 300,000 employees. He also rates Workday stock outperform.
Ashley said Europe was "ramping nicely," and said the addition of Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC) as new system integrator partners was a plus.

Employment costs rise 0.7% in Q2The employment cost index rose 0.7% last quarter, above estimates of 0.5% and the fastest increase since '08, the Labor Dept. said. The rise possibly puts upward pressure on inflation. Wages grew 0.6%, the most since Q3 '08. The yearly wage gain of 1.8% was still contained. Benefits grew 1% for the quarter and 2.5% for the year, led by retirement benefit increases. Health benefits rose 2.7% for the year, up from 2.6% in the prior year.
Jobless claims back above 300,000

Initial claims for unemployment benefits rose to 302,000 in the week ended July 26. That followed a drop in claims to a 14-year low of 279,000 the prior week, revised down from the 284,000 initially reported. The four-week average of claims fell by 3,500 to 297,250, dipping below 300,000 for the first time since '06. Claims can be volatile this time of year due to auto-plant equipment changeovers. Continuing claims rose 31,000 to 2.54 mil in the week of July 19.
Challenger: Job cuts head back up from '14 low

U.S.-based employers announced 46,887 job cuts in July, up from 31,434 in June, Challenger, Gray & Christmas said. The cuts were dominated by the tech sector, with Microsoft (MSFT) announcing as many as 18,000 layoffs and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) 16,000. In the first seven months of '14, firms announced 292,921 job cuts, down 1.3% from the same period in '13.

 Chicago factory activity slowed in July by the sharpest pace since '08 but stayed about the neutral 50 level. The Chicago PMI gauge fell to 52.6 from 62.6, hitting the lowest in the more than a year. Gauges of production and orders both fell sharply, but surveyed purchasing managers described the slowdown as a temporary lull.

 The 30-year fixed-rate mortgage averaged 4.12% in the week ended July 31, down from 4.13% the prior week, Freddie Mac said. The 15-year fixed-rate mortgage dipped to 3.23% from 3.26%. The 5-year adjustable-rate mortgage averaged 3.01%, up from 2.99%.
Eurozone inflation cools again

Eurozone consumer prices rose just 0.4% in July from a year ago, down from June's 0.5% annual gain. The closer brush with deflation largely reflected a 1% drop in energy prices. Core inflation, stripping out food and energy, held steady at 0.8%. Deflation is even more of a worry in individual countries than the region as a whole. Prices fell 0.3% from a year ago in Spain and were unchanged over the same period in Italy. Prices rose 0.8% in Germany.
Eurozone jobless rate falls to 11.5%

Eurozone unemployment eased to 11.5% in June from 11.6% in May, reaching the lowest level in nearly two years. The ranks of the unemployed fell by 152,000 from May, the biggest monthly drop in '14. Compared with a year ago, there were 783,000 fewer jobless, but 18.4 mil remained without work. The jobless rate stood at 27.3% in Greece, 24.5% in Spain and 5.1% in Germany.

 German retail sales rose a better-than-expected 1.3% in June, spurred by Germany's World Cup exploits. French consumer spending was also unexpectedly robust in the month, growing 0.9% from May vs. expectations of 0.1%.

 Japan wages rose 0.4% in June vs. a year ago, slower than the 0.6% and 0.7% gains in May and April. But real wages fell 3.8% from a year ago for the second month as consumer purchasing power was hurt by a recent sales tax hike. That's the biggest drop since '09.
COMING UP FRIDAY

 Personal spending, income for June, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: income and spending both up 0.4%).
 ISM Manufacturing survey for July, 10 a.m. ET (forecast: 56.0).

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) seems poised to continue its recent positive performance in notebooks and commercial business revenue, Brent Bracelin, an analyst for Pacific Crest Securities, said in a research report Friday, ahead of HP's Discover user conference next week.
HP's notebook and commercial business revenue rose by 7% and 12%, respectively, year over year in fiscal Q2 ended April 30, Bracelin said.

"Our semiconductor team raised our notebook forecasts for the month of May based on enterprise-PC demand trends, which remain healthy," he wrote. "Despite this being a small uptick, it was an encouraging sign that perhaps a corporate refresh cycle has legs beyond just the (Microsoft) XP (operating system) expiration in April."
In April, Microsoft ceased offering support for its 12-year-old, but still popular, Windows XP operating system.
Bracelin also expects big things to come out of HP's Discover user conference.

"Not only do we expect HP to weigh in on how its new product and service offerings are enabling Big Data and cloud, but we also expect to hear an update on new innovations coming out of HP Labs," he wrote.

HP has posted a year-over-year decline in revenue in its past 11 quarters, as the company works through a five-year restructuring effort launched in May 2012 and aimed at pushing growth in its emerging cloud, Big Data, security and other businesses to offset declines in its core PC and printing units, which provide the bulk of its revenue.

But HP reported year-over-year growth in its PC business in the past two quarters. HP posted disappointing Q2 revenue last month, but it also said that it would lay off more employees to cut costs further, and the stock continued its uptrend.

HP stock is up more than 20% in 2014, though shares were down a fraction in afternoon trading in the stock market today.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) seems poised to continue its recent positive performance in notebooks and commercial business revenue, Brent Bracelin, an analyst for Pacific Crest Securities, said in a research report Friday, ahead of HP's Discover user conference next week.HP's notebook and commercial business revenue rose by 7% and 12%, respectively, year over year in fiscal Q2 ended April 30, Bracelin said."Our semiconductor team raised our notebook forecasts for the month of May based on enterprise-PC demand trends, which remain healthy," he wrote. Thin opening gains firmed in early action Wednesday following a flood of primarily positive economic news. The Nasdaq rolled ahead 0.3%, while the Dow and the S&P 500 held to 0.1% gains.Volume faded about 20% each on the NYSE and the Nasdaq, compared with action at the same time on Tuesday.The stock market today launched to a heavy slate of economic news, led by better than expected — or at least as good as expected — October durable goods orders, weekly unemployment claim and personal income numbers.The preliminary services sector estimate from researcher Markit was also positive, with its Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 56.5 for November, up from 54.4 and above economist projections of 55. Employment gains aided the bounce off October's nine-month low, but business confidence remained subdued, the report said.Also above expectation: the Federal Housing Finance Agency's September House Price Index, which leaped 0.8%, up from August's 0.3% rise and vs. consensus projections for an 0.4% rise.New home sales jumped to an annualized rate of 495,000 in October, the Commerce Department reported. The reports also revised September's rate lower, to 447,000. Economist consensus had forecast a November increase to a rate of 499,000 homes sold.The University of Michigan offered the morning's leading down note. The final reading of its November Consumer Sentiment Index dipped to 91.3 — above October's tally of 90 but down from a preliminary November estimate of 93.1 and below views for no change.Oil prices were still down more than 1%, but losses eased a bit on the approach to the Energy Information Administration's 10:30 a.m. weekly report on inventories.Oil-related stocks held eight of the 10 worst losses among S&P 500 companies in early action. Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) posted to the worst opening declines on the Dow.In other stocks, nothing runs like a Deere, the ads say, and that was true Wednesday morning as Deere (DE) led the S&P 500 after narrowing a 5% gain to 3%. The agricultural and construction equipment maker reported its fiscal fourth quarter earnings fell less than consensus forecasts. The stock is trying to climb off the floor of a three-month consolidation.Freshly halved PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) dived 13% at the start of trade. IT services and equipment sibling Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) surged 6%. The company late Tuesday reported its last full quarter as a combined outfit, following the Nov. 1 split into separate operations.Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) charged ahead almost 4%, continuing its rebound from its week-ago low. The stock is deep in a year-long correction, attempting to retake support at its 10-week moving average.Electronic Arts (EA) jumped 3%, attempting to bounce back from the two-day sell-off that appeared to follow comments from retailer GameStop (GME) that sales of EA's Star Wars Battlefront were weaker than expected.On the IBD 50 list, Euronet Worldwide (EEFT) climbed more than 2% at the start of trade. It put the stock in buying range on a rebound from its 10-week moving average. It is the first test since the ATM and card payment processor broke out above a cup base in September.China-based online game provider NetEase (NTES) added nearly 2%. The stock is working on its seventh straight gain and is extended above a 154.98 buy point.Overseas, Europe's market powered higher following mostly positive U.S. economic news. Benchmark indexes in London, Paris and Frankfurt traded higher in afternoon action, led by Frankfurt's DAX, up 1.7%.

Stock futures stuck to steady, slender gains ahead of Wednesday's open as investors dug through a trove of fresh economic news and earnings reports.Dow futures flew straight and level, up 33.8 points. Nasdaq 100 futures showed a 10.2-point gain. S&P 500 futures traded 2.6 points above fair market value.The stock market today gets a bellyful of economic news, as government agencies clear the decks before their Thanksgiving break.Personal income jumped 0.4% — in line with estimates — in October, the Commerce Department reported, while revising its September estimate upward to 0.2%. A 0.1% gain in consumer spending stopped short of projections for a 0.3% improvement. Prices popped 0.1%, reversing September's 0.1% decline, but stopping short of projections for a 0.2% increase. Core prices, minus energy and food, were flat — below expectations for a 0.2% gain.The Commerce Department also said durable goods orders jumped 3% in October, and revised September's decline from 1.2% to 0.8%. Orders for commercial aircraft boosted October's numbers. Minus transportation, orders rose a slimmer 0.5%. Economists had projected an overall 1.5% gain for the month and a 0.4% improvement minus transportation.Jobless claims slowed to 260,000 in the week ended Nov. 21, down more than 4% from the prior week and better than estimates for a slight decline to 270,000 claims. The Labor Department also reported the four-week moving average continued to tick higher, to 271,000.The Federal Housing Finance Agency sets out its September Housing Price Index at 9 a.m. ET. Researcher Markit reports its preliminary service purchasing managers' index for November at 9:45. At 10 a.m., look for October new-home sales from the Commerce Department and a final November consumer sentiment estimate from the University of Michigan.Oil will be in focus later this morning, when the Energy Information Administration releases its weekly inventories data at 10:30. In early trading, oil prices erased most of their gains from Tuesday, down nearly 2%. Nymex gasoline futures fell almost 3%.The majority of Dow stocks remained flat ahead of the open. Pfizer (PFE) led the handful of gainers with a 0.9% advance. Intel (INTC) dropped 0.8%, the biggest decline.The flow of earnings reports had slowed to a trickle, but still continued to kick up major moves.Apparel retailer Guess (GES) powered up 7% after a solid Q3 report late Tuesday. China-based social networking site Momo (MOMO) popped 6%, despite a sales and earnings miss, as its monthly active users rose 21% to 73 million in September.Deere (DE) cranked up a 5% advance as its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings fell to $1.08 a share, far above consensus views for a fall to 75 cents. Revenue fell 26%, also better than expected. Management's outlook essentially said sales would deteriorate at an improved pace. Deere shares are in a three-month consolidation, ending Tuesday 22% below an August high.Hewlett Packard's two companies went in different directions following their first quarterly report released since the Nov. 1 divorce.HP Inc. (HPQ), the PC and printer manufacturer, tumbled 9% after announcing late Tuesday it sees fiscal Q1 and full-year earnings below consensus expectations. HP shares ended Tuesday 33% above an early October low, working to climb the right side of a 10-month consolidation.Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), the information technology hardware, software and service unit, was up 5% before the open. HPE shares have been consolidating since their Nov. 1 launch.In their last quarter as a combined company, HP's earnings and revenue fell further than expected by analysts.Leading stocks were predominately quiet in premarket trade, with stocks on the IBD 50 and Your Weekly Review lists holding to gains or losses of less than 1%.Overseas, markets across Asia were narrowly mixed, with the leading indexes in Hong Kong and Tokyo posting mild losses. European markets bounced higher after harsh losses on Tuesday. Benchmark indexes in London, Paris and Frankfurt traded up around 1% at midday.
Add another analyst feeling better about Oracle (ORCL) sales after second-quarter field checks showed improvement, especially in cloud revenue.
Feeling better, however, is not the same as feeling great.
Oracle will let investors know how fairly Wall Street has been feeling its pain/gain when it releases fiscal Q2 results after the market closes Wednesday.
The 32 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters say earnings should fall 13% from a year earlier to 60 cents per share minus items, on revenue down 5.6% to $9.06 billion for its Q2 ended Nov. 30.

As Oracle's performance has been unkind to growth-oriented investor's lately — earnings were down 15% year to year in each of the past two quarters and dead flat in the two quarters before — investors have sold off. Oracle company stock mostly has been consolidating since Thanksgiving and traded this past week near 38.20, about 16% below its 52-week high set Christmas Eve at 46.70.

Pacific Crest Securities' Brendan Barnicle, like Goldman Sachs' Heather Bellini last month, returned from the field with Q2 sales checks that "were in line or better than expectations," he wrote in a research note issued Wednesday. "Additionally, (channel sales) partners reported increasing momentum for Oracle in the cloud. We heard that usability and functionality continue to improve and drive increased cloud adoption from legacy on-premise Oracle customers.
"In the Pacific Crest Q4 CIO Survey, the feedback for Oracle was very encouraging."

In maintaining Pacific Crest's sector weight rating for Oracle, Barnicle stated the case: "Oracle is seeing an acceleration in cloud, specifically in its SaaS (software as a service) and PaaS (platform as a service) product line, which is likely to create uncertainty and inconsistency in its model during this transition. Therefore, despite a relatively attractive valuation, we see limited upside in ORCL from current levels."

Last month, Goldman Sachs analyst Heather Bellini upgraded Oracle to conviction buy from buy, suggesting that Oracle's earnings may have found some footing "if Oracle is successful in attaining fiscal '16 bookings targets." She said field checks give Goldman "growing confidence" in those booking targets, so she'd "expect management to guide to accelerating cloud-revenue growth in fiscal '17, and with gross margins expanding, we believe fiscal '16 will mark the bottom in non-GAAP operating margins."

Oracle Executive Chairman Larry Ellison said in the Q1 earnings announcement that the company is "still on target to book between $1.5 billion and $2.0 billion of new SaaS and PaaS business this fiscal year. That means Oracle would sell between 50% more (than) and double the amount of new cloud business (as)Salesforce.com (CRM) plans to sell in their current fiscal year.
"Oracle is the world's second largest SaaS and PaaS company, but we are rapidly closing in on No. 1."

Oracle is sailing against the "same headwinds," FBR analyst Daniel Ives said in early November, as other "mature, tech stalwarts" such as IBM (IBM), Cisco (CSCO), newly divided Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and HP Inc. (HPQ), and EMC (EMC) and Dell, which are merging.

A Wall Street darling with its stock trading at record highs, upstart Salesforce.com is an SaaS niche player with sales of about $6.3 billion, one-sixth Oracle's revenue. Salesforce enjoys a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99. Ahead of Thanksgiving Day, stocks inched higher Wednesday in quiet volume. The Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq rose 0.1% each while the S&P 500 ticked up a fraction. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking well below Tuesday's levels in the stock market today.Pfizer (PFE) was the best performer in the Dow, rising 3%. It recently announced plans to buy Allergan (AGN) for around $160 billion.In economic news, personal income rose 0.4% in October, in line with estimates. Spending came up a bit short, rising 0.1%. The Commerce Department also said durable goods orders jumped 3% in October, double expectations. Excluding transportation, orders rose 0.5%, a tad better than expected.In earnings news, PC and printer manufacturer HP (HPQ) tumbled 14% after reporting sluggish earnings and issuing weak guidance.Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), spun off from HP earlier this month, rose nearly 4% after reporting solid results late Tuesday.Inside the IBD 50, Euronet Worldwide (EEFT) is getting support at its 10-week moving average after a recent breakout. Shares rose 2%. Edwards Lifesciences (EW) garnered more strength after a breakout over a 154.84 buy point. Shares rose nearly 2%.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, WTI crude oil futures fell 78 cents, or 1.8%, to $42.09 a barrel.The stock market will be closed Thursday for Thanksgiving. It will be open for a half-session Friday, closing at 1 p.m. ET.Follow Ken Shreve on Twitter @IBD_KShreve and on Facebook.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect…

Research firm IDC is predicting that two of the top 10 PC makers will exit the market within the next 24 months.IDC made the prediction this week as part of its annual tech industry forecasts for the next year and beyond.

IDC also predicted that more than 30% of today's information technology vendors won't exist as we know them within five years. They'll either be acquired, merged, downsized or significantly repositioned by 2020. Those companies will be casualties of the shift to "third platform technologies," including cloud computing services, Big Data and analytics, mobile computing and social networking, IDC said.

The PC market has been impacted by the rise of mobile and cloud computing. Customers have shifted spending to smartphones and tablets, postponing PC replacements and sometimes substituting mobile devices for PCs. Also, the rise of Internet cloud-based applications and data storage has lessened the need for new personal computers.

Shifting priorities will drive IT organizations to push the average commercial PC lifespan past six years by 2017, IDC predicted. PC lifespans have been in the range of 4.5 to 5 years, IDC analyst Tom Mainelli told IBD.

As PC sales have shrunk in recent years, the top four vendors have consolidated market share. They are Lenovo, HP Inc. (HPQ), Dell and Apple (AAPL), Mainelli said. So the two companies likely to bow out of the PC market probably will be in the lower half of the top 10, he said.
The bottom six are Acer, Asus, Toshiba, Samsung, Tongfang and Fujitsu, Mainelli said.

"The most likely scenario is that two will simply leave the market," Mainelli said. "I don't expect there to be many acquisitions as the (top four) don't gain much from buying anybody in the bottom half of the list. There will likely be much discussion about possible mergers among the rest, but I'm not sure that this course of action will play out."

Dell explored the sale of its PC business ahead of its recent deal to purchase enterprise storage firm EMC (EMC), but couldn't find any takers, according to Re/code. It approached HP, Lenovo and Huawei without success, the news site said.

China-based Lenovo was the top PC vendor in the third quarter with 21% market share based on global unit shipments, IDC said. HP was second with 19.6%, followed by Dell (14.3%), Apple (7.5%) and Acer (7%). All other vendors combined for 30.6% market share.
Worldwide PC shipments fell 10.8% year over year to 71 million units in Q3, IDC said.
IDC foresees a modest recovery in PC shipments in 2017, following five years of decline.
RELATED:
Wearables, 3D printers to face major upheavals soon

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) extended its lead in the global market for server computers in the second quarter, while principal rivals IBM and Dell lost ground, market research firm IDC reported Tuesday. HP took 25.4% of the server market based on factory revenue in Q2, up from 25% a year earlier. It increased its server sales by 4% year over year to…
Investors gave thumbs up to the increased layoffs at Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), with HP stock rising Friday despite a ho-hum fiscal Q2 earnings report late Thursday.
HP's EPS minus items just met analyst expectations, while revenue came in a tad short.
HP boosted its planned layoffs from 34,000 jobs to as many as 50,000, or by as much as 47%.
Cost-cutting can go only so far, though, Cantor Fitzgerald analyst Brian White said in a research note Friday.

"HP gained more wiggle room around its margin profile through yet another restructuring initiative; however, we continue to question the company's competitive position with a portfolio that we believe is highly exposed to some of the more commoditized areas of the IT industry," White wrote. "Essentially, it remains difficult for us to understand the end game for HP."

Brent Bracelin, an analyst for Pacific Crest Securities, noted in a research report that "the 7% increase in PC revenue was the highest in three years, on 10% unit growth and 12% commercial growth. April results demonstrate that management has executed well, juggling a large product and services portfolio that is in different stages of a turnaround.
"We see the potential for further earnings and multiple expansion in the coming year as HP executes a turnaround and further right-sizes its operations."
Bracelin rates the stock outperform, with a price target of 30. White rates it a hold, with a price target of 30

Tibco Software's lack of traction in cloud computing is a prime reason the enterprise software company will likely wind up in the hands of a private equity firm rather than being bought by a larger software company such as Oracle or SAP, some analysts say.Tibco (TIBX), a leading provider of infrastructure software, early Monday announced it had agreed to be sold for $4.3 billion, or $24 a share, to Vista Equity Partners, a private equity firm focused on software, data and tech-enabled businesses.The news comes nearly a month after Tibco said it hired Goldman Sachs to look at strategic options, including pursuing potential acquirers.Vista's purchase price is a 23% premium to Tibco's Friday closing price. The companies expect the deal to close next quarter.Tibco stock rose more than 21% Monday to 23.65.Like its industry overall, Tibco is transitioning its business model from collecting a large upfront software licensing fee to a software-as-a-service model, where users access the software as needed via the Internet cloud.The cloud transition also is a top priority for licensed-software giants Oracle (ORCL) and SAP (SAP), but Tibco failed to move fast enough to the cloud, says Derrick Wood, an analyst for Susquehanna Financial Group."And that is probably why there was no interest from Oracle or SAP," Wood told IBD.Earnings DropTibco's sales growth has slowed the past two years, and earnings were down the past year, as the company struggled through a poor economy, internal sales execution issues and a maturing market for its core business as it expanded into new areas such as business analytics software.The company earlier this month reported Q3 earnings and a fiscal Q4 forecast that missed Wall Street estimates. Sales for the quarter ended Aug. 31 fell 6% from the year-earlier quarter while its EPS ex items plunged 50%.Tibco had become a leading provider of middleware that acts as a glue for developing applications. The company's big push into data analytics came with its 2007 acquisition of Spotfire for $195 million.But in analytics and elsewhere, Tibco faced increasing competition from Oracle, IBM (IBM) and smaller cloud vendors, says Steve Koenig, an analyst for Wedbush Securities."Tibco's market position with respect to the cloud was almost nowhere," Koenig said. "It was a number of problems that really crept up on them and kind of snowballed over the last couple of quarters."Tibco's challenges emerged as CEO Vivek Ranadive led an investment group that purchased the NBA's Sacramento Kings.Ranadive in May 2013 reached a deal to pay $347 million for a 65% interest in the team.The Kings' acquisition and the exit of top executives such as CFO Sydney Carey, who left last year, weighed on the company, Koenig says."There is ample evidence to say that Vivek was not minding the store, at least not as well as he should have been, with him spending quite a bit of time on his basketball endeavors," Koenig said. "And Tibco had not been very good at bringing in outside talent to shore up executive departures. Their bench was getting thinner and thinner."SAP's announcement Sept. 18 that it would acquire Concur Technologies (CNQR), a maker of cloud-based travel and expense software, for $7.4 billion underscores the desire of the legacy software leaders to build stronger cloud businesses.Oracle, SAP and others want to appeal to a growing number of business software customers that prefer to pay monthly subscriptions rather than large upfront license fees, analyst Wood says."There is less appetite from buyers for these older license models," he said.Large companies such as Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), IBM and SAP will likely focus on acquiring cloud data analytics software vendors in the near future, Bhavan Suri, an analyst for William Blair & Co., said in a research report Monday."We believe that a number of pure-play business intelligence vendors will ultimately be acquired by some of the larger vendors that need analytics front ends for their existing data warehousing/integration stacks," Suri wrote. "We believe that some of these larger vendors will look to achieve greater participation in the next-generation business intelligence space as the transition from legacy solutions continues, and that they will likely acquire as they have done in the past."For its fiscal Q3, revenue for Tibco's core infrastructure business fell 26% following a 29% drop in Q2. And its optimization business, which is primarily Spotfire, fell 7% in Q3.Tibco is feeling the effects from data analytics rivals that include Tableau Software (DATA), Koenig says."In the analytics business, Tableau has taken the market by storm and squeezed Spotfire," he said.

Synaptics (SYNA) saw its shares rise early Friday after Touchscreen chipmaker late Thursday posted fiscal Q4 earnings above analyst estimates, but its Q1 revenue outlook was light, reflecting a weaker-than-expected product ramp for the Samsung Galaxy S5.
Smartphone leader Samsung is Synaptics' biggest customer, Samsung reported a Q2 profit decline this week, its first in three years.

"The weaker-than-expected September-quarter guidance was widely anticipated given the guide down from Samsung driven by lower smartphone and tablet shipments," said Andrew Huang, an analyst at Sterne Agee, in a research report. "While some competitor reports have indicated design losses for the Galaxy Note 4, we believe Synaptics continues to gain traction at Samsung, including touch and fingerprint for the Galaxy Tab S tablets and fingerprint for the Galaxy S5 Mini smartphone."

Synaptics stock was up 13.5% in early trading in the stock market today, near 82. That's still down well below the all-time high of 93.27 touched by the stock on July 3, but shares are up sharply in 2014 for the maker of fingerprint ID technology that provides security for laptops, PCs and mobile devices.

Synaptics said it earned $1.46 a share in the June quarter, up 5% from the year-earlier quarter. Revenue rose 37% to $315 million, including acquisitions, the company said. Analysts had estimated sales of $304.1 million and earnings per share of $1.42.

"The pop in revenue growth, we believe, was due to two single design wins," said Oppenheimer analyst Andrew Uerkwitz in a report. "Despite taking share in a rapidly growing Chinese market, revenue growth still slowed. We believe this is caused primarily by ASP (average selling price) decline. Customer mix also plays a role. Going forward, margins could be under more pressure as China OEMs take up a higher portion of revenues."
Mobile revenue rose 40% to $242.9 million.

"Revenue from fingerprint ICs was 22% of total revenue in FQ4, up 122% from the prior quarter and thus driving solid top-line results for the quarter. Synaptics reiterated confidence regarding market adoption of fingerprint solutions and expects an increasing number of smartphone models with fingerprint features to be launched," John Vinh, an analyst at Pacific Crest Securities, wrote in a report.

Synaptics forecast fiscal Q1 revenue of $285 million at its midpoint. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had modeled current-quarter sales of $295.7 million. Fiscal Q1 EPS guidance of $1.06 to $1.28 — $1.17 at the midpoint — was below consensus of $1.31.

"As we look ahead to fiscal 2015, we see signs of stability in the PC market, coupled with strong but moderating growth rates for smartphones," Synaptics CEO Rick Bergman sad in a statement. "With continued strength in our core focus areas and fingerprint ID solutions now successfully incorporated into our platform, we feel confident that we can achieve another year of very strong annual revenue growth in the mid-20% range, excluding revenue from our impending acquisition of Renesas SP Drivers."
The company repurchased 5% of its shares in fiscal 2014 and increased its share buyback authorization by $110 million to $200 million.

In June, Synaptics agreed to buy Japan-based Renesas SP Drivers for $475 million. It makes display driver chips for mobile devices. Renesas SP Drivers' customers include Apple (AAPL). Synaptics hopes the Renesas deal will lead to an integrated touch-and-display driver product for smartphones and tablets.

Synaptics is part of IBD's Computer Hardware-Peripherals group, which ranks No. 13 out of 197 industry groups. The group also includes Apple and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ).Synaptics (SYNA) saw its shares rise early Friday after Touchscreen chipmaker late Thursday posted fiscal Q4 earnings above analyst estimates, but its Q1 revenue outlook was light, reflecting a weaker-than-expected product ramp for the Samsung Galaxy S5.Smartphone leader Samsung is Synaptics' biggest customer, Samsung reported a Q2 profit decline this week, its first in three years."The weaker-than-expected September-quarter guidance was widely anticipated given the guide down from Samsung driven by lower smartphone and tablet shipments," said Andrew Huang, an analyst at Sterne Agee, in a research report. ServiceNow reported a mixed bag for Q2 after the close Wednesday, sending its stock down 6% in after-hours trading. The provider of software that companies use to manage IT service desk operations beat revenue expectations, but its bottom line was merely in line as profit remains elusive, and deferred revenue came up short of Wall Street views. Its Q3 revenue…

ServiceNow's (NOW) trajectory as one of the fastest-growing companies among the young gun high-growth software names will likely continue when the company reports its second-quarter earnings after the market close Wednesday.The maker of software-as-a-service used to manage service desk functions is growing at the expense of larger rivals BMC Software, CA Technologies (CA) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ).ServiceNow stock was up more than 1% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 59. But ServiceNow stock is down 18% since touching an all-time high of 71.80 on Feb. 27. ServiceNow made its IPO in June 2012, pricing its initial shares at 18.The company is expanding into new areas, including software to help manage human resources and sales and marketing departments.Growth won't be an issue with the Q2 results, Michael Turits, an analyst for Raymond James, said in a report Tuesday."U.S. checks with systems integrators, (value added resellers and large account resellers) this quarter indicated continued strong business momentum with ServiceNow's product suite," he wrote. "Increasingly, we heard resellers and integrators say customers are standardizing on ServiceNow instead of deploying in mixed environments with legacy vendors, and are viewing ServiceNow as a more strategic vendor."For Q2, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect a loss per-share minus items of 7 cents vs. a 6-cent loss in the year-earlier period.Revenue is expected to climb 58% to $161.5 million.For the current quarter, analysts expect a per-share loss of 3 cents, up from a penny a share loss, with revenue rising 52% to $169.5 million.Turits rates ServiceNow stock a strong buy, for a number of reasons."ServiceNow is our analyst current favorite and we continue to be positive on the stock given the company's role as a pioneer and leader in SaaS-based ITSM, ability to displace legacy on-premise ITSM vendors including BMC and HP, expansion of both ITSM and new packaged operations management applications within customers and ability to drive usage of its business workflow development platform," he wrote.RELATED:CA Seen Gaining By Selling Storage-Software Business.

The new enterprise service and cloud computing issue fell 1.6% in its debut…
Lacking firmer footing in the cloud "until it can prove otherwise," Oracle (ORCL) stock was downgraded Thursday by FBR & Co. to market perform from outperform, though FBR kept its price target at 44.
Oracle stock, up 14% since late September, was down a fraction, near 40, in afternoon trading on the stock market today.

"Although we have patiently awaited a turnaround story at Oracle, and the company has talked a great talk, the lack of consistent results, an empty M&A strategy ... and major secular challenges from the likes of Amazon (AMZN) Web Services are hard to ignore and thus make it tough to be bullish," wrote FBR analyst Daniel Ives in a research note.

Oracle is sailing against the "same headwinds," Ives said, as other "mature, tech stalwarts" such as IBM (IBM); newly divided Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and HP Inc. (HPQ); EMC (EMC) and Dell, which are merging; and Cisco Systems (CSCO).
He says that more budget dollars are flowing toward the next-generation data centers and away from traditional IT purchase cycles.

For Oracle's fiscal Q2, ending Nov. 30, FBR lowered its revenue estimates to $9.1 billion from $9.5 billion, and its earnings per share estimate to 60 cents from 61 cents. The consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters also is 60 cents, which would be down 13% from the year-earlier quarter.

For fiscal 2016, FBR knocked down Oracle sales estimates from $38.4 billion to $37.6 billion and pro forma EPS from $2.67 to $2.61. In its fiscal 2015, which ended May 31, Oracle reported EPS of $2.21 on sales of $38.2 billion.
"Cloud is the focus; growth remains the problem," said Ives.

Ives says that the company's cloud products — software-as-a-service, platform-as-a-service and infrastructure-as-a-service — are expanding and improving. But, he said, "Oracle faces major company-specific and secular headwinds on its legacy database and applications business, which continue to see slower deal flow in light of an evolving IT landscape.

"To this point, we believe Oracle needs to be aggressive on M&A (big data, cloud, cybersecurity) and get back to its core DNA that helped create the Oracle powerhouse of yesterday, otherwise darker days could be ahead."

After two strong up days following the Hewlett-Packard split-up, PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) fell Wednesday after getting a cautious report from UBS.

HP was down 2% in afternoon trading on the stock market today, near 14. Its sister company, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), was down 4%, also near 14. Hewlett-Packard split into HP and HPE on Sunday.
UBS analyst Steven Milunovich on Wednesday initiated coverage of HP with a neutral rating and HPE with a buy rating.
He set a 12-month price target of 15 on HP.

"Although we find the valuation and dividend yield somewhat attractive, we think the business fundamentals are likely to get worse before they get better," he said about HP. "We expect the printing margin to come under pressure and PC sales to decline albeit at a more modest rate."
In the longer term, he is optimistic about HP's prospects in encroaching on the copier market and becoming a leader in 3D printing.
HP gets about 80% of its profit from printing, mostly by selling ink, and the remaining 20% from personal computers.
On a revenue basis, printers and supplies account for 40% of sales, with PCs and workstations accounting for 60% of sales.
"Although HP Inc. is comprised of two secularly challenged businesses — printing and PCs — we do expect to see a benefit from increased focus over time," Milunovich said.
As for HPE, Milunovich sees the business improving in the near term, but has longer-term concerns. He set a price target of 18.50 on the stock.

"HPE has in its favor a combination of low valuation and positive momentum," he said. "We expect results to improve in storage, Enterprise Services, and software with stabilization in Technology Services and more modest growth in servers."
But HPE might be too hardware-centric and not sufficiently differentiated for long-term success, Milunovich said.
Barclays Favors HP Over HPE
Meanwhile, Barclays analyst Mark Moskowitz favors HP over HPE. On Wednesday, he rated HP stock as equal weight with a price target of 14 and HPE as underweight with a target of 13.
Of the two stand-alone companies, HP is the more attractive, thanks to its better cash flow and yield prospects, he said.
HPE faces competition from cloud computing companies such as Amazon.com's (AMZN) Amazon Web Services.
On Tuesday, Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi initiated coverage of HP with an outperform rating and price target of 17. He gave HPE a rating of market perform and a price target of 16.

HP is the dominant player in printing, with about a 40% share of A4 laser printer units and a 45% share of A4 inkjet printer units. It is a close No. 2 behind Lenovo in the PC market, with about an 18% share.

"We believe that both are scale- and brand-driven businesses, and that consolidation is afoot in PCs, and appears inevitable in printing (both Lexmark (LXK) and Xerox (XRX) have recently announced that they are exploring strategic options)," Sacconaghi said. "In the near term, HP should benefit from distractions at its printing peers and No. 3 PC vendor Dell, which is in the process of attempting to swallow larger EMC (EMC)."

HPE faces a different set of challenges. He described it as "an on-premise vendor in an increasingly off-premise world." IT customers are shifting from servers and storage located on site to cloud computing resources accessed over the Internet.

"The IT spending landscape is undergoing massive changes, chief among them is the migration from on-premise infrastructure to off-premise solutions," Sacconaghi said. "Increasingly, CIOs are telling us that their priority for workloads is (software-as-a-service), (infrastructure-as-a-service), then — at last resort — on premise. This transition is affecting all traditional IT vendors, whose growth rates have stagnated."
Besides HPE, other vendors hurt by the shift include IBM (IBM), NetApp (NTAP), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Oracle (ORCL) and EMC excluding its VMware (VMW) unit, he said.

In the breakup of Hewlett-Packard, investors on Monday showed more love for the stodgy, slow-growth PC and printer business, rather than for the supposedly more attractive enterprise technology business.Shares of HP Inc. (HPQ), the personal computer and printer maker, were up more than 13% to near 14 in the stock market today. Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock opened at 14.99 and was a fraction lower in afternoon trading.HP garnered several upbeat analyst reports post-split.Credit Suisse analyst Kulbinder Garcha initiated coverage of HP with an outperform rating and price target of 19. He called HP a "worthy annuity.""HP Inc. has a solid franchise and a multifaceted strategy to offset secular pressures in the printing and PC end markets," Garcha said in a report Monday. HP has "an extremely inexpensive valuation and significant cash return" potential.HP also is on track to improve the profitability of its printer unit by maximizing ink sales and expanding its commercial printer business, he said.S&P Capital IQ analyst Angelo Zino reiterated a strong buy rating on HP stock.Needham analyst Richard Kugele initiated coverage of HP with a buy rating and 14.50 price target.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani was more cautious on HP and its spinoff. He reiterated a sector perform rating on HP post-split and set a price target of 13.HP has "an attractive valuation and 4%+ dividend yield offset by secular challenges in printing and PC markets," Daryanani said in a report Monday.Meanwhile, he initiated coverage of Hewlett Packard Enterprise at sector perform, with a price target of 17.Credit Suisse's Garcha initiated coverage of HPE with a neutral rating and price target of 19."Secular challenges in the IT market (low growth rate and impact of the public cloud) create a headwind for the business," Garcha said in a report.HPE faces traditional competitors such as IBM (IBM) and Cisco Systems (CSCO), plus public cloud computing firms such as Amazon.com's (AMZN) Amazon Web Services.Mergers and acquisitions will be key for HPE, which has $11.5 billion of gross cash and $5.5 billion of net cash, Garcha said: "HPE has a strong balance sheet allowing for transformative M&A."Potential acquisitions include faster growth companies and current end-market positioning improvements, such as Arista Networks (ANET) and Nimble Storage (NMBL), and more legacy yet highly accretive acquisitions, such as NetApp (NTAP), Citrix Systems (CTXS) and CommVault Systems (CVLT).RELATED:HP Starts Life As A House Divided: Now The Hard PartHewlett-Packard spreading FUD over Dell-EMC merger.
Troubled 3D Systems (DDD) announced the resignation of president and CEO Avi Reichental, one week before the maker of 3D printers is set to report third-quarter earnings.

The announcement came Thursday morning and was effective Wednesday at the close of business. Reichental held the position for 12 years. Taking his place on an interim basis is Andrew Johnson, the company's chief legal officer.

"The company's board of directors will immediately commence a comprehensive search and evaluation process to select a permanent replacement for the role of president and chief executive officer," the company said in a statement.

The resignation comes during a difficult time for 3D Systems and its chief competitor, Stratasys (SSYS). Last week, Stratasys reported preliminary third-quarter earnings estimates well below Wall Street expectations.

"We are profoundly grateful for the visionary leadership Avi has provided to our business and to our industry, and we wish him well in his future endeavors," said Charles Hull, company co-founder and chief technology officer, in the press release. "As our industry continues to evolve and we look to the future, we are focused on aligning our resources and programs to best serve our customers and are excited about the many opportunities ahead."

3D Systems, founded in 1986, pioneered the industry. It initially developed expensive 3D printers used in aerospace and automotive manufacturing to develop prototype parts, in what then was a niche market. Advances in technologies and materials led to 3D printers able to create physical objects from a wide array of plastics, metals, ceramics and other materials.

Stratasys and 3D Systems shares soared from early 2012 to early 2014 as media reports touted the technology as one of the next big things. The stocks began to tumble in early 2014 when 3D Systems and Stratasys began to lower their estimates. Nor did it help that short-seller Citron Research slammed 3D printer stocks in several reports.
3D Systems stock peaked at 97.28 on Jan. 3, 2014. The stock was down 5%, near 10.30, in early afternoon trading on the stock market today.
Stratasys stock also tumbled in early 2014 but regained momentum, hitting a peak of 130.83 on Sept. 19. 2014, then commenced to fall. Stratasys stock was near 26.75 Thursday afternoon, up a fraction.

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) plans to enter the 3D printer market in late 2016. A research note last month by UBS, on HP's entry into the market, said the industry had many mountains yet to climb. Hewlett-Packard as of Sunday is set to split into separate companies, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, focusing on enterprise products and services, and HP Inc., focusing on the PC and printer businesses.

"We think 3D printing is a significant long-term opportunity, but the technology is immature in terms of speed, quality and reliability, which has caused problems for Stratasys and 3D Systems," the report said.

Stratasys, when it lowered its Q3 outlook, said that during 2013 and 2014, the overall 3D printing industry experienced extraordinary growth that it said might have created excess capacity in the market. It said this is contributing to the current slowdown, as that excess is worked off.
