Stocks ended with solid gains Friday after battling back from weakness spurred by a disappointing jobs report. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 ended up 1.7% and 1.4%, respectively. Both were down 1.6% at Friday's low. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1.2%. According to preliminary data, volume ended higher across the board in the stock market today.Among leading stocks, Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) reversed higher to a 6% gain. The stock had already risen 3% Thursday, following the pricing of a share offering. Dave & Buster's was recently featured in Stock Spotlight.Verisk Analytics (VRSK) stretched its win streak to four straight sessions. It rebounded from a 2% loss and rose 2%. The stock nearly reached a 79.98 buy point in a flat base. Verisk, which provides data to insurance underwriters and banks, will be added to the S&P 500 after Wednesday's close.Tyler Technologies (TYL) added 2% for its second straight new high. It's now 15% past a 145.84 buy point from a flat base cleared Sept. 14. On Thursday, the company announced that it would buy privately held New World Systems for $670 million in cash and stock.Domino's Pizza (DPZ) climbed 0.5% after bucking morning weakness. It failed to retake its 200-day moving average. Domino's will report Q3 earnings Thursday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see the pizza chain's profit rising 17% to 74 cents a share..

The stock market closed mixed Friday after indexes bounced back from an early slump. The Nasdaq rose 0.2% thanks to strength in biotechs, security software and solar stocks.The S&P; 500 fell 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average lagged with a 0.3% drop and closed near session lows.Small caps paced the market: The small-cap Russell 2000 climbed 0.6%. Volume rose on the NYSE and edged lower on the Nasdaq, according to early figures.After a serious decline the prior day, Friday's price reversals were encouraging. Yet the market remained locked in a long sideways trend.Stocks sank at the open as a better-than-expected jobs report for May triggered a slide in bond prices.Energy stocks rose after OPEC left its output targets unchanged, as expected. Solar shares jumped after China-based JA Solar 's (JASO) chief executive offered to buy the company and take it private.Financials also helped lead the stock market today. Bank of America (BAC) rose more than 2% and closed back near a 24.88 buy point. JPMorgan (JPM) rose 2% and hit a new high. Thinly traded BofI Holdings (BOFI) rose 2% and topped the 97.78 buy point of a long cup-with-handle base.It was a strong day for the IBD 50, with the average component up about 1.3%. Volume was just average or light for most of the 50 stocks, though.

Stocks struggled for direction, ending narrowly mixed Wednesday amid better-than-expected new-home sales and a second day of testimony from Fed chief Janet Yellen. But some stocks made waves after hours.

Salesforce.com (CRM) bolted 11% in extended trading after posting Q4 2015 results that met views. Earnings came in at 14 cents a share, double from a year ago. Sales rose 26% to more than $1.44 billion.
Avago Technologies (AVGO) rallied 4% after it delivered fiscal Q1 results above views. The chip designer also announced it was buying Emulex (ELX), which was soaring after hours.
MercadoLibre (MELI) was also up about 4% in extended trading, despite posting mixed quarterly results.

In the regular session, the Nasdaq eased a fraction, ending a 10-day run. The S&P; 500 slipped 0.1%. But the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.1%. According to preliminary data, volume end higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today.

Aruba Networks (ARUN) soared 21% on reports that it's in talks to be bought by Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), which reported quarterly results late Tuesday. The late surge sent Aruba above a 22.34 buy point from a consolidation intraday.

Leaderboard name GrubHub (GRUB) rallied nearly 4% in strong volume. It cleared a cup-with-handle buy point of 41.85. Earlier this month, the provider of online food ordering services beat views with a Q4 earnings that surged 550% and sales that jumped 50%.
3D Systems (DDD), Air Lease (AL), Iconix Brand Group (ICON), Kohl's (KSS), Ross Stores (ROST) and Splunk (SPLK) are some leading stocks reporting earnings Thursday.

Weekly jobless claims, consumer prices and durable goods will be out Thursday morning. The late surge sent Aruba above a 22.34 buy point from a consolidation intraday.Leaderboard name GrubHub (GRUB) rallied nearly 4% in strong volume. It cleared a cup-with-handle buy point of 41.85. Earlier this month, the provider of online food ordering services beat views with a Q4 earnings that surged 550% and sales that jumped 50%.3D Systems (DDD), Air Lease (AL), Iconix Brand Group (ICON), Kohl's (KSS), Ross Stores (ROST) and Splunk (SPLK) are some leading stocks reporting earnings Thursday.Weekly jobless claims, consumer prices and durable goods will be out Thursday morning. Atlanta Fed President Dennis Lockhart will also be speaking Thursday.

Reselling tech products may not be a glamorous business, but that didn't stop CDW from turning heads on Wall Street when it posted strong quarterly financial results this month. CDW (CDW) stock rose to a record high on Feb. 10 after the company's fourth-quarter earnings and sales topped analysts' estimates and management gave upbeat prospects for 2015. The stock then…

Shares of Redbox parent Outerwall (OUTR) tumbled Tuesday after the company announced that Scott Di Valerio has stepped down as CEO and resigned from the board, a major red flag coming just two weeks before Outerwall is due to report Q4 earnings.Outerwall was down 17% in midday trading in the stock market today, at a two-month low near 64.50.Outerwall narrowed its fourth-quarter guidance at or above its previous guidance range to assuage investors. It now expects Q4 sales of $598 million to $602 million and earnings per share from continuing operations of $2.40 to $2.52. Based on the midpoint of its guidance, EPS would be up 46% to $2.46 and sales would be up 1% to $600 million.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were modeling Outerwall to earn $2.06 a share on sales of $596 million. Outerwall is scheduled to report Q4 earnings after the market close on Feb. 5.Outerwall is expected to provide 2015 guidance on its Q4 earnings conference call. The Bellevue, Wash.-based company sees low single-digit revenue growth and core adjusted earnings from continuing operations to be in line with expected 2014 results.Nora Denzel, a member of Outerwall's board since February 2013, was appointed interim CEO. Denzel held various management positions at Intuit (INTU) from February 2008 through August 2012. Before that, she was senior vice president of the global software business unit and the storage and consulting divisions at Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) from August 2000 to February 2006. She also previously worked at Legato Systems and IBM (IBM).The resignation of Di Valerio blind-sided Wall Street. Outerwall stock on Friday reached an all-time high of 77.94."The timing of this transition signals the board's dissatisfaction with the company's strategic direction and desire to bring in new blood," Dougherty & Co. analyst Steven Frankel said in a note Tuesday. "The resignation of Mr. Di Valero clears the decks for the company to appoint an outsider as CEO, as opposed to in 2013 when the board chose Mr. Di Valero, who was then the company's CFO."The company's raised guidance for Q4 EPS was a positive, but its 2015 guidance disappointed, Frankel said.The Q4 EPS upside is likely the result of a combination of share buybacks and lower-than-expected taxes, Frankel said.For 2015, Wall Street was looking for year-over-year growth of 5% in sales and 7% in adjusted earnings. That compares with management's target of low single-digit sales growth and flat earnings."While in the short run strong cash generation from Redbox can drive continued share repurchases, we remain concerned that the inherent volatility of the box office combined with the rise of digital distribution and the shift toward episodic television pose serious challenges," Frankel said. The failure of its joint venture with Verizon (VZ) leaves Redbox without a digital strategy."Without a clear vision on how the company drives per kiosk rental growth at Redbox and meets the challenges of the digital world, we remain Neutral rated," Frankel said.Outerwall is likely being conservative with its 2015 forecast because of the CEO transition and other "moving parts," such as the recent Redbox price increase, Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a note Tuesday.In addition to its Redbox movie rental business, Outerwall runs Coinstar coin-counting kiosks, ecoATM mobile phone trade-in kiosks and is testing other in-store kiosks.RELATED:Redbox tells DVD movie renters to dig deeperRedbox Q3 profit growth surprises, adds loyalty program.

Shares of both EMC (EMC) and VMware (VMW) dropped Tuesday as investors and Wall Street struggled to understand the complexities of the deal in which privately held tech giant Dell would swallow up the two enterprise computing companies.After a fall of 8.1% Monday, when Dell announced its pending acquisition of VMware majority owner EMC, VMware stock was down another 4% in afternoon trading on the stock market today, putting it at a more than two-year low near 69. EMC stock was down 2%, near 27, after climbing for nine straight sessions. Dell and EMC early Monday announced their merger, valued at $67 billion, the biggest pure-tech merger ever.But at least three investment banks downgraded EMC stock Tuesday as Wall Street parsed the transaction.The Byzantine deal involves issuing of a VMware tracking stock that lets Dell retain EMC's control of VMware — which some consider the most attractive part of EMC — with minimal capital outlays, analysts say. The terms also enable Dell to pay down $20 billion in debt that it needed when it went private in 2013. Analysts expect that the deal will lead to more industry consolidation."Apparently they want control over VMware without paying for it," analyst Rajesh Ghai of Macquarie Securities told IBD. "They want their cake and to eat it, too."A complete VMware spinoff would have been better for VMware shareholders, Ghai says."The stock's kind of taking a big hit because of the (deal's) stupid structure," Ghai said.A spinoff was what activist investor Elliott Management had been advocating for VMware, though Elliott came out in support of the Dell-EMC deal on Monday. Elliott executives could not be reached for comment on VMware's continued fall Tuesday. Neither Dell nor EMC responded to requests for comment.Dell Keeps Voting RightsThe terms of the deal allow Dell to pay $24.05 in cash and 0.111 share of a tracking stock linked to EMC's 81% control over VMware. The other 19% are traded on the NYSE. VMware had been trading above 80, and so the deal was estimated to be worth 33.15 a share of EMC. With VMware stock dropping, the value has fallen below 32.Ultimately, Dell will outright own 28% of VMware shares, 53% of shares will go to the tracking stock, and the other 19% will remain on the open market. Shareholders can freely trade the tracking stock, but the voting rights will remain in the hands of Dell.Some analysts, however, say that the deal at least solidifies VMware's future."Overall, we view this as net positive for (VMware), as the deal removes future uncertainty, which has been the biggest overhang on the stock," UBS analyst Brent Thill said in a research note. "Management noted that (Dell CEO) Michael Dell is aligned to driving shareholder value and committed to increasing economic interest over time, via buyback of either (VMware) tracking or common stock."But Thill lowered his price target on VMware stock to 90 from 97. "Our biggest concerns are around VMware management having to deal with a new owner as well as how the other strategic partners react to Dell building out a more complete stack," he wrote.Argus Research analyst Jim Kelleher downgraded EMC stock to hold from buy."During a post-announcement conference call, executives of EMC, Dell and VMware stated that the potential for revenue synergies rather than cost synergies (was) driving the deal," Kelleher wrote. "EMC (Chief Executive) Joe Tucci also acknowledged that amid unprecedented technology industry disruption, EMC's older products were tailing off more rapidly than earlier anticipated."That may have given further impetus to this transformative deal, which comes amid shake-ups in other leading (information technology) companies such as the coming split-up of (Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) into two companies."Follow Russ Britt on Twitter @IBD_RBritt and on Facebook.
Now that Hewlett-Packard has split in two, the question for the iconic technology giant and pioneer is whether its divide-and-conquer strategy will spark a rebound and accelerate growth.

HP's efforts to revisit the heights that it reached during the dot-com boom 15 years ago have largely failed. Its shares and market cap have lagged those of many contemporaries. So, 14 years after it mushroomed in size through the huge acquisition of Compaq, the Silicon Valley stalwart is downsizing.

HP aims to unleash the growth-starved enterprise side of the company that serves businesses, and says that its consumer technology engine, run by PCs and its industry-leading printers, can keep chugging along despite few organic growth prospects.

It's a risky gambit that could backfire, some observers say. Others say that it's the only way for HP to keep from becoming a dinosaur. While such tech titans as Apple (AAPL) find success and blue skies in new businesses, others such as IBM (IBM), Oracle (ORCL) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) see clouds, as in cloud computing, as they gaze into their crystal balls.

"HP is trying to figure out how to get off the innovation treadmill that's going 2 miles per hour," said Daniel Ives, a tech analyst at FBR & Co. "It makes sense that they're willing to do something to shake up the status quo."
Dell Does Opposite

Investors gave a mixed greeting to the split stocks in their first day of trading Monday. Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), which gets a new ticker, fell 1.6% to 14.49. But HP Inc. (HPQ), which retains the ticker Hewlett-Packard has used since it acquired Compaq, rose 13% to 13.83.

Ives says the split-up isn't meant to reverse HP's oft-criticized 2001 purchase of then-giant PC firm Compaq Computer for $25 billion. Opinions on that deal vary, but observers note that other tech Goliaths are trying the same method to keep from being slain by Davids. Most notably of late, privately held Dell announced an agreement in October to acquire EMC (EMC), at $67 billion the largest-ever merger of pure tech companies. That move could be considered the opposite of what HP is doing.
Many tech titans are scrambling to find ways to stay on their toes, but some observers question the strategy of HP and Chief Executive Meg Whitman. HP executives were unavailable for comment.
Rob Enderle, a longtime Silicon Valley analyst, is among the dubious. He points to Dell and China giant Lenovo as among companies that view offering a broad spectrum of technology as key.
"HP seems to be an example of a company determined to do something wrong," Enderle said.
Market Cap Vs. Sales

Right or wrong, Hewlett Packard Enterprise is the "new" company that will aim to deepen technology's ties to corporations. It looks to make money providing services via the cloud or Internet. HP Inc. will focus on the consumer PC and printing businesses.

One signpost by which to gauge the split's success is how it transforms HP's market capitalization. For now, HP is the only tech company of its size with a market cap smaller than its annual sales. Prior to the split, the combined HP was valued below $48 billion, while revenue for its fiscal year, which ended Saturday, is estimated near $106 billion. Prior to the split, there were roughly 1.8 billion shares of HP; its stock closed Friday at 26.96.

By comparison, Apple's world-leading market cap of $683 billion compares with annual sales of $234 billion. IBM has less than 1 billion shares outstanding, roughly half of HP's; but its market cap is nearly triple HP's, at $136.4 billion, with its stock closing Friday just above 140. IBM posted 2014 sales of $93 billion.

Oracle has roughly double the shares that HP has but more than triple the market cap: $166 billion, with annual sales near $38 billion. Cisco is roughly equal to Oracle, with $146 billion in market cap and $49 billion in sales this fiscal year.
Ranking Low
Excluding financial services firms, which don't record revenue, HP ranks No. 33 among multinational companies in the Financial Times Global 500 in terms of sales, but it ranks No. 125 in market cap.
And HP ranks No. 111 in revenue per employee and No. 162 in market value per employee.
"How the hell do you even get there?" asked analyst Enderle of HP's standing. "For the most part, it's being clueless."
But some — including Crawford Del Prete, an analyst at tech research firm IDC who has followed HP since the late 1990s — view the split as a solid move.
"It's hard for me to be skeptical (about whether) it's going to work," Del Prete said. "I don't see how they're going to have trouble executing the split."
FBR's Ives says that the key for HP is how well the enterprise unit adapts to cloud computing, a huge trend in the tech industry.

"HP was late to the cloud," Ives said. "A lot of these (older, legacy tech) companies miscalculated how quickly this shift would happen. I think these companies have hubris and are seeing through rose-colored glasses not only on the board but (in) the CEO seat as well."Now that Hewlett-Packard has split in two, the question for the iconic technology giant and pioneer is whether its divide-and-conquer strategy will spark a rebound and accelerate growth.HP's efforts to revisit the heights that it reached during the dot-com boom 15 years ago have largely failed. Its shares and market cap have lagged those of many contemporaries. So, 14 years after it mushroomed in size through the huge acquisition of Compaq, the Silicon Valley stalwart is downsizing.HP aims to unleash the growth-starved enterprise side of the company that serves businesses, and says that its consumer technology engine, run by PCs and its industry-leading printers, can keep chugging along despite few organic growth prospects.It's a risky gambit that could backfire, some observers say. Others say that it's the only way for HP to keep from becoming a dinosaur. While such tech titans as Apple (AAPL) find success and blue skies in new businesses, others such as IBM (IBM), Oracle (ORCL) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) see clouds, as in cloud computing, as they gaze into their crystal balls."HP is trying to figure out how to get off the innovation treadmill that's going 2 miles per hour," said Daniel Ives, a tech analyst at FBR & Co. "It makes sense that they're willing to do something to shake up the status quo."Dell Does OppositeInvestors gave a mixed greeting to the split stocks in their first day of trading Monday. Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) stock gapped up more than 5% Wednesday after the tech giant announced plans to slash up to 30,000 jobs as part of a restructuring that will split it into two companies. Late Tuesday, company executives told analysts they would make the cuts as HP separates its enterprise divisions from its consumer products operations, with the split set to…

Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) enterprise unit will cut 25,000 to 30,000 jobs from its work force as part of the restructuring as it separates from HP's consumer operations, company officials said Tuesday.HP made the announcement at a meeting with analysts and later disclosed the plan publicly in a press release. The tech giant now has 302,000 employees worldwide across all its operations, and would end up with as few as 272,000 as a result of the enterprise unit cutbacks. Company officials told analysts they may do some rehiring once the restructuring is complete.Further guidance on HP's consumer unit, known as HP Inc., was expected later in the day but sources didn't expect the company to announce further layoffs from that division, which formally separates from the enterprise operations Nov. 1.The enterprise unit's restructuring is expected to take out $2.7 billion in annual costs, company officials said in a press release. The costs associated with the restructuring will amount to a $2.7 billion GAAP charge, beginning in the fourth quarter, and the move will impact cash by $2.6 billion over the next three years, starting in fiscal 2016."These restructuring activities will enable a more competitive, sustainable cost structure for the new Hewlett Packard Enterprise," HP Chief Executive Meg Whitman said in a prepared statement. "We've done a significant amount of work over the past few years to take costs out and simplify processes and these final actions will eliminate the need for any future corporate restructuring."RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani said in a research note late Tuesday that the "expectation is that some of the savings will be invested back in the business and savings will be fully realized by fiscal-year 2017 to 2018 time frame."The reductions come three years after HP slashed 55,000 jobs in 2012.HP also said it expects 2016 earnings, excluding items, of $1.85 to $1.95 a share for the enterprise unit. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters have been expecting $3.72 in adjusted income per share for both the consumer and enterprise divisions in 2016, 2.8% up from 2015's expected $3.62. Revenue for the combined entity, however, is expected to drop 1.6% to $102.4 billion.HP stock ended Tuesday's regular trading session in the stock market today up marginally to 27.11, but was trading down more than 2% after hours.
Chinese Tsinghua Group's $3.8 billion investment in data storage firm Western Digital (WDC) might signal the death knell for a rumored deal with Micron (MU), Rosenblatt Securities said Friday.
Buzz circling SanDisk (SNDK) and Toshiba might also be overblown, Rosenblatt analyst Jun Zhang wrote in a research report.

"We believe SanDisk and Toshiba are unlikely targets," he wrote. "Micron is still attractive to Chinese PEs, but we think the decision to invest in Western Digital already tells us that talks or a potential deal with Micron might already be falling apart."
Micron stock was down more than 1.5% in midday trading in the stock market today while SanDisk stock was down more than 2%.
Tsinghua, a state-owned Chinese chip designer, has been lapping up U.S. acquisitions for several years.

In 2013 and 2014, the group acquired Spreadtrum Communications and RDA Microelectronics. In May, Tsinghua acquired a controlling stake in Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) China-based networking equipment group.

Tsinghua reportedly made an unsolicited $23 billion bid for Micron, unnamed sources told the Wall Street Journal in July. Acquiring Micron would move the needle on the government's goal of establishing a DRAM memory chip fabrication plant in China. Dynamic random access memory is the main type of memory chip in PCs.

Tsinghua also could be eyeing Taiwanese memory chip companies, Zhang wrote. Micron, SanDisk and Toshiba will experience demand and inventory headwinds in the next two quarters, making them risky purchases, Zhang says.
China Eyes Memory Market

Mizuho Securities analyst Vijay Rakesh called the reported hiring of Charles Kau by Tsinghua "a double-edged sword" for Micron. Kau recently resigned his presidency at Taiwan-based Nanya Technology. Kau also is chairman at Inotera, in which Micron holds a 35% stake.

"The potential of China acquiring Micron appears de minimis to us and we believe Micron is not looking for investments from China," Rakesh wrote. "But longer term, a substantial Chinese entry into memory might be a headwind for DRAM and Nand (flash memory chips)."
Samsung's rumored capital expenditures' cut for 2016 — excepting its South Korea DRAM fabrication plant — could help Micron's rebound, Rakesh said.

Rakesh sees Samsung, Hynix and Micron lifted in 2016 by 30% year-over-year growth in memory production, even as DRAM demand slows in PCs and smartphones. All three companies plan DRAM ramps in the first half of 2016, he wrote.
"So while 2015 saw DRAM hurt by a demand slowdown, 2016 could be affected by higher supply," he wrote. "On the other hand, we believe broader smartphone and PC growth remain headwinds."
On Monday, RBC Capital analyst Mahesh Sanganeria suggested Micron would come out on top in the 2016 DRAM market after Samsung, Hynix and Inotera flooded the supply chain in 2014.
Samsung's reported capex cuts could help Micron by leading "to better supply-demand next year," Deutsche Bank analyst Sidney Ho wrote in a report Monday.
Rakesh boosted his price target on Micron stock to 18 from 16 and reiterated his neutral rating.

Enterprise data-storage company EMC saw its shares jump Thursday on reports that it could be acquired by privately held Dell, a deal analysts say could lead to more consolidation among the largest tech hardware and services companies.

Dell is said to be in advanced talks with EMC (EMC) about a possible merger, as was first reported late Wednesday by the Wall Street Journal. With a market capitalization of $52 billion, EMC would be one of the tech's biggest takeover targets ever.

Dell's offer for EMC could be more than $27 a share, CNBC reported Thursday. The deal announcement could be only a week away. Dell likely would need $40 billion in financing for the acquisition, CNBC said.

"A combined EMC/Dell would create a larger vendor that would own the entire stack and give it scale to compete against other large OEMs and cloud vendors, though the company would have to integrate and execute a strategy," Wells Fargo Securities analyst Maynard Um said in a research report Thursday.
EMC stock rose 4.7% Thursday, to 27.18, its seventh up day in a row after hitting a two-year closing low of 23.13 on Sept. 29.
EMC has been under pressure by activist investor Elliott Management to divest assets, including its 80% ownership in virtualization-software leader VMware (VMW) .

Dell was taken private in October 2013 by Dell founder and CEO Michael Dell and private-equity firm Silver Lake Partners, in a deal worth $25 billion. Since going private, Dell has shifted its emphasis from personal computers to enterprise hardware, software and services.

Other media reports suggest that Dell is interested in buying only part of EMC. Re/code reported Wednesday that EMC approached Dell within the last six weeks to sell its VNX storage product line, not the whole company.
VNX has annual sales of about $3 billion, Re/code said.
A purchase of part of EMC would be easier to digest for Dell, which has about $12 billion in debt on its books.
Wall Street Skeptical Of Deal
A breakup of EMC would unlock more value for EMC shareholders than a sale to Dell, BMO Capital Markets analyst Keith Bachman said in a report Thursday.
"EMC's individual business units are worth more than the current aggregate valuation," Bachman said. "We believe the sum of the parts valuation is between $30 and $32 (a share)."
Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi doubts that Dell could buy EMC.

"We don't think that Dell has the financial capacity to buy EMC, even if EMC were to spin-out VMware," Sacconaghi said. "Dell currently has about $12 billion in debt and an enterprise value likely around $20 billion to $25 billion, vs. EMC's enterprise value of around $45 billion.

"Even spinning out VMware, Dell would likely have to pay $25 billion or more for EMC to ensure a premium for EMC shareholders, which we believe would be financially very difficult to do. Moreover, it is unclear how compelling EMC without VMware would be to Dell, particularly since Dell has its own storage line-up."
'Head-Scratcher'

The possible sale of EMC's VNX storage business to Dell appears more plausible, given its size ($2 billion to $6 billion in annual sales), he said. "But it is still not obvious why Dell would be eager to acquire the assets," he said.
FBR Capital Markets analyst Daniel Ives calls any Dell-EMC deal a "major head-scratcher."
"It would be a very financially complex merger, high integration issues, and fundamentally would combine two very mature companies into one," he told Bloomberg.
But EMC CEO Joe Tucci is under pressure to boost returns for EMC investors, Ives said in a note late Wednesday.

"Joe Tucci and the EMC board have their backs against the wall as activist investor Elliott Management appears to have put enough heat in the kitchen to force this mature stalwart to figure out a strategic plan after years of struggles," Ives said. "Of all the options potentially on the table, we would view a merger with the now-private Dell as a 'nightmare scenario' that would lack strategic synergies and further complicate EMC's troubled growth path."

The information-technology industry "is ripe for consolidation," Macquarie Capital analyst Rajesh Ghai said in a report Thursday. "EMC, with its market leadership in the storage and virtualization markets, has significant strategic value and is likely to be the first candidate for consolidation."
A merger of EMC and Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) HP Enterprise would have more cost synergies than a merger with Dell, Ghai said. But Dell may be more willing to divest EMC's stake in VMware, he said.
HP stock rose 4.2% Thursday.
A Dell-EMC deal could kick off a wave of M&A activity in the IT infrastructure industry, William Blair analyst Jason Ader said in a report.

"Such a deal would be a response to massive secular changes occurring in the market," Ader said. "A deal of this magnitude would also effectively 'blow up' the current IT chess board, forcing the hand of other incumbent vendors to gain greater scale and/or assemble vertically integrated stacks."Enterprise data-storage company EMC saw its shares jump Thursday on reports that it could be acquired by privately held Dell, a deal analysts say could lead to more consolidation among the largest tech hardware and services companies.Dell is said to be in advanced talks with EMC (EMC) about a possible merger, as was first reported late Wednesday by the Wall Street Journal. With a market capitalization of $52 billion, EMC would be one of the tech's biggest takeover targets ever.Dell's offer for EMC could be more than $27 a share, CNBC reported Thursday. The deal announcement could be only a week away. Dell likely would need $40 billion in financing for the acquisition, CNBC said."A combined EMC/Dell would create a larger vendor that would own the entire stack and give it scale to compete against other large OEMs and cloud vendors, though the company would have to integrate and execute a strategy," Wells Fargo Securities analyst Maynard Um said in a research report Thursday.EMC stock rose 4.7% Thursday, to 27.18, its seventh up day in a row after hitting a two-year closing low of 23.13 on Sept. 29.EMC has been under pressure by activist investor Elliott Management to divest assets, including its 80% ownership in virtualization-software leader VMware (VMW) .Dell was taken private in October 2013 by Dell founder and CEO Michael Dell and private-equity firm Silver Lake Partners, in a deal worth $25 billion. Since going private, Dell has shifted its emphasis from personal computers to enterprise hardware, software and services.Other media reports suggest that Dell is interested in buying only part of EMC. Re/code reported Wednesday that EMC approached Dell within the last six weeks to sell its VNX storage product line, not the whole company.VNX has annual sales of about $3 billion, Re/code said.A purchase of part of EMC would be easier to digest for Dell, which has about $12 billion in debt on its books.Wall Street Skeptical Of DealA breakup of EMC would unlock more value for EMC shareholders than a sale to Dell, BMO Capital Markets analyst Keith Bachman said in a report Thursday."EMC's individual business units are worth more than the current aggregate valuation," Bachman said. "We believe the sum of the parts valuation is between $30 and $32 (a share)."Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi doubts that Dell could buy EMC."We don't think that Dell has the financial capacity to buy EMC, even if EMC were to spin-out VMware," Sacconaghi said. "Dell currently has about $12 billion in debt and an enterprise value likely around $20 billion to $25 billion, vs. EMC's enterprise value of around $45 billion."Even spinning out VMware, Dell would likely have to pay $25 billion or more for EMC to ensure a premium for EMC shareholders, which we believe would be financially very difficult to do. Moreover, it is unclear how compelling EMC without VMware would be to Dell, particularly since Dell has its own storage line-up."'Head-Scratcher'The possible sale of EMC's VNX storage business to Dell appears more plausible, given its size ($2 billion to $6 billion in annual sales), he said. "But it is still not obvious why Dell would be eager to acquire the assets," he said.FBR Capital Markets analyst Daniel Ives calls any Dell-EMC deal a "major head-scratcher.""It would be a very financially complex merger, high integration issues, and fundamentally would combine two very mature companies into one," he told Bloomberg.But EMC CEO Joe Tucci is under pressure to boost returns for EMC investors, Ives said in a note late Wednesday."Joe Tucci and the EMC board have their backs against the wall as activist investor Elliott Management appears to have put enough heat in the kitchen to force this mature stalwart to figure out a strategic plan after years of struggles," Ives said. "Of all the options potentially on the table, we would view a merger with the now-private Dell as a 'nightmare scenario' that would lack strategic synergies and further complicate EMC's troubled growth path."The information-technology industry "is ripe for consolidation," Macquarie Capital analyst Rajesh Ghai said in a report Thursday. "EMC, with its market leadership in the storage and virtualization markets, has significant strategic value and is likely to be the first candidate for consolidation."A merger of EMC and Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) HP Enterprise would have more cost synergies than a merger with Dell, Ghai said. But Dell may be more willing to divest EMC's stake in VMware, he said.HP stock rose 4.2% Thursday.A Dell-EMC deal could kick off a wave of M&A activity in the IT infrastructure industry, William Blair analyst Jason Ader said in a report."Such a deal would be a response to massive secular changes occurring in the market," Ader said. "A deal of this magnitude would also effectively 'blow up' the current IT chess board, forcing the hand of other incumbent vendors to gain greater scale and/or assemble vertically integrated stacks."

Microsoft (MSFT) earned high marks for the new products it unveiled Tuesday, but Wall Street analysts doubt that these latest smartphones, tablet-notebook convertibles and wearable devices will be big sales drivers for the company.

At a product launch event in New York City, Microsoft showed off new Lumia smartphones, the Surface Pro 4 tablet with attachable keyboard and the Surface Book notebook PC with detachable tablet display. It also trotted out the Microsoft Band 2 wearable fitness tracker and demonstrated its still-in-development HoloLens holographic computing glasses.
Microsoft wants to change the perception that it is a "rounding error" in the mobile device landscape, FBR analyst Daniel Ives said in a research note Tuesday.

"While the new hardware products look impressive, it all comes down to consumer adoption as Microsoft aggressively tries to change its consumer image," Ives said. He rates Microsoft stock as outperform.

Microsoft's Lumia smartphones are a distant third in market share behind Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google Android-based handsets and Apple's (AAPL) iPhones, lacking the scale in app ecosystem and user base necessary to attract consumers and developers. Microsoft is positioning its Lumia 950 and 950 XL handsets as full Windows 10 PCs for users focused on productivity.

"We continue to be skeptical about Microsoft's ability to take meaningful smartphone share," Cowen analyst Gregg Moskowitz said in a note Tuesday. He rates Microsoft stock market perform, with a price target of 49.
Microsoft stock rose a fraction to 46.80 on the stock market today.

With its latest Surface computers, Microsoft is pursuing the high-end of the portable computer market, where Apple reigns. At the event, Microsoft compared the performance of the Surface Pro 4 with Apple's MacBook Air and the Surface Book with Apple's MacBook Pro. But Microsoft has priced its devices at a premium to Apple.
The 12.3-inch Surface Pro 4 starts at $1,029 with a keyboard cover, compared with the $999 starting price for the 13-inch MacBook Air.
The 13.5-inch Surface Book starts at $1,499, compared with $1,299 for an entry-level 13-inch MacBook Pro.

Microsoft's second-generation fitness band, the Microsoft Band 2, plays in a space between Fitbit (FIT) activity trackers and the Apple Watch smartwatch. It costs $250, the same price as a high-end Fitbit Surge GPS watch, but less than the $349 starting price of the Apple Watch.
Jefferies analyst John DiFucci said Microsoft's fall product launch didn't change his bearish view on Microsoft. He rates Microsoft stock underperform, with a price target of 37.
"We still see Microsoft as overly dependent on the secularly challenged PC ecosystem, and we believe there is material risk to a transition to cloud," DiFucci said in a report Tuesday.

Microsoft's entry into the laptop market with the Surface Book could strain its relationship with hardware partners that make their own Windows PCs, such as Lenovo and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), he said.Microsoft (MSFT) earned high marks for the new products it unveiled Tuesday, but Wall Street analysts doubt that these latest smartphones, tablet-notebook convertibles and wearable devices will be big sales drivers for the company.At a product launch event in New York City, Microsoft showed off new Lumia smartphones, the Surface Pro 4 tablet with attachable keyboard and the Surface Book notebook PC with detachable tablet display. Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) appears to be making progress as it works through the third year of a five-year restructuring process launched in May 2012 and prepares for a company split into two entities by the end of next year.
That's the assessment from several analysts after the global computer product giant reported a mixed bag of fourth-quarter results after the market close on Tuesday. Here is IBD's report.
HP's restructuring process involves putting more emphasis on emerging markets, including cloud computing, Big Data and security, to offset declining growth in other businesses such as printing.
In a Wednesday report, Steven Milunovich, an analyst for UBS Securities, called HP's Q4 performance "a decent end to a strong year." He has a neutral rating on the company.

"Although light revenue was the headline after the close, we aren't too concerned, as improving margin performance was a positive offset," he wrote. "HP continues to have some momentum due to improved products, cost savings to protect profits, the coming breakup that adds modest value, and the roll-out of Meg Whitman's 'Playing to Win' approach borrowed from Procter & Gamble."
Others agreed.
In a report late Tuesday, Maynard Um, an analyst for Wells Fargo Securities, says HP is making significant strides in its restructuring plan. He has an outperform rating on the company.

"We believe HP has largely turned the corner and is well positioned in a number of segments — share gain potential in PCs, strong portfolio and cycles in servers, improvement in services, a bottoming of supplies in printing, improved margins across its segments, strong cash flow generation, good growth in new higher margin businesses (networking, security, Big Data, Inkjet Pro X) and catch-up share repurchases ahead," he wrote. "While it doesn't change the secular forces in the industry and the impact to HP, we think the company is much better positioned to move forward than it has been in quite some time."

In a report late Tuesday, Brent Bracelin, an analyst for Pacific Crest Securities, noted that healthy notebook PC growth of 9% was masked by a revenue shortfall in the enterprise group, which declined 4% vs. the year-earlier period. Storage and industry-standard servers revenue also fell by the most in over a year.

But HP's coming separation, which would place its PC and printer groups in one company and its enterprise and software businesses in another, could help reaccelerate the company's growth, Bracelin wrote.
"We are maintaining our outperform rating based on the separation that could enhance shareholder value and justify upside to $40 (a share)," he wrote.
Some investors seem to share the analyst optimism. Shares rose more than 3% in the stock market today.

But some analysts remain cautious. In a report Wednesday, Ambrish Srivastava, an analyst for BMO Capital Markets, said that while the coming split will likely drive the stock higher, several questions remain. He has a market perform rating on the company.

"Will total costs increase in fiscal year 2016 post-split, since HP will have to carry two public companies? Can HP grow revenues, even post-split (more nimble and more focused)? Until we satisfy our concerns surrounding these two questions, we choose to sit on the sidelines," he wrote.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) appears to be making progress as it works through the third year of a five-year restructuring process launched in May 2012 and prepares for a company split into two entities by the end of next year.That's the assessment from several analysts after the global computer product giant reported a mixed bag of fourth-quarter results after the market close on Tuesday. He has a neutral rating on the company."Although light revenue was the headline after the close, we aren't too concerned, as improving margin performance was a positive offset," he wrote. "HP continues to have some momentum due to improved products, cost savings to protect profits, the coming breakup that adds modest value, and the roll-out of Meg Whitman's 'Playing to Win' approach borrowed from Procter & Gamble."Others agreed.In a report late Tuesday, Maynard Um, an analyst for Wells Fargo Securities, says HP is making significant strides in its restructuring plan. Hewlett-Packard's road to revenue growth has hit another pothole.The computer products giant reported a mixed bag of fiscal fourth-quarter numbers late Tuesday as the company continues to work through a restructuring that will include splitting it into two separate entities by the end of next year.The company's Q4 sales missed analyst views, while its earnings for the quarter were merely in line.Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) earnings forecast for the current quarter was lighter than expected.Shares fell about 1% in after-hours trading. HP stock ended the regular session up a fraction at 37.63.HP's revenue fell 2% year over year to $28.4 billion in the quarter ended Oct. 31. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected a 1.2% decline to $28.76 billion.HP reported earnings per share minus items of $1.06, up 5% from the year-earlier period and in line with analyst estimates.The company's 2% decline in revenue in Q4 failed to match the 1% year-over-year revenue growth in the prior quarter, which had been its first positive revenue gain in 11 quarters dating back to July 2011. HP's sales miss comes even as the company posted its fourth consecutive quarter with year-over-year revenue growth in its PC business.HP has been scrambling to move into newer areas such as cloud computing and Big Data to offset declining growth in its printing and other businesses.The company launched what is expected to be a five-year restructuring effort in May 2012.But HP's third-quarter growth was more of an anomaly than a new direction for the company — at least for now, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald."When you look at the big picture of HP and you look at all of the different businesses, there is really not one market where you can say, 'That is going to take off in terms of revenue,'" he told IBD. "Whether it's services or the enterprise group, PCs or printers — none of them is really growing, or at least the markets are not growing at respectable rates."For the current quarter, HP said it expects earnings per share of 89 to 93 cents, or a decline of 1.1% to an increase of 3.3%.Analysts had modeled for 93 cents EPS and revenue to decline by 2.1% to $27.55 billion. HP doesn't provide a revenue forecast.For the full year, HP said it expects EPS of $3.83 to $4.03, up 2.4% to 7.7%.Analysts have been expecting $3.94 EPS, or growth of 5.3%, and revenue of $110.35 billion, down 1%.During a conference call with analysts, HP CEO Meg Whitman expressed confidence in the company's direction."Overall, I'm very pleased with the progress we have made," she said. "On the top line, I have always said that turnarounds aren't linear and, while we are seeing clear pockets of growth, other areas still need more work. But overall our revenue performance has improved dramatically over the past three years."HP will keep a sharp focus on its fundamental operations, she said, including its cost structure and supply chain.As in prior quarters, HP's line items reveal a company with more misses than hits.Revenue from the company's personal systems group, which is mostly PCs, increased 4% year over year to $8.94 billion.Sales of notebooks increased 9% to $4.86 billion while desktops decreased 3% to $3.18 billion.Printing revenue declined 5% to $5.74 billion.Sales of supplies slipped 7% to $3.59 billion.HP stock is up 35% year to date through Tuesday's close. Investors might be buying into the promise that HP can carve a niche in the growing 3D printing market after it announced the development of a product last month that is expected to be ready for sale in 2016, White says."The 3D dream helps the perception around the stock," he said. "The market does believe in 3D printing, and they are definitely a leader in printing."Revenue from HP's enterprise group, including servers, storage and networking systems, declined 4% to $7.27 billion.Sales of industry standard servers fell 2% to $3.37 billion.Technology services revenue decreased 3% to $2.11 billion.Enterprise services revenue declined 7% to $5.51 billion.Sales of infrastructure technology outsourcing fell 7% to $3.44 billion, while revenue from application and business services fell 6% to $2.06 billion.HP will need more than just a resurging PC business to reaccelerate its growth, White says."It comes back to (the question): Is this portfolio positioned for Big Data, cloud, Internet of Things, things that are major trends?" he said. "I don't think it's as well positioned as other companies."Even though HP plans to split the company into two separate companies, the challenge for the company doesn't end there, says Rohit Mehra, an analyst for IDC."The bigger challenge is for the personal systems side as well as the enterprise side to actually show the market that they have entered a period where they can show sustained growth," he told IBD.

Stocks finished narrowly mixed Tuesday with volume running mildly higher than the prior day, according to preliminary data.The Nasdaq rose 0.1%; the S&P 500 fell 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average was slightly lower. The S&P 500 notched another intraday all-time high, and the Nasdaq reached its highest level since March 2000.After the close, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) reported EPS of $1.06 a share, in line with estimates. Revenue was $28.4 billion, slightly below the forecast number of $28.76 billion. The stock was trading mildly lower after hours.Wednesday morning will be busy with the publication of economic indicators, some moved up a day because of Thursday's Thanksgiving holiday.Before the open, new durable goods orders for October are forecast to drop 0.5%. In September, they fell 1.3%.Jobless claims are expected to come in at 286,000, down from 291,000 the previous week. Personal income for October is expected to rise 0.4% vs. 0.2% in the prior month.After the open, the final University of Michigan sentiment survey for November is expected to be 90.0 vs. 89.4 in October.Pending home sales, new-home sales, crude oil inventories and the natural inventories are also scheduled for release after the open.

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) might not show much progress on reaccelerating its revenue growth when the company reports its fourth-quarter earnings after the market close Tuesday, analysts say.
Analysts expect revenue to slip 1.2% from the year-earlier quarter. Three months ago, HP posted a 1.3% year-over-year revenue gain for the first time in 11 quarters.
HP is amid a restructuring effort as it focuses on emerging growth areas such as cloud services and Big Data to offset declines or slowing growth in its computer and printer businesses.
Last month, HP announced it would split itself into two separate companies, on for PCs and printers and the other enterprise services. It plans to complete the split by the end of next year.

HP's recent $2 billion on share buybacks, however, prompted Sherri Scribner, an analyst for Deutsche Bank, to add 5 cents per share to her EPS estimates for fiscal 2015 and 2016, and to boost her price target on HP stock to 45 from 40.
Scribner now expects EPS minus items of $4 for 2015 and $4.15 in 2016, where the consensus analyst estimates are 3.94 and 4.19. She rates HP stock a buy.

"We have raised our price target to $45 from $40, driven by our higher fiscal year 2015 estimate EPS and by higher multiple of 11x (vs. 10x previously)," she wrote in a research note. "An 11x multiple is in line with HP's historical average multiple and in line with peers."

She said downside risks include an inability to deliver on restructuring plans, lack of growth from PCs and printers, risk of cannibalization from the cloud and the split not taking place, for whatever reason.
For fiscal Q4, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect HP to report earnings per share minus items of $1.06, up 4.9% from the year-earlier period. Revenue is expected to fall to $28.7 billion.
For the current quarter, analysts expect an EPS of 93 cents, up 3.3% and revenue to decline 2% to $27.55 billion.
HP stock was up a fraction in midday trading in the stock market today, near 37.50 and near a more than three-year high of 38.25 touched in September. HP stock is up nearly 35% this year.
Investors are likely buying in on the promise of future performance, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald. He rates HP stock a hold.

"What HP has going for it is its restructuring initiatives and the fact that they are going to split the company in two," White told IBD. "Those are two great things for shareholders."Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) might not show much progress on reaccelerating its revenue growth when the company reports its fourth-quarter earnings after the market close Tuesday, analysts say.Analysts expect revenue to slip 1.2% from the year-earlier quarter. A stronger dollar will rear its head when companies report fourth-quarter earnings, with Apple (AAPL), Google and IBM among those that will be affected.

The rally in the dollar has been driven by the strength of the U.S. economy and expectations for rising interest rates. The big question, though, is how currency weakness in Europe and Japan will factor into Q1 and 2015 guidance on earnings calls, analysts say.

"The decline in the euro, (British) pound and yen is accelerating and is a risk for many companies in Q4 and 2015," said Pacific Crest Securities in a research report late Sunday. "Companies with the most exposure are Priceline (PCLN), Gentex (GNTX), Google (GOOGL) and Harman (HAR) (International)."
Other companies with somewhat less exposure to Europe and Japan include eBay, Amazon.com (AMZN), Facebook (FB) and Discovery (DISCA).
According to Pacific Crest, Chinese Internet companies, including Alibaba (BABA), have "essentially zero" currency risk.
The Q4 and 2015 impact of currency fluctuations on Apple, while exposed to Europe, could be mitigated by growing sales in China, says UBS in a research report.

Barclays, in a report in September, warned that a stronger dollar and weaker euro and yen would spell trouble for many U.S. information technology companies. The companies it identified included IBM (IBM), EMC (EMC), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Juniper Networks (JNPR).
Cisco Systems (CSCO), F5 Networks (FFIV) and Aruba Networks (ARUN) generate 20%-30% of revenue from Europe/Middle East region, but the majority of their sales are denominated in dollars.
Piper Jaffray, in a report Wednesday, said Akamai Technologies' (AKAM) Q4 earnings will be affected by currency.

"Currency will likely prove to be a (revenue drag), likely leading to Q4 results that are only in line with our and street estimates. Thirty percent of Akamai revenue is international (primarily Europe and Japan); both the euro and the yen have depreciated around 5% since the company provided Q4 guidance," wrote Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson.

At Evercore Partners, analyst Jonathan Schildkraut cautions that data center operators such as Digital Realty Trust (DLR) and Equinix (EQIX) as well as Rackspace Hosting (RAX) will be affected by currency fluctuations.

Polycom (PLCM) stock retreated Friday, a day after activist investor Elliott Management disclosed it had a major stake in the videoconferencing company and called on its board to merge with a wireless telecom provider.Shares of Polycom, whose top rivals include heavyweights Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), were down 4% in early afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 12.80. But this comes after a 17% jump Thursday to a four-month high above 13.Elliott Management sent a letter Thursday to San Jose, Calif.-based Polycom, noting it had a 6.6% stake in the company, as well as a major stake in Mitel Networks (MITL), a Canadian wireless provider. All told, New York-based Elliott says it has roughly $100 million invested in each of the companies.In its letter, Elliott called for Polycom to undertake a full strategic review and to consider buying Mitel. Mitel stock, which rose 16.5% Thursday to a two-month high, was up a fraction early Friday afternoon, near 8.20."Maintaining the status quo strategy will perpetuate Polycom's track record of underperformance and risk further shareholder value erosion," Elliott's letter said. "In the last two years, Polycom has already responded by cutting costs, buying back stock and changing management, none of which has generated value to stockholders. Polycom must initiate a comprehensive review of all strategic options, and the time for that review is now."Polycom stock has traded between 9.99 and 14.22 for two years.Mitel and Polycom both declined to comment on the prospect of a deal."Polycom's board and management regularly review and evaluate the company's strategy as part of our commitment to enhance shareholder value," Polycom said in a prepared statement. "We maintain an ongoing dialogue with our shareholders, and we will be meeting with Elliott's representatives to discuss their thoughts. It is our policy, however, not to comment on our discussions with shareholders."William Blair & Co. analyst Jason Ader isn't sure a Polycom-Mitel marriage is the best idea, though he agrees Polycom needs a shake-up. Polycom has been trying to challenge industry leader Cisco in videoconferencing."While we agree with Elliott's premise that the status quo at Polycom is untenable, after reviewing the details of proposal, we are not as optimistic about the potential of a combined Polycom-Mitel entity to drive shareholder value," Ader said in a research note Friday. "Our principal concerns are the lack of substantial cost synergies between Mitel's voice-oriented and Polycom's video-centric products, as well as what we view as overly optimistic Street expectations for Polycom's top-line growth in 2016."Elliott Management has also gotten in the thick of another boardroom issue, calling for data storage giant EMC (EMC) to sell its 80% stake in VMware (VMW). This week, rumors swirled that privately held computer maker Dell might purchase EMC.Follow Russ Britt on Twitter @IBD_RBritt and on Facebook.

Stubbornly high levels of older personal computers still in the sales channel are hindering Windows 10 PC sales, Morgan Stanley says. PC inventory levels have been elevated since early 2015 after manufacturers built too many PCs late last year, Morgan Stanley analyst Katy Huberty said in a report Thursday. To prepare for the Windows 10 product cycle, the industry began clearing inventory in the second quarter, resulting in a decline in production and shipments.
"Our data suggests that even at the seasonal lows in July, inventory was well above peak levels during the Windows 8 launch year (late 2012)," Huberty said.
Computer makers such as Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), Dell and Lenovo have hoped that Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows 10, released on July 29, would spur PC replacement sales.
But initial Windows 10 demand isn't helping to digest the inventory glut, Huberty said.

"Our U.S. PC channel tracker reveals two takeaways regarding the Win 10 refresh cycle: (1) channel inventory was much too high coming into the cycle; and (2) early sell-out isn't helping to clear inventory. As a result, we're cautious on PC sell-in heading into the holiday quarter," she said.
On Wednesday, research firm Gartner said that personal computer and tablet owners are holding on to their current devices longer, putting a crimp on sales of new devices.
Gartner predicts that PC shipments will fall 7.3% to 291 million units worldwide this year. It sees no change in PC shipments in 2016 and a 4.1% increase to 303 million units in 2017.

Publicly traded 3D printer companies are in Wall Street's doghouse, but research firm Gartner (IT) says sales of additive-manufacturing machines are set to soar over the next few years.Worldwide shipments of 3D printers are forecast to more than double every year between 2015 and 2019, by which time shipments are expected to reach more than 5.6 million units, Gartner said in a report Tuesday. Shipments this year are expected to be about 245,000 units, up 129% from 2014."Rapid quality and performance innovations across all 3D printer technologies are driving both enterprise and consumer demand, with unit shipment growth rates for 3D printers increasing significantly," Gartner analyst Pete Basiliere said in a statement. "The 3D printer market is continuing its transformation from a niche market to a broad-based, global market of enterprises and consumers."Additive manufacturing, or 3D printing, uses a device to create physical objects from digital models by applying layer upon layer of material.The primary market drivers for consumer 3D printers costing under $2,500 are not household purchases but acquisitions of low-cost devices by schools and universities, Gartner said. The primary enterprise 3D printer market drivers are the finished-piece quality and material advances, it said.Gartner expects revenue from 3D printer sales to exceed $14.6 billion in 2019 as consumers, businesses and educational institutions ramp up their purchases.Two of the largest enterprise 3D printer makers, Stratasys (SSYS) and 3D Systems (DDD), have encountered strong headwinds due to macroeconomic factors, Gartner said. Those factors included currency exchange rates, prospective customers delaying purchases, and internal issues with the introduction of new 3D printer models, the research firm said.Stratasys hit an all-time high of 138.10 in January 2014, but it closed Thursday at 25.60.3D Systems reached a record high of 97.28 that same month, and it closed Thursday at 10.95.Computer printer and IT giant Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) plans to deliver its first 3D printer in late 2016, initially targeting business and enterprise customers.RELATED:3D Printers Building Up Own Construction Boom3D Systems Earnings Show Ongoing 3-D Printer Struggle.

Investor enthusiasm for tech stocks showed continued signs of weakness, as Pure Storage opened below its initial public offering price Wednesday and closed down 5.8%, while wireless provider Digicel Group postponed its IPO.

Pure Storage (PSTG), a maker of flash-chip-based storage products for the enterprise market, priced late Tuesday at 17, the midpoint of its expected range. The stock opened at 16.74 and closed at 16.01, down 5.8%.
The IPO raised $425 million by offering 25 million shares. The lead underwriters were Morgan Stanley (MS) and Goldman Sachs (GS).

Investors had hoped for a strong showing, since Pure Storage was the first tech IPO since the July 17 debut of Rapid7 (RPD), a data-security and analytics firm. Rapid7 was the only tech IPO in Q3, marking the fewest quarterly tech IPOs in more than six years, according to Renaissance Capital.
In Q3, the IPO market slowed to 34 deals, down 43% from Q3 2014, amid a broad market sell-off, Renaissance said.

Since launching its first product in May 2012, Mountain View, Calif.-based Pure Storage says it's signed up more than 1,100 customers. They include large and midsize organizations in many industries, including cloud-based software and service providers, consumer Web, energy, financial services, governments and health care. Its competitors include much-bigger companies EMC (EMC), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and IBM (IBM).

Pure Storage is growing fast but remains deep in the red. For the 12 months ended Jan. 31, Pure Storage reported revenue of $154.8 million, nearly four times its $39.2 million in revenue for the year-earlier period. But it reported a net loss of $183.2 million as it spent more on research and development and sales and marketing.
For the three months ended April 30, Pure Storage reported revenue of $74 million, up 200% from the year-earlier quarter, but it posted a net loss of $49 million.
Pure storage is one of some 130 "unicorns" — venture capital-backed technology companies with valuations of at least $1 billion.
Before going public, Pure Storage had raised more than $470 million in venture capital, giving it a market valuation of about $3 billion, according to CB Insights.
Box Down, New Relic Up

Other post-IPO unicorn companies have had mixed results. Online-storage provider Box (BOX) was the most recent to go public, on Jan. 23, pricing shares at 14. While the stock popped 66% on its first day of trading, Box closed Wednesday at 11.09.
New Relic (NEWR), a provider of software analytics, went public last December. Shares priced at 23 and popped 48% on its first trading day. New Relic closed Wednesday at 39.31.
Overall, the highest-valued unicorn is ride-hailing firm Uber, at $51 billion. Home-rental service Airbnb is valued at $25.5 billion.

The weak market for tech IPOs is a deterrent for many of these companies to list, but several are expected in the fourth quarter, according to Renaissance Capital. The largest is mobile-payment services company Square, which has an estimated market valuation of $6 billion.
Another is Cloudera, a provider of data analytic services, with an estimated valuation of $4.1 billion.
Square's CEO and co-founder, Jack Dorsey, on Monday was named permanent CEO of Twitter (TWTR), where he had been acting CEO and which he also co-founded.
The $450 million raised by Pure Storage marked the second-largest tech IPO this year.
The largest was website-hosting services provider GoDaddy (GDDY), which raised $460 million. GoDaddy priced at 20 and rose 31% on its first day of trading April 1. GoDaddy closed Wednesday at 25.78.

Box had the third-largest tech IPO, raising $175 million. Shopify (SHOP), which helps small and midsize retailers build and manage online stores, raised $131 million with its May 21 IPO. Shopify stock priced at 17, and it closed Wednesday at 37.33.

While the IPO market has been slow, mergers and acquisitions activity among venture-backed companies was healthy in Q3, marking the strongest quarter this year, reports the National Venture Capital Association.
Digicel Postpones IPO
Meanwhile, Digicel Group, which had planned for a $1.8 billion IPO this week, has decided not to proceed at this time.

"Given our growth outlook, an IPO for Digicel was optional and predicated on achieving fair value for the company," said company Chairman Denis O'Brien in a release issued late Tuesday. "Recent volatility in equity markets has seen a number of IPOs listing at a discount to their signaled price range, and this was a less attractive route for us."

Digicel was slated to price Wednesday and begin trading Thursday. Deep in transition, IBM showed its 14th quarter in a row of year-over-year declining revenue, as the company reported third-quarter earnings after the market close Monday. IBM (IBM) logged earnings per share minus items of $3.34, down 9% from the year-ago period but beating the consensus estimate of $3.30, as polled by Thomson Reuters.Revenue from continuing operations came in at $19.3 billion, down 14%. IBM said adjusting for currency and divested business, revenue fell 1%. Currency fluctuations clipped revenue by $1.9 billion.Foreign currency exchange woes have battered earnings, as IBM gets about two-thirds of its revenue from outside the U.S. IBM has estimated that currency headwinds and divestiture will cut approximately 80 cents off its EPS for 2015.IBM lowered full-year EPS minus items to a range of $14.75 to $15.75, vs. previous guidance of $15.75-$16.50. The midpoint for its updated guidance, $15.25, is below the consensus estimate of $15.68.IBM stock slipped 0.8% during the regular trading session Monday and was down 5%, near 141.85, in after-hours trading. That reflects a decline of about 18% since the company last reported earnings on July 20, beating earnings estimates but missing on revenue.IBM has long been in transition, shedding hardware units and realigning its workforce to cut costs as it focuses on growth areas such as cloud computing, data analytics, mobile computing and security — what it refers to as strategic imperatives.Revenue from strategic imperatives rose 17% from a year earlier (27% adjusting for currency and divested business). It is up 20% year-to-date (30% adjusting for currency and divested business), IBM said.IBM said revenue from its cloud computing business rose 45% (65% after currency and divestiture adjustments). In the trailing 12-month period, cloud revenue totaled $9.4 billion."We've always said our transformation would take time and the transition wouldn't be a straight line," said Martin Schroeter, IBM chief financial officer, in a call with reporters after earnings posted. "We've maintained high levels of investments because we are seeing our strategy is correct and we are getting the returns and growth."IBM is not alone among tech giants that are transitioning to more advanced business models."As we have seen with IBM and many of its mature tech brethren (Oracle (ORCL), EMC (EMC), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), Cisco (CSCO) over the past year, growth has been agonizing to come by as these large traditional IT vendors face an Everest-like climb in their quest for success in this ever changing IT landscape," FBR Capital Markets analyst Daniel Ives wrote in a research note prior to IBM earnings.An example of that is the $67 billion Dell will pay to acquire data-storage giant EMC."These once almighty stalwarts are now scratching their heads trying to figure out the path (or exit strategy) for a renaissance of growth around cloud, big data, cybersecurity, and IoT (Internet of Things)," Ives wrote.Schroeter said IBM has invested over $10 billion in research and development, capital expenditures and acquisitions in the past year.This month, IBM acquired Merge Healthcare, a provider of medical image processing technology, for $1 billion. It will become part of IBM's new Watson Health business unit. IBM also launched a new business unit called IBM Cognitive Business Solutions, based on its Watson computer.IBM said revenue from the Americas fell 10% to $9.1 billion, down 3% adjusting for currency fluctuations and divestitures.

Personal computer and tablet owners are holding on to their current devices longer, putting a crimp on sales of new devices, market research firm Gartner said Wednesday.Gartner predicts that shipments of personal computers will fall 7.3% to 291 million units worldwide this year. It sees no change in PC shipments in 2016 and a 4.1% increase to 303 million units in 2017.Gartner forecasts shipments of tablets and convertible devices to fall 11.9% to 199 million in 2015. It predicts shipments in the category will increase to 208 units in 2016 and 218 million in 2017.Mobile phone shipments are seen topping 1.9 billion units in 2015, up 1.4%, and 1.96 billion in 2016. Gartner projects that mobile phone shipments in 2017 will hit 2 billion units, with smartphones accounting for 89% of the total.Combined PC, tablet and mobile phone shipments will decline 1% this year because PC and tablet owners are experiencing "replacement indecision," Gartner said in a press release."Replacement activity across all types of devices has decreased," Gartner analyst Ranjit Atwal said in the release. "Users are extending the lifetime of their devices, or deciding not to replace their devices at all."The launch of Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows 10 operating system has failed to reverse declining PC sales, Gartner noted. But PC sales should return to growth in 2017, thanks to business orders, it said.Sales of tablets like Apple's (AAPL) iPad also have been hurt by longer replacement cycles, the researcher said. Also, a Gartner survey of 19,000 consumers in the U.S., U.K., France, China, Brazil and India found that 44% of current tablet users are planning to substitute their tablets with a different device, such as a smartphone.Rival research firm IDC said it expects the current downturn in PC shipments to last five years.Last month, PC maker Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) said it expects PC sales to remain weak through early 2016.

Jabil reported revenue of $4.68 billion, up 15% from the year-earlier quarter, beating Wall Street estimates of $4.55 billion. It posted earnings per share minus items of 53 cents, up from 5 cents and…

New Relic (NEWR) is in a great position to carve out a piece of the fast-growing Big Data market, even as the company competes with much larger rivals that include Hewlett-Packard and IBM. At least three investment banks opened coverage Tuesday on the applications management software maker with favorable ratings. New Relic, however, was down nearly 3% in early trading…

2014 saw the fewest planned job cuts since 1997, according to placement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas. Layoffs announced in December were down 9.2% from November, the second straight month of declines, and took 2014 totals 5.0% below those notched in 2013.Fewer layoffs are good news for job seekers, Challenger said, because they "will not only find more employment opportunities in 2015 but will enjoy increased job security once they are in those new positions."Challenger's figures point to not only a firming job market but also one with more churn. The two industries with the greatest number of layoffs were computer and retail. Both, Challenger acknowledged, are benefiting from the economic expansion.The computer industry saw a 69% jump in layoffs last year to 59,528. But much of that downsizing came thanks to efforts by Microsoft (MSFT) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) to compete better with more streamlined operations.Lower oil prices might help the overall economy but could lead to layoffs this year in the energy and energy-related fields. U.S. Steel (X) said this month that it would shut a plant that makes specialized pipes for the energy industry, cutting 768 jobs.Coca-Cola (KO) said Thursday it will cut 1,600-1,800 jobs as part of a previously announced $3 billion cost-cutting plan amid stalling soda sales. Caterpillar (CAT) said Wednesday it will 200 jobs, mostly related to mining equipment, which has struggled as low commodity prices and demand hit mining.Those three companies' job cut announcements will show up in Challenger's January report.The Labor Department releases its December employment report on Friday morning.

Europe, China, South Korea and Japan aim to jump ahead with 5G mobile broadband next-generation wireless services. The U.S. might not roll out 5G wireless on a wide…

But already Amazon (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT) have emerged as early leaders. Microsoft, which dominated during the…

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) held the top position in the computer server market in the third quarter with 26.5% share of revenue, followed by IBM (IBM) with 18.2%. Global server sales rose 4.8% to $12.7 billion, as unit shipments rose 5.7% to 2.38 million. This is the second consecutive quarter that the server market has experienced a year-over-year improvement in worldwide revenue,…

While it has yet to ship a single 3D printer, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) is in a strong position to lead the market, says UBS. HP expects to begin delivering its first 3D printers in late 2016 and will target sales to businesses and other enterprises.HP's timing is good, says the investment bank, after the early 3D printer leaders Stratasys (SSYS) and 3D Systems (DDD) encountered some big ups and big downs."The market was overhyped, with the technology still immature, resulting in roller-coaster rides for the stocks of Stratasys and 3D Systems," wrote UBS analyst Steven Milunovich in a research report. "However, we think the market is real and could be about $20 billion in 2020."Sales in the 3D printer market this year are estimated to come in at about $5 billion.Stratasys and 3D Systems are the two largest providers of 3D printers. The stock of both companies soared from early 2012 through early 2014. Then the stocks fell, on the reality that the industry had many mountains yet to climb."We think 3D printing is a significant long-term opportunity, but the technology is immature in terms of speed, quality and reliability, which has caused problems for Stratasys and 3D Systems," Milunovich wrote.He says that HP has solved bottlenecks holding back 3D printing, such as speed.It is "entirely believable that HP could become the leading 3D printing company," due to its current strength as a printing vendor, he wrote."Our view is that 3D printing is in the early innings of commercial implementation, with the industrial greater than the consumer opportunity," Milunovich wrote. "3D printing lacks economies of scale today for most applications. Over time, however, we believe 3D printing is on a path to overcoming its shortcomings in throughput, process stability, equipment life, post-processing elimination, materials know-how, production qualification and ease of use."Follow Brian Deagon on Twitter @IBD_BDeagon.
