Call-center operators are still plenty busy handling phone calls for tech support, service complaints, billing, collections and other matters. One of them is Convergys (CVG), spun off from Cincinnati Bell in 1998 and now one of the largest call-center operators in the world. It provides services to customers in…

When you're developing cutting-edge technology, it's easy to get carried away. Just ask John Sculley. Apple's (AAPL) chief executive from 1983 to 1993, Sculley had already gained a reputation as a marketing whiz from his earlier years running Pepsi (PEP). In 1992, he oversaw Apple's launch of the Newton, the first handheld personal digital assistant.
"The product failed," Sculley recalled. "We should have spent more time focusing on customer experience instead of saying: 'This is a cool technology. Let's get it out there.'"

Sculley, now 75, remembers the excitement of unveiling a whole new type of mobile personal digital system. He and his team knew they were creating something that consumers had never seen, but their drive to innovate stymied their ability to alleviate a customer's pain points.
"We were focused on this advanced technology instead of identifying a big customer need," he said. "The tech direction we were going in was right, but we were years ahead of ourselves."
A few years after the Newton launch, Palm Computing introduced its version of a personal digital assistant. It proved a success.

"Palm used traditional technology that had been around for years," Sculley said. "But they solved a real customer problem: how to keep track of numbers for a mobile phone and email addresses." Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) bought Palm in 2010 for more than $1 billion.
Newton And The Apple Watch
Reflecting on the Newton rollout, Sculley says that it's important not to get too enamored of technology.
"The lesson I learned is always start with solving a really big customer problem in a way that customers tell you they want," he said. "You want to solve that problem in a way that customers love."
From that standpoint, what does the former Apple executive think of Apple's newest innovation?

"The Apple Watch is a beautiful product with a stellar design," Sculley said. "But the reality is we don't know what people will do with it yet. From an investor's standpoint, it's a 2016 story, not a 2015 story. It'll take well into next year to see the real implication in terms of shareholder value."
Sculley has heard that individuals who have tested the watch report that they don't pull out their iPhone as much. They are embarking on what he calls "a new user experience.

"It'll do new things like notify you of alerts on your calendar or allow you to not stop at the front desk when you check into a hotel," he said. "Maybe it'll be used for digital health, or maybe you'll be talking into your watch like Dick Tracy."
The Moonshot Man
Author of "Moonshot!: Game-Changing Strategies to Build Billion-Dollar Businesses," Sculley now serves as an investor and entrepreneur.

In 1996, he heeded the lesson from the abortive Newton launch when he joined the founding team that built MetroPCS, a prepaid wireless carrier. "We solved a really big customer problem at price points lower than anybody else," Sculley said. "People wanted an inexpensive way to have a cell phone without a contract, and we reached out to those people." MetroPCS merged with T-Mobile (TMUS) in 2013.

If you want to spur innovation, Sculley suggests asking, "What's a big customer problem we can solve?" He urges CEOs to stay close to the customer at every phase of product development and constantly assess what users think and how you can enhance their experience.

"When you look at all the new technologies, market power is shifting from large incumbent companies to new companies coming out with better customer experiences," he said. "Small companies can become big without waiting a decade to grow."

He credits social media with enabling shoppers to tap other customers' positive experiences. They provide a springboard for startups to prosper in just a year or two, as long as they devise a better way to address a common frustration that consumers face.

"Uber doesn't advertise," he noted. "It's all word-of-mouth."When you're developing cutting-edge technology, it's easy to get carried away. Just ask John Sculley. Intel slashed its revenue estimate for Q1 by nearly $1 billion early Thursday, citing weaker-than-expected demand for business personal computers and lower-than-expected inventory levels across the PC-supply chain.The Santa Clara, Calif.-based chipmaker, the longtime leader in chips that power PCs and servers, expects Q1 revenue of $12.8 billion, plus or minus $300 million, down from its previous forecast of $13.7 billion, plus or minus $500 million.Late Thursday, market tracker IDC lowered its outlook for PC shipments this year to a 4.9% decline from its earlier forecast for a 3.3% decline.Intel (INTC) stock fell 4.7% Thursday to 30.80, a five-month low. Intel stock has fallen 15% this year.PC operating system leader Microsoft (MSFT) fell 2.3%, but shares of No. 2 PC maker Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), down much of the day, ended up a fraction."The company believes the changes to demand and inventory patterns are caused by lower-than-expected Windows XP refresh in small and medium business and increasingly challenging macroeconomic and currency conditions, particularly in Europe," Intel said in a press release Thursday.Intel noted that its data center business is meeting expectations. Intel is slated to report Q1 earnings after the close April 14.Intel expects its closely watched gross profit margin, or earnings after production costs, to remain at 60% and the midpoint of its guidance as lower PC unit volume is offset by higher average selling prices.Expectations for research and development spending, merger and acquisition spending, and depreciation for Q1 remain unchanged, Intel said.In January, Intel reported a 6.5% increase in Q4 revenue to $14.72 billion, with a solid holiday season for PC sales and mobile phone sales helping boost Intel's results above analysts' expectations. The company saw an increase in PC purchases after Microsoft ended technical support for its Windows XP operating system.

ExOne (XONE) reported a wider-than-expected fourth-quarter loss Monday night as sales missed forecasts, continuing the run of bad news for once-hot 3D printer stocks despite advances for additive manufacturing.ExOne said it lost 50 cents a share, appearing to miss analyst estimates for a 5-cent loss. Revenue rose 47% to $15.8 million vs. views for about $18.5 million. The company, which makes large-scale 3D printers for customers in auto, aerospace and other industrial markets, sold 11 machines vs. 12 a year earlier.The 3D-printer maker sees 2015 revenue of $58 million to $66 million, up 32%-50% and in line with views. But the company has struggled to live up to its guidance, and it sees 70% of revenue in the second half of 2015.ExOne shares fell 9.6% to 10.70 in after-hours trading. The stock had closed up 4 cents to 15.15 on the stock market today. The stock hit a record intraday low of 13.40 on Feb. 4. It peaked at 78.80 in August 2013.ExOne isn't the only 3D printer stock to stumble.3D Systems (DDD) fell 1.1% to 26.93, hitting its lowest level since late 2012. In late February, 3D reported weaker-than-expected earnings and another quarter of decelerating sales growth.Stratasys (SSYS) on Feb. 2 reported weak Q4 earnings and a disappointing 2015 outlook, with its consumer-focused MakerBot line having particular problems. Shares plunged 28% the next day, hitting 51.55 intraday, the worst since July 2012. Stratasys rose 0.3% to 57.95 on Monday.While pure-play 3D stocks sink, 3D printing — or additive manufacturing — takes flight, literally. General Electric (GE) plans to use 3D-printed parts in jet engines that are far stronger than those from traditional manufacturing processes.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), a traditional printer giant, has been making a big move into 3D printing as well, with sales expected next year. That could put pressure on 3D-focused companies.

Global sales of enterprise disk storage systems reached $10.57 billion in the fourth quarter at the factory level, up 7.2% from the year-earlier period, says research firm IDC.EMC (EMC), the longtime leader, retained its No. 1 spot with a 22% market share, down from 21% in Q4 2013. EMC's Q4 revenue in disk storage systems totaled $2.35 billion.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) was No. 2 with a 13.8% share. HP maintained its Q4 lead in server sales, however.Dell was No. 3 in disk storage system sales last quarter, while IBM (IBM) and NetApp (NTAP) tied for the fourth position."The storage market had a strong finish to 2014," IDC analyst Eric Sheppard said in a press release."Fourth-quarter spending on enterprise storage systems was up strongly in most major geographic markets, driven by traditional year-end seasonality, demand for midrange systems that incorporate flash capacity, and continued growth of systems designed for hyperscale datacenters," he said.Storage systems sales by original design manufacturers selling directly to hyperscale datacenter customers accounted for 12.8% of global spending during the quarter.Disk storage system spending for the year rose 3.6% to $36.2 billion.IDC defines a disk storage system as a packaged set of storage elements, including disk drives, controllers and cables.

In Q1, notebook shipments from original design manufacturers are expected to fall 6% from the year-earlier period, while motherboard shipments will likely decline 9%, following a weaker-than-expected February, says the report, from investment bank BMO Capital Markets. The trend is headed…

Hewlett-Packard continues to be stuck in neutral, with all of its businesses recording revenue that fell or was flat compared with a year ago, though a few units within those businesses saw increases. Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) late Tuesday reported earnings for its fiscal Q1, which ended Jan. 31, that edged analyst estimates. It also reported revenue that fell short. The company…

Fueled by stronger-than-expected PC sales, Hewlett-Packard on Thursday posted first-quarter results that beat analyst estimates. However, its current-quarter earnings guidance lagged Wall Street expectations.

The Q1 results were a positive sign for the global computer products company, which is slogging through a five-year restructuring effort launched in May 2012. Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) is trying to build up its enterprise, software and other businesses to offset stagnant growth in its core multibillion-dollar PC and printing units.
HP stock rose nearly 1% in late trading Thursday, after closing the regular session at 30.19, up 2.5%.

HP's results came a week after Cisco Systems (CSCO) reported declining revenue growth for its first quarter as the networking company struggles to transition from its core switching and router hardware systems to software and other products.
Though HP's Q1 report shows stability, it's still a long way from re-accelerating growth, says Needham & Co. analyst Richard Kugele.

"They have righted the ship, but they haven't gone and found a way to truly grow yet," he said. "It's difficult because they have so many different business lines that it's like they are fighting a five-front war all at once."
HP's restructuring plan is akin to a massive juggling effort, says Crawford Del Prete, an analyst for research firm IDC.

"PCs are slowly stabilizing, which will help the revenue growth," he said. "They need to balance all of these things to deliver on that plan, let alone beating that plan. They are still transitioning the business."
In the quarter ended Jan. 31, HP reported a per-share profit, minus items, of 90 cents, up 9.7% vs. 82 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 84 cents.
Revenue fell 1% to $28.2 billion. Analysts had expected sales of $27.19 billion or a 4.1% decline.
For the current quarter, HP expects a per-share profit, ex items, of 85 to 89 cents vs. 87 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts were modeling for 89 cents.
HP didn't give a revenue outlook. But analysts target a year-over-year sales decline of 2.3% to $26.93 billion.

During a conference call with analysts, HP CEO Meg Whitman said the company achieved revenue growth in its personal systems group for the first time in seven quarters. She said the company's Q1 performance was encouraging, but more improvement is needed.

"HP is in a stronger position than we have been in quite some time," she said. "We still have a long way to go, but I am more convinced than ever that we are making the right moves to set HP up for the long term."
Whitman also said HP is planning new product offerings to fuel its turnaround effort.

"We are not taking our foot off the pedal," she said. "Over the next few quarters, we will introduce significant new innovations that will build upon our offerings in cloud, security, Big Data and converged infrastructure, as well some remarkable new technologies in printing and personal systems."
HP's business unit performance was a mixed bag in Q1.

Revenue from the company's personal systems group, which is largely PCs, increased 4% to $8.53 billion vs. the year-earlier period.Fueled by stronger-than-expected PC sales, Hewlett-Packard on Thursday posted first-quarter results that beat analyst estimates. However, its current-quarter earnings guidance lagged Wall Street expectations.The Q1 results were a positive sign for the global computer products company, which is slogging through a five-year restructuring effort launched in May 2012. Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) entry into the high-end commercial 3D printer market, expected in June, is unlikely to worsen price competition for Stratasys (SSYS), 3D Systems (DDD) and ExOne (XONE), says RBC Capital.

"We do not envision increased competition among industry players once HPQ introduces 3D printing products and potentially other ancillary 3D products and services, as we see a growing 3D total addressable market and increased opportunities for all 3D market participants," wrote Amit Daryanani, an RBC Capital analyst, in a research report late Wednesday.

HP CEO Meg Whitman told shareholders at the company's annual meeting on Tuesday that HP had solved a number of technical problems that have hindered broader adoption of the high-tech manufacturing process, as Reuters reported. Whitman said the company would have more to say in June.

3D printer stocks are well off 2013 highs amid slowing revenue growth and mixed financial results. Before Thursday, shares of Stratasys, which owns MakerBot, were down nearly 15% this year, while 3D Systems stock had plunged more than 30% and ExOne nearly as much.

But disappointing results released last Wednesday by ExOne is hurting the stock Thursday morning. ExOne stock was down 9% in morning trading in the stock market today, while 3D stock was down nearly 3% and Stratasys stock down 1%.
HP stock, though, was up more than 2% in morning trading Thursday.

In the just-emerging consumer end of the 3D market, U.S. companies will face more competition from China-based makers of 3D printers. Some of these companies showcased products at the Consumer Electronics Show in January.
HP plans to enter the higher-priced commercial market.

"While it remains to be seen which type of printer technology the firm will ultimately roll out, we believe the firm will focus on the enterprise and industrial segment, and leverage its existing printing-head technology and distribution channel to become a formidable player in this market over time," Daryanani wrote.

"We continue to see the 3D printing market growing at around a 24% compound annual growth rate from 2013-2021, to become a $15 billion industry, fueled by lower average selling prices, increased industry awareness, increased ability to manufacture production-grade parts," he said.

"Shutterfly grew organic consumer revenue by an estimated 15% in 2013, vs. 17% growth for overall U.S. e-commerce, the first time Shutterfly has not…

Friday's launch of two technology IPOs became a story of opposites. Shares of 2U (TWOU), which provides online education services, were up 7% in their debut, but shares of Aerohive Networks (HIVE), which sells a cloud-based mobile networking platform, were down 5% in early afternoon trading in the stock market today. 2U offered 8 million shares at an opening price…

Investors had an unpleasant surprise for ServiceNow after the fast-growing enterprise software company released Q1 earnings late on April 23 that easily beat Wall Street expectations. The company also provided a stronger-than-expected outlook for the current quarter.Yet ServiceNow stock fell more than 6% on April 24, and fell the following two days as well.The investor reaction perplexed ServiceNow (NOW) CEO Frank Slootman, whose company is taking share from larger rivals including CA Technologies (CA) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) in IT service management software."I don't think in all my years of doing this kind of thing that have I ever seen anything remotely close to it," Slootman told IBD . "It all goes under the motto of 'no good deed goes unpunished.' Investor sentiment is in turmoil right now and it really has nothing to do with our business or our company."ServiceNow's results, with sales up 62% from the year-earlier quarter, were exceptional, says Matthew Hedberg, an analyst for RBC Capital Markets."They couldn't have done much more in the quarter," he said.But ServiceNow wasn't alone.Highflying software companies such as Tableau Software (DATA), Splunk (SPLK), Workday (WDAY) and Salesforce.com (CRM) have seen their stocks dive this year despite strong quarterly earnings and outlooks.Shares of ServiceNow were down 9% this year through Tuesday before rallying 16% the rest of the week. Salesforce's stock has declined 6%. Tableau, a fast grower in the data analytics market, is down 12% this year. Workday, a leader in the human capital management market, is down 3%. The Nasdaq composite index is up 3.5%.High ValuationsInvestors generally appear to be nervous about the high valuations in the sector — all of the above companies are in the red except Salesforce — rather than any specific fundamental issues, says Kirk Materne, an analyst for Evercore Partners. Also, the young software stocks tend to move up and down more greatly than older legacy software stocks, he points out."It's more of a general nervousness around some of the higher beta stocks and tech in general," he said.Older tech stalwarts such as Oracle (ORCL), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Microsoft (MSFT) and HP are up this year despite recent quarters with decelerating or declining sales and EPS.Investors are placing a higher premium on size and stability rather than fast growth — for now, says Karl Keirstead, an analyst for Deutsche Bank."You are seeing a growth-to-value rotation," he said. "What is hurting Workday is the flipside of what is helping Oracle."Splunk might the biggest victim among the highflier group.Splunk stock is down 37% this year, after falling 16% the day after its recent Q1 earnings soundly beat views.The magnitude of Splunk's sell-off is out of the company's hands, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald."It's the cycle of the stock, the stock is in a bad mood," White said. "There was really nothing in the (Q1) report that wasn't good. It was a very solid report."Splunk raised its revenue forecast for the year from $400 million to $402 million-$410 million. Analysts had modeled for $406.9 million, slightly above Splunk's midpoint.The company's forecast could be construed as light, but there likely are bigger forces at work, says J. Derrick Wood, an analyst for Susquehanna Financial Group."The shorts are winning over the longs right now," he said. "The issue there is a re-evaluation for these high-growth assets. Where that value should fall is what the market is trying to figure out."Prior to the sell-off, on Feb. 26 Tableau's stock reached an all-time high of 101.86 a share, or 13 times above the $476.2 million that analysts polled by Thomson Reuters project for 2015.Workday's peak price of 116.47 on Feb. 27 was roughly 19 times its expected revenue of $1.09 billion for its fiscal year ending on or near Jan. 31, 2016.Splunk's all-time high of 106.15, set on Feb. 28, was 29 times the $547.5 million revenue that analysts had projected for its fiscal year ending on or near Jan. 31, 2016.Those valuations have come down to earth. After Friday's close, Splunk's stock was trading near nine times revenue for its next fiscal year, with Workday at 13.5 times revenue and Tableau at eight times revenue.Over the past 15 years, "growth company" stocks have seen a mean average of eight times projected revenue, with anything near 20 among the highest, says Daniel Ives, an analyst for FBR Capital Markets.Those high valuations can make investors nervous, Ives says."Once they start to sell off, it starts to be like yelling 'fire' in a crowded theater," he said.Where Is The Sweet Spot?As Deutsche Bank's Keirstead puts it, investors in cloud software companies are still struggling to find prices they are comfortable with."You are seeing a re-evaluation of the growth software sector and that is why these stocks are struggling," Keirstead said.Legacy vendors, meanwhile, are up despite their own struggles.Oracle, Cisco and Microsoft are each up 11% this year, while HP is up 21%.All four companies are in various stages of some sort of reorganization or reprioritization, looking to recharge growth.Investors are attracted to these companies for varying reasons, Keirstead says."In the case of Oracle, their total revenue growth rate in the most recent reported quarter was actually the highest in three years," he said. "With HP, some people are enthusiastic about the pace at which they are cutting costs."

IBM last year passed on acquiring Rackspace Hosting and opted instead to acquire cloud-services provider SoftLayer, a deal analysts say is working out so well that IBM again is likely to take a pass on acquiring Rackspace. In May, Rackspace (RAX) said it hired Morgan Stanley to advise on a possible company sale or partnership. But IBM's  (IBM) $2…
THE BUZZ
Cloud computing has fundamentally changed the way companies build data centers and deliver software applications.
Arista Networks (ANET), a leading provider of cloud networking solutions, is tapping into this enthusiasm with an initial public offering scheduled to begin trading Friday.

Cloud-computing centers consist of thousands of servers and storage systems connected by optical-fiber lines, routers and switches that can rapidly distribute software apps and data across the Internet and wireless networks to smartphones, tablets, PCs and other systems.

Businesses large and small are rapidly moving to cloud computing. Amazon (AMZN), eBay (EBAY), Facebook (FB), Google (GOOGL), Yahoo (YHOO) and Microsoft (MSFT) pioneered the development of large-scale cloud-data centers in order to meet the growing demands of customers.

"We believe that cloud computing represents a fundamental shift from traditional legacy data centers and that cloud networking is the fastest-growing segment within the data-center switching market," Arista Networks said in its IPO prospectus.
Arista plans to raise $200 million by offering 5.3 million shares at a price range of 36 to 40, giving it a market valuation near $2.7 billion. It will trade on the NYSE with the ticker ANET.
THE COMPANY

Arista Networks manages data traffic at large Internet centers for companies such as Facebook, Yahoo and Comcast (CMCSA). Its technology was initially embraced for high-frequency stock-trading environments, where fast data handling is vital. Then its use was expanded to elsewhere in the financial industry.

Arista's core product consists of a line of ethernet switching modules used to connect servers, storage devices and other components. At the core of its cloud networking platform is Arista's Extensible Operating System, or EOS. The software operating system manages all aspects of the network and enables customers to integrate a wide range of applications and other customized features quickly.
"We believe that our networking technology represents a fundamental advance in networking software," the company said.

Arista has developed strategic relationships with a number of "technology ecosystem participants," including Microsoft, Aruba Networks (ARUN), F5 Networks (FFIV), Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Splunk (SPLK) and VMware (VMW) "to allow integration of our cloud networking solutions with their offerings."

Arista competes in the data-center market for ethernet switches that run at per-second speeds from 10 gigabits to 100 gigabits. According to Crehan Research, this market will grow from approximately $6 billion in 2013 to $12 billion in 2017, a 19% compound annual growth rate.

"Arista is a disruptive player in data centers," said Evercore analyst Mark McKechnie. "Arista Networks started with a clean sheet of paper and is clearly disrupting Cisco's (CSCO) incumbent market position in data-center switches."

Arista has 850 full-time employees and more than 2,500 customers, up from 570 at the end of 2010. Customers span a range of industries and include Internet service providers, financial services organizations, government agencies and media and entertainment companies. They include big cloud-service providers such as eBay, Facebook, Microsoft and Yahoo, as well as financial services organizations such as Barclays, Citigroup (C) and Morgan Stanley (MS). One of Arista's largest customers is Microsoft, which accounted for 22% of revenue in 2013.
RISK/CHALLENGES

The market for data-center technology is intensely competitive. Arista's rivals include Juniper Networks (JNPR), Brocade Communications Systems (BRCD), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Cisco Systems. Cisco is the dominant player in the data-switching category, with a market share above 60%.
"Arista found an opportunity to break into Cisco's front yard, but Cisco has them in their sights," McKechnie said.

Arista has a relatively short business history. Its first products shipped in 2008, though most of its revenue growth has occurred since early 2010. The company's 10 largest customers in 2013 accounted for 43% of revenue, up from 39% in 2012.
THE RESULTS

Arista's revenue comes primarily from sales of switching products and software, in addition to its services revenue. Arista revenue rose 87% to $361 million in 2013 from the same period a year earlier. The company reported net income of $42.5 million, up from $21.3 million. For the three-month period ended March 31, Arista reported revenue of $117.2 million, up 91% from the year-earlier period, and net income of $12.3 million. Not including proceeds from the IPO, Arista reports having cash and equivalents of $129.5 million.

"The financials look solid for this company, as they have been profitable in the three years leading up to this stock offering — a rarity for tech companies in this day of IPOs," said research firm IPOboutique in a report.
USE OF PROCEEDS

Arista Networks plans to raise $200 million by offering 5.3 million shares at a price range of 36 to 40. The company estimates that net proceeds form the offering will be approximately $182.4 million, or about $210.6 million if the underwriters exercise their over-allotment option in full at an assumed IPO price of 38 per share. It intends to use approximately $23.6 million of the net proceeds to pay down debt and the remaining proceeds for general corporate purposes, including working capital, sales and marketing activities, and product development.
THE MANAGEMENT
Jayshree Ullal
President, chief executive officer

Ullal, 53, served in various management positions at Cisco Systems from 1993 to May 2008. She has also held various positions at Advanced Micro Devices and Fairchild Semiconductor. She holds a B.S. in electrical engineering from San Francisco State University and an M.S. in engineering management from Santa Clara University.
Andy Bechtolsheim
Founder, chief development officer

Bechtolsheim, 58, has served as chairman since 2004 and as Arista's chief development officer since 2009. In 1982, Bechtolsheim co-founded Sun Microsystems. From April 2004 to October 2008, he served as Sun's senior vice president and chief systems architect. He attended the University of Technology Munich and holds an M.S. in computer engineering from Carnegie Mellon University. He was also a doctoral student in electrical engineering and computer science at Stanford University from 1977 to 1982.
Kenneth Duda
Founder, chief technology officer

Duda, 42, has served in various roles at Arista since 2004. He holds B.S. and M.S. degrees in computer science and electrical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a Ph.D. in computer science from Stanford University.
Arista Networks
Santa Clara, Calif.
Arista.com
Lead underwriters:
Morgan Stanley, Citigroup
Offering price: 36 to 40
Expected date: June 6

Ticker: ANETCloud computing has fundamentally changed the way companies build data centers and deliver software applications.Arista Networks (ANET), a leading provider of cloud networking solutions, is tapping into this enthusiasm with an initial public offering scheduled to begin trading Friday.Cloud-computing centers consist of thousands of servers and storage systems connected by optical-fiber lines, routers and switches that can rapidly distribute software apps and data across the Internet and wireless networks to smartphones, tablets, PCs and other systems.Businesses large and small are rapidly moving to cloud computing. Amazon (AMZN), eBay (EBAY), Facebook (FB), Google (GOOGL), Yahoo (YHOO) and Microsoft (MSFT) pioneered the development of large-scale cloud-data centers in order to meet the growing demands of customers."We believe that cloud computing represents a fundamental shift from traditional legacy data centers and that cloud networking is the fastest-growing segment within the data-center switching market," Arista Networks said in its IPO prospectus.Arista plans to raise $200 million by offering 5.3 million shares at a price range of 36 to 40, giving it a market valuation near $2.7 billion. It will trade on the NYSE with the ticker ANET.THE COMPANYArista Networks manages data traffic at large Internet centers for companies such as Facebook, Yahoo and Comcast (CMCSA). Its technology was initially embraced for high-frequency stock-trading environments, where fast data handling is vital. Then its use was expanded to elsewhere in the financial industry.Arista's core product consists of a line of ethernet switching modules used to connect servers, storage devices and other components. At the core of its cloud networking platform is Arista's Extensible Operating System, or EOS. The software operating system manages all aspects of the network and enables customers to integrate a wide range of applications and other customized features quickly."We believe that our networking technology represents a fundamental advance in networking software," the company said.Arista has developed strategic relationships with a number of "technology ecosystem participants," including Microsoft, Aruba Networks (ARUN), F5 Networks (FFIV), Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Splunk (SPLK) and VMware (VMW) "to allow integration of our cloud networking solutions with their offerings."Arista competes in the data-center market for ethernet switches that run at per-second speeds from 10 gigabits to 100 gigabits. According to Crehan Research, this market will grow from approximately $6 billion in 2013 to $12 billion in 2017, a 19% compound annual growth rate."Arista is a disruptive player in data centers," said Evercore analyst Mark McKechnie. ServiceNow (NOW) is a disruptive force in the market and is taking market share, says RBC Capital Markets analyst Matthew Hedberg, who initiated coverage of the cloud software maker on Monday with an outperform rating.

In a research report, Hedberg said he's "bullish on the company's ability to take share" in the information technology services management market. He said ServiceNow could become the platform customers and partners use to write custom software-as-as-service applications.

Hedberg said ServiceNow is gaining share as legacy vendors such as Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and BMC Software are losing share. He pointed out that ServiceNow added 122 new customers in Q3, to more than 1,900, up from 1,346 in the year-earlier quarter.

ServiceNow's software automates IT processes, aiming to improve service relationships between vendors and customers and helping companies get a better handle on the increasing requests they are getting from many departments and employees using many different types of devices.

ServiceNow stock was up a fraction in morning trading in the stock market today, near 59.50. Earlier Monday, the stock touched 59.82, good enough to give the stock a record high for the fourth straight trading day. Hedberg set a price target of 70.

The company, which remains unprofitable, is slated to release Q4 results after the market close Jan. 29. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect a per-share loss minus items of a penny, the same as in the year-earlier quarter.

Hewlett-Packard is on the hunt.The computer product and service giant is looking to reaccelerate growth in part by acquiring cloud, mobile, Big Data and security firms. Analysts, though, don't expect any overnight miracles.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) CEO Meg Whitman listed all of the above target areas during a Feb. 20 conference call with analysts to discuss its fiscal Q2 earnings.All are sectors where HP is playing catch-up, says Bill Kreher, an analyst for Edward Jones."Meg basically gave you a laundry list of all of the buzzwords in tech right now, and Hewlett-Packard will certainly have to make meaningful acquisitions in order to have a presence in those growing markets," Kreher told IBD.HP's acquisition push into newer areas looks to offset generally declining sales in its core PC and printing units.Those two businesses combined represent half HP's total revenue, so their decline has led to 10 straight quarters of year-over-year drops in overall revenue.HP has little choice but to try to buy into those fastest-growing technology segments, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald. "They are absolutely right to do it," he told IBD. "They don't have the products, but a lot of guys have good stuff already, like IBM (IBM), (which) has a phenomenal Big Data analytics platform."Whitman says HP expects to have free cash flow, or cash profit, of $6.5 billion at the close of its fiscal 2014 ending Oct. 31.$3.5 Billion For AcquisitionsShebly Seyrafi, an analyst for FBN Securities, says the figure could be closer to $7 billion, which he says leaves $3.5 billion for mergers and acquisitions and half for dividends and share repurchases."The way to think about logical candidates for HP are companies that have $3.5 billion or less of a market cap and are in the security, mobility, Big Data or cloud areas," he told IBD.He says security candidates include Fortinet (FTNT), Proofpoint (PFPT), Imperva (IMPV), Aruba Networks (ARUN) and Ruckus Wireless (RKUS).Tibco Software (TIBX), with its market cap of $3.6 billion, could also be a candidate. The company makes middleware and infrastructure software. But Seyrafi says Teradata (TDC), a data analytics and management company, would likely be too expensive with its $7.5 billion market cap.The values of some takeover candidates have risen on speculation that Cisco Systems (CSCO) and IBM (IBM), in addition to HP, will likely step up their M&A activity, Kreher said. "All of these large conglomerates are looking at the same companies, which is pushing market values higher," he said.HP's stock, meanwhile, has generally been rising since touching a 10-year low in November 2012, as investors bet Whitman can forge a turnaround. HP stock is trading near a 30-month high of 32.41 that it touched on Thursday.But HP's recent acquisitions have been hit and miss.Its biggest blunder might be Autonomy, a U.K.-based search software maker that HP acquired for $10.3 billion in 2011.In 2012 HP took an $8.8 billion write-down on the deal, while charging its former managers with fraud.HP has seemingly fared better with Vertica, a data analytics software company it acquired for an undisclosed sum in 2011.Though HP's software revenue fell 3.7% in its Q1 ended Jan. 31 vs. the year-earlier period, HP CFO Cathie Lesjak noted in the company's earnings conference call last month that Vertica and security "gained traction" in the company's Big Data business.HP has also received favorable reviews for its acquisition of 3Par, a maker of systems and software for data storage and information management. It acquired 3Par for $2.35 billion in 2010.Buying 3Par let HP offer converged storage architecture to handle growing customer demand for cloud and virtualized applications, says Crawford Del Prete, an analyst for market tracker IDC."HP had a problem; they had this virtualized application product that was old and needed to be refreshed, and they didn't have the IT to do it, so buying 3Par was superimportant because it allowed them to improve their product line significantly," he said. "3Par is a huge part of reaccelerating the revenue growth."But HP's acquisition strategy is likely more about preparing for the long haul than a quick fix for its declining revenue, Seyrafi says."They are a very big company, so a $3.5 billion market cap security company is not going to swing the needle that much," he said.Today's acquisitions could make all the difference for whether HP succeeds or fails several years from now, says White.Acquisitions today "are not going to matter in the near term," he said. "It's more of 'Let's build the pieces (now) so that in five years we are not totally irrelevant.'"

Hewlett-Packard showed some muscle in the fledgling Network Functions Virtualization market by beating Cisco Systems, VMware and others in signing telecom carrier Telefonica to a multiyear pact.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) is one of several tech giants scrambling to offer NFV, a virtualization computing system that relies more on software than hardware to help service providers speed an increasing amount of data through their networks at a reduced cost.Besides Cisco Systems (CSCO) and VMware (VMW), other NFV providers include Juniper Networks (JNPR).HP will fuel Telefonica's Unica project. Telefonica is moving all of its services, including Internet and mobile, to a new platform driven by NFV and software-defined networking, another technology system where software presides over hardware. The project will take several years.Spain-based Telefonica (TEF) is a large telecom operating in 21 countries, mostly in Europe and Latin America.HP is stepping up its NFV efforts, launched only last year, as the company gets closer to splitting into two separate companies. One will focus on PCs and printers, the other on enterprise products and services.Signing Telefonica should boost HP's revenue and set a bar for rivals in the NFV market, says Crawford Del Prete, an analyst for market tracker IDC."It's a nice win in advance of the split," Del Prete told IBD. "Carriers are going to be moving more toward these network functions and virtualization environments. This is a big industry shift that is going to be measured in billions."UBS on Tuesday upgraded HP to buy from neutral and hiked its 12-month price target to 40 from 37.25. HP stock is trading near 33. In a research report, UBS analyst Steve Milunovich said, "(HP Enterprise is) too hardware-dependent but improving. Software and services need to pick up, or HP Enterprise might be forced to merge with another larger computing vendor."With the Telefonica contract, HP has seemingly leapfrogged rivals in what looks to be a very large market, says Roz Roseboro, an analyst for Heavy Reading, a market research firm that focuses solely on the telecom market."From an endorsement standpoint, it's very big," she told IBD. "The market right now is very much up in the air in terms of who is going to end up in the lead position with all of this NFV transformation."HP provides NFV services for several customers, but Telefonica is a milestone for the company, says Saar Gillai, general manager of HP's NFV program."This is our biggest deal in terms of providing end-to-end capabilities across our entire portfolio with open NFV," he told IBD.Not all of HP's rivals can handle such a large NFV migration, Gillai says."We are uniquely positioned in this space because a lot of the traditional vendors are playing defense — they have a lot of existing systems that are in the old architecture, and they are not necessarily that motivated to get the new architecture that quickly," he said.Other vendors, such as Cisco, are stepping up their efforts in the NFV and SDN markets, said Amitabh Passi, an analyst for UBS Securities, in a March 2 research report."Unlike years past, Cisco is more openly embracing shifts to software defined networking and Network Functions Virtualization, and in fact accelerating the shift to software and cloud services," he wrote.Several other telecom carriers, including AT&T (T) and Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), are in the process of adopting NFV.Reducing costs and streamlining networks are top priorities, says Roseboro."They are moving from a world where you have lots of different boxes that are specialized to do one thing and moving all of that onto more commodity servers, which allows you to lower your capex," she said. "And once it's virtualized, you can start using some other kind of IT tools to automate a lot of your processes and reduce your opex quite significantly."Gillai declined to put a value on the Telefonica contract."I can say that it's meaningful revenue, and it's also an indicator of things to come," he said.HP's revenue needs a boost. In the quarter ended Jan. 31, its enterprise revenue was flat with the year-earlier quarter, at $6.98 billion. And its enterprise services revenue fell 11% to $4.99 billion.

Hewlett-Packard is taking aim at Cisco Systems with its bid to buy Aruba Networks, but HP might not be done making acquisitions before its split-up, analysts say.

The struggling computer maker early Monday confirmed plans to acquire Aruba for $24.67 a share, or about $3 billion. The deal, which both boards have approved, is expected to close in the second half of HP's fiscal year, ending Oct. 31.
Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) stock rose a fraction Monday. Aruba stock jumped 35% last week as reports of the pending deal surfaced.
Among wireless networking equipment vendors, Aruba is No. 2 to Cisco (CSCO), the No. 1 maker of computer networking equipment.
HP is also in the Wi-Fi market, but is far behind Cisco or Aruba.
Acquiring Aruba will change that, says Crawford Del Prete, an analyst for market tracker IDC.
"This definitely moves them to be competing more with Cisco than any other (Wi-Fi) networking supplier today," Del Prete told IBD.
HP aims to boost its networking business, Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald, said in a research report Monday.

"Given HP's bigger push into the networking market over the past few years that included the acquisition of 3Com in 2010, we believe the planned acquisition of Aruba Networks complements HP's existing networking portfolio," he wrote.

As of Sept. 30, Aruba had an 11.5% share of the wireless local area network gear market, IDC says. Aruba trailed only Cisco's commanding 48.4% share. HP was No. 4 at a 5.8% share. Ruckus Wireless (RKUS) ranked No. 3 at 6.3%, says IDC.
Analysts say Aruba will bolster HP's enterprise group business, which reported revenue of $6.98 billion for its fiscal Q1 ended Jan. 31, flat vs. the year-earlier period.
Before year's end, HP plans to split into two separate companies, one focused on the PC and printer businesses and the other on its enterprise and software businesses.

The company is also working through a five-year restructuring plan launched in May 2012 that involves building up emerging growth areas, including mobile, security and the cloud, to offset little or no growth in PCs and printers.
"They need to be able to show they have the IT assets to keep the enterprise group growing," Del Prete said.
White, however, says HP can choose better targets.
"Although we believe this deal expands HP's networking portfolio, we believe HP's capital would be better spent on cloud and Big Data software vendors," he wrote.
Enterprise software companies will likely be HP's next targets, Del Prete says. In Q1, HP's software sales fell nearly 5% year over year.

"They are not moving fast enough in software," he said. "They need to continue to build out that portfolio, particularly around information management, security and Big Data — and it's just not there yet."Hewlett-Packard is taking aim at Cisco Systems with its bid to buy Aruba Networks, but HP might not be done making acquisitions before its split-up, analysts say.The struggling computer maker early Monday confirmed plans to acquire Aruba for $24.67 a share, or about $3 billion. The deal, which both boards have approved, is expected to close in the second half of HP's fiscal year, ending Oct. 31.Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) stock rose a fraction Monday. Aruba stock jumped 35% last week as reports of the pending deal surfaced.Among wireless networking equipment vendors, Aruba is No. 2 to Cisco (CSCO), the No. 1 maker of computer networking equipment.HP is also in the Wi-Fi market, but is far behind Cisco or Aruba.Acquiring Aruba will change that, says Crawford Del Prete, an analyst for market tracker IDC."This definitely moves them to be competing more with Cisco than any other (Wi-Fi) networking supplier today," Del Prete told IBD.HP aims to boost its networking business, Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald, said in a research report Monday."Given HP's bigger push into the networking market over the past few years that included the acquisition of 3Com in 2010, we believe the planned acquisition of Aruba Networks complements HP's existing networking portfolio," he wrote.As of Sept. 30, Aruba had an 11.5% share of the wireless local area network gear market, IDC says. Aruba trailed only Cisco's commanding 48.4% share. HP was No. 4 at a 5.8% share. Ruckus Wireless (RKUS) ranked No. 3 at 6.3%, says IDC.Analysts say Aruba will bolster HP's enterprise group business, which reported revenue of $6.98 billion for its fiscal Q1 ended Jan. 31, flat vs. the year-earlier period.Before year's end, HP plans to split into two separate companies, one focused on the PC and printer businesses and the other on its enterprise and software businesses.The company is also working through a five-year restructuring plan launched in May 2012 that involves building up emerging growth areas, including mobile, security and the cloud, to offset little or no growth in PCs and printers."They need to be able to show they have the IT assets to keep the enterprise group growing," Del Prete said.White, however, says HP can choose better targets."Although we believe this deal expands HP's networking portfolio, we believe HP's capital would be better spent on cloud and Big Data software vendors," he wrote.Enterprise software companies will likely be HP's next targets, Del Prete says. In Q1, HP's software sales fell nearly 5% year over year."They are not moving fast enough in software," he said. "They need to continue to build out that portfolio, particularly around information management, security and Big Data — and it's just not there yet."

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) likely will do little more than meet expectations when it reports its fiscal Q1 earnings after the market close Tuesday, as the company continues to work through restructuring plan and gets closer to cleaving itself into two separate companies by year's end.

HP is struggling to reaccelerate its revenue growth, which has mostly been in decline since July 2011. The company is scrambling to move into emerging growth areas including the cloud, Big Data and security to offset slowing or declining growth in other areas including printing and enterprise services.

The company is planning to split into two separate companies, with HP Inc. managing its PC and printing businesses and HP Enterprise consisting of its server, storage, networking, converged systems, cloud, software and financial services units.
HP is kind of in a holding pattern until it can regain some footing and show some traction in emerging growth segments, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald. He rates HP stock a hold.
"There are not a lot of drivers underneath their business, underneath the portfolio, that can really drive strong growth," he told IBD.

Foreign exchange issues that have plagued other tech companies. They include HP rival IBM (IBM), which last month gave weak guidance that sent its stock falling. Currency also poses a problem for HP, White says.
"The currency foreign exchange has been a big headwind," he said. "I think that will clearly have an impact on HP."

For the quarter ended on or near Jan. 31, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect earnings per share minus items of 91 cents, up 1.11% from the year-earlier period. Revenue is expected to decline 2.94% to $27.35 billion.
For the current quarter, analysts expect EPS of 96 cents, up 9%, and revenue of $26.81 billion, down 1.81%.

In a research report Wednesday, Steven Milunovich, an analyst for UBS Securities, said he expects some upside from HP's printing segment but says other areas including PCs and enterprise services will be challenged. He rates HP stock neutral.

"Printing, which is about 40% of profit, should be in line to better than expected, with the weak yen bolstering margins and improved channel inventory presaging lesser supplies declines," he wrote. "The company has anticipated a return to flat PC results, but post fiscal Q1 there is risk based on reports from Taiwan and the upcoming separation. We are expecting the enterprise group to be down 3%, enterprise services down 7% and software flat, for a total enterprise decline of 4%."
HP stock is down about 5% this year after rising 43% last year.

Investors appear to be waiting for HP to show revenue growth or some new product segments that have growth potential, White says. For now, he said, the company is "at a crossroads."Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) likely will do little more than meet expectations when it reports its fiscal Q1 earnings after the market close Tuesday, as the company continues to work through restructuring plan and gets closer to cleaving itself into two separate companies by year's end.HP is struggling to reaccelerate its revenue growth, which has mostly been in decline since July 2011. The company is scrambling to move into emerging growth areas including the cloud, Big Data and security to offset slowing or declining growth in other areas including printing and enterprise services.The company is planning to split into two separate companies, with HP Inc. managing its PC and printing businesses and HP Enterprise consisting of its server, storage, networking, converged systems, cloud, software and financial services units.HP is kind of in a holding pattern until it can regain some footing and show some traction in emerging growth segments, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald. He rates HP stock a hold."There are not a lot of drivers underneath their business, underneath the portfolio, that can really drive strong growth," he told IBD.Foreign exchange issues that have plagued other tech companies. They include HP rival IBM (IBM), which last month gave weak guidance that sent its stock falling. Currency also poses a problem for HP, White says."The currency foreign exchange has been a big headwind," he said. "I think that will clearly have an impact on HP."For the quarter ended on or near Jan. 31, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect earnings per share minus items of 91 cents, up 1.11% from the year-earlier period. Revenue is expected to decline 2.94% to $27.35 billion.For the current quarter, analysts expect EPS of 96 cents, up 9%, and revenue of $26.81 billion, down 1.81%.In a research report Wednesday, Steven Milunovich, an analyst for UBS Securities, said he expects some upside from HP's printing segment but says other areas including PCs and enterprise services will be challenged. He rates HP stock neutral."Printing, which is about 40% of profit, should be in line to better than expected, with the weak yen bolstering margins and improved channel inventory presaging lesser supplies declines," he wrote. "The company has anticipated a return to flat PC results, but post fiscal Q1 there is risk based on reports from Taiwan and the upcoming separation. We are expecting the enterprise group to be down 3%, enterprise services down 7% and software flat, for a total enterprise decline of 4%."HP stock is down about 5% this year after rising 43% last year.Investors appear to be waiting for HP to show revenue growth or some new product segments that have growth potential, White says. For now, he said, the company is "at a crossroads."

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) is buying a bigger piece of the growing mobile market. The computer products and services company on Monday announced an agreement to acquire Aruba Networks (ARUN), a leading provider of network access products for the mobile enterprise for $24.67 a share in cash, or about $3 billion. The deal net of cash and debt is worth about $2.7…

Aruba Networks (ARUN) stock rose Friday after the gear maker late Thursday had no comment on Hewlett-Packard takeover speculation in reporting a fiscal Q2 beat but light guidance. Federal government sales helped Q2 earnings and revenue beat Wall Street expectations, but its current-quarter outlook fell short on weaker spending in the education market. Still, many analysts say an HP-Aruba merger…
The Computer Networking group is home to some dynamic new issues and is on the rise, ranked 40th Tuesday, up from 51st six weeks ago.
The group is anchored by Cisco Systems (CSCO), with a market cap of more than $150 billion.
The network gear king's shares have heated up recently, gapping to a multiyear high Feb. 12 in response to fiscal first-quarter earnings results.
Earnings and revenue climbed at the strongest quarterly pace in at least two years.
Cisco will face stepped-up competition from computer giant Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) after its bid to acquire Aruba Networks (ARUN), the No. 2 maker of wireless network equipment makers.

It also competes with smaller recent IPOs Ruckus Wireless (RKUS) and Arista Networks (ANET), both of which delivered explosive earnings and sales growth in 2014. Their stocks remain well off 52-week highs after recent slides, but may be starting to turn around.

Arista, which makes high-speed switching equipment, has seen fund sponsorship soar to 161 funds in Q4 from just 99 in Q3. It debuted in June 2014 and is starting to climb the right side of a deep base.

Elsewhere in the group, Sierra Wireless (SWIR) has reported three straight quarters of triple-digit earnings growth. The stock may be shaping a new base but is still below its 10-week moving average. It corrected a fairly deep 36%, and will need more time to shape the right side of the pattern.

Israeli networking firm Radware (RDWR) is working on a new cup base, but the pattern has a lopsided shape caused by a 16% drop in the week ended Jan. 30. Stocks reversed higher at the closing bell Monday, ending a four-session skid despite another rout in China's stock market and a further drop in oil prices.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.3% and the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%, while the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today rose 10% on the Nasdaq and 6% on the NYSE compared with Friday, according to preliminary data.
Energy, mining and biotech stocks lagged, while department store, hospital and tobacco stocks led the upside.
Aluminum producer Alcoa (AA) rose after hours following its Q4 earnings report. The stock ended the regular session down nearly 1%, declining for the eighth straight session.

Macy's (M) led the S&P 500, rising 8% in strong volume after investment advisory firm Starboard Value reportedly said Monday it supports the department store's recent joint ventures for its mall-based and real estate properties. Other department store stocks also rallied, with Kohl's (KSS) rising 5% and Dillard's (DDS) 2%.

On a sour note, IBD 50 stock Celgene (CELG) dropped nearly 6% to its lowest level in over four months. The biotech offered 2016 guidance and named COO Mark Alles as its new CEO starting March 1. Current chief Bob Hugin will become executive chairman.
Companies due to report quarterly results Tuesday include CSX (CSX) and IHS (IHS).

Workflow management entails lots of little details, from setting up a new employee with a computer and password to handling questions about health benefits and vacation time.
And that's just a starter list.
ServiceNow (NOW) has become one of the fastest-growing companies in technology by automating key activities, tasks and processes that make up day-to-day work life.
The firm says that its cloud-based software service management model can replace emails, interoffice phone calls and spreadsheets to "change the way people work."
"In our personal lives, we have all of these apps that can help get and manage information and customize what we need and want. Think of this as an app for your work," said a ServiceNow spokeswoman.
A growing number of customers want in on ServiceNow's workflow cloud solutions. Since the company went public in 2012, revenue has grown at a compounded annual rate of 75%.
A Billion-Dollar Year?
In 2014, revenue jumped 61% to $682.6 million. Management expects revenue of $960 million to $1 billion this year, an increase of 41% to 47% over 2014.
"Very few companies are growing 40%-plus on a $1 billion revenue base," said Kirk Materne, an analyst with Evercore ISI.

Most of its revenue is subscription-based. ServiceNow doesn't record all revenue upfront but over the billing cycle of a contract, which is typically one or three years. But it recognizes expenses upfront. That and the revenue lag creates a "mismatch," says Rob Owens, analyst with Pacific Crest Securities.
Earnings, he said, are a "lagging indicator," while cash flow and billings are more "leading indicators."
Backlog and deferred revenue combined at year end totaled $1.4 billion, up 57% from the prior year.
The company has seen 50%-plus growth in billings for some time, says Owens. "But cash flow is just starting to move from negative to positive, as is earnings," he said.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters anticipate that ServiceNow will log its first annual profit in four years this year: 21 cents per share, up from a 7-cent loss in 2014. They expect earnings to more than double next year, to 50 cents.
"You're starting to see leverage as they get bigger," Materne said.
Since last spring, investors seem to have looked past the lack of profits to future gains, sending shares up 75% from a low of 44.17 on April 28.
ServiceNow, which was founded in 2004, targeted IT departments initially. But it's been expanding its reach to areas such as human resources, legal, facilities management and marketing.

"They're seeing end customers develop apps within the ServiceNow platform," Owens said. "It's a very compelling solution that is displacing a lot of traditional legacy capabilities," including help desks.
Customers Try Unique Apps

For example, one state's department of wildlife created a custom app on ServiceNow to keep track of endangered animals. A fashion retailer set up an app on ServiceNow to enable store managers to report security incidents such as shoplifting, broken windows and threats.
"ServiceNow is moving from just being an IT service to becoming a platform provider," Materne said, adding that it's also been building specific apps to run on its platform.
ServiceNow plans to open an online app store for customers, though no date as yet been set. Materne likens it to Salesforce.com 's (CRM) AppExchange.

"Some part of it will compete with Salesforce, but ServiceNow's core constituent is the IT market, and Salesforce.com's is marketing," Materne said. "They both have tremendous opportunities in front of them. I don't view them as mutually exclusive."

Salesforce.com was first set up as a customer relationship management database for salespeople but has moved "more broadly across the organization," Owens said. He says that ServiceNow is deploying a similar "land and expand" strategy.

ServiceNow also has "modest overlap" with cloud player Workday (WDAY), which is focused on human resources, or the so-called "human-capital market," Materne says. He adds that Workday competes more directly with Oracle (ORCL) and SAP (SAP) .

"There are more opportunities to partner with Workday than to compete," he said. "They can help each other sell and grow their customer bases. They're both the disrupters in the broader enterprise software world."

Materne says that ServiceNow has "significant mind-share lead over legacy competitors" such as BMC Software (BMC), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and CA Technologies (CA), who are "trying to catch up but all have their own issues."
More than 25% of ServiceNow's new customers are part of the "Global 2000," the world's largest companies, according to management.

Its customers range from bagel eatery chain Einstein Noah Restaurant Group to global biopharmaceutical firm AstraZeneca (AZN). Others are Standard Life, Flextronics (FLEX) and Vitamix, among many others.
Customer Count Rises

In the fourth quarter, ServiceNow added 211 net new customers for a total of 2,725 worldwide. Newcomers included satellite broadcaster Dish Network (DISH), financial services firm Fiserv (FISV) and Cars.com.
The renewal rate among ServiceNow's existing customers in the quarter was 97%.
"It's the only IT provider that's delivering enterprise service management solutions on a global scale," said Materne. "It has a fairly nice defensible position."
The big question, he says, is whether new rivals will pose a threat.

He doesn't see "hot private companies" emerging anytime soon with the kind of capital needed to compete on a global scale.Workflow management entails lots of little details, from setting up a new employee with a computer and password to handling questions about health benefits and vacation time.And that's just a starter list.ServiceNow (NOW) has become one of the fastest-growing companies in technology by automating key activities, tasks and processes that make up day-to-day work life.The firm says that its cloud-based software service management model can replace emails, interoffice phone calls and spreadsheets to "change the way people work.""In our personal lives, we have all of these apps that can help get and manage information and customize what we need and want. New Relic (NEWR) gained more traction than expected among large customers last quarter, as wider adoption of its services sparked better-than-expected guidance for the current quarter. New Relic's positive outlook prompted at least two analysts to raise their price targets on the stock on Friday. The company late Thursday also posted better-than-expected earnings and revenue for its fiscal Q3 ended…

Cisco Systems (CSCO) appears to be back on track after the No. 1 computer networking equipment maker late Wednesday reported what it called its best across-the-board results in three years, beating estimates.
The company's outlook for the current quarter was mostly in line.

Analysts cheered. At least six investment banks raised their price targets on Cisco stock, which was up nearly 8% in morning trading in the stock market today, near 29, its highest point since December 2007.

Wunderlich Securities bumped its price target to 29 from 28 while maintaining its hold rating. Oppenheimer increased its price target to 30 from 29 and kept its outperform rating. RBC Capital Markets hiked its price target to 31 from 29, and also kept its outperform rating. Sterne, Agee & Leach upped its price target to 31 a share from 28. It has a buy rating on the company. FBN Securities increased its price target to 35 from 30. It has an outperform rating on the company. S&P Capital IQ increased its rating to a buy from a hold and hiked its price target to 34 from 27.

Cisco is hitting on almost all cylinders after posting year-over-year revenue growth in nearly every product category, Jason Ader, an analyst for William Blair & Co., said in a research report late Wednesday. He rates Cisco stock outperform.

"Cisco saw the best balance in its business in 12 quarters, with virtually all regions, verticals and product lines showing growth," he wrote. "While Cisco clearly benefitted from easy comparisons across its business and several major product cycles, we nonetheless walked away with increased confidence in the company's business momentum, growth prospects and strategic positioning."
Alex Kurtz, an analyst for Sterne Agee, says improvement in offshore markets are one of the upsides from the quarter.

"The biggest takeaway that should drive incremental support in the stock near term is the improving tone on emerging markets (India plus 11%, Mexico plus 21%) along with U.S. commercial strength up 12% against a relatively tough comp (total Americas up 7% along with EMEA up 7%)," he wrote in a report.
Cisco appears on track to making its transition to becoming an all-purpose IT service company, Kurtz says.

"Services in higher growth segments like cloud, analytics and security all grew double digits as well, suggesting Cisco is slowly becoming a more strategic vendor (relative to traditional data center companies like IBM (IBM) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ)," he wrote.

Last month, Cisco attempted to shed light on corporate security concerns with the results of a new survey.Cisco Systems (CSCO) appears to be back on track after the No. 1 computer networking equipment maker late Wednesday reported what it called its best across-the-board results in three years, beating estimates.The company's outlook for the current quarter was mostly in line.Analysts cheered. New Relic (NEWR) hopes to show it's starting to challenge larger incumbent vendors such as CA Technologies and Hewlett-Packard in the application performance management market when it reports its fiscal Q3 earnings after the market close Thursday.
The earnings report will be the company's first since it made its initial public offering on Dec. 12.
New Relic stock jumped 48% on its first day of trading, to 34, and it peaked above 37 on Jan. 5.
New Relic was down more than 1% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 34.
New Relic's APM software lets companies monitor the performance of their software apps and related areas, including server applications and browser applications.
The company is one of four recent tech IPOs looking to cash in on the growing cloud and Big Data markets.
New Relic, after focusing on smaller companies, is starting to target enterprise customers, where it will face much larger rivals CA Technologies (CA), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), IBM (IBM) and Dell.
New Relic already is making an impact, Michael Turits, an analyst for Raymond James & Associates, said in a research report last month. He has an outperform rating on New Relic stock.

"New Relic is a disruptive software-as-service (SaaS) vendor taking share from legacy incumbents in APM and pioneering software analytics — using application data for IT operations management (ITOM) and business analytics," he wrote. "We see strong demand drivers in an increasingly software-defined IT environment and the need to leverage application Big Data for IT and business intelligence."
For the quarter ended Dec. 31, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect a loss per share minus items of 37 cents vs. a loss per share of 25 cents in the year-earlier period.
Revenue is expected to rise 52% to $26.1 million.
For the current quarter, analysts expect a loss per share of 27 cents vs. a loss per share of 21 cents.
Revenue is expected to rise 42% to $28.2 million.
Turits says New Relic's move to larger customers will accelerate profit growth.

"We expect a steady path to profitability as the installed base shifts toward higher-value enterprise customers," he wrote.New Relic (NEWR) hopes to show it's starting to challenge larger incumbent vendors such as CA Technologies and Hewlett-Packard in the application performance management market when it reports its fiscal Q3 earnings after the market close Thursday.The earnings report will be the company's first since it made its initial public offering on Dec. 12.New Relic stock jumped 48% on its first day of trading, to 34, and it peaked above 37 on Jan. 5.New Relic was down more than 1% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 34.New Relic's APM software lets companies monitor the performance of their software apps and related areas, including server applications and browser applications.The company is one of four recent tech IPOs looking to cash in on the growing cloud and Big Data markets.New Relic, after focusing on smaller companies, is starting to target enterprise customers, where it will face much larger rivals CA Technologies (CA), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), IBM (IBM) and Dell.New Relic already is making an impact, Michael Turits, an analyst for Raymond James & Associates, said in a research report last month. Many leaders making the Stock Spotlight are well-known names that have received extensive coverage but are overextended for the time being. But two newer stocks in the screen are showing similar strong price action and making quite a splash. Keep in mind that younger companies often make their biggest runs during the first 10 years after they go public.

Luxoft Holding (LXFT), a custom software developer for the auto, financial, technology and travel industries, held its initial public offering on June 26, 2013. The company, which was founded in 2000, is incorporated in the British Virgin Islands and headquartered in Switzerland. It serves big-name clients including Boeing (BA), Harman International (HAR), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and IBM (IBM).

On Tuesday, Luxoft said it's developing the Human-Machine Interface for Swiss carmaker Rinspeed's self-driving vehicle concept, Budii, which can learn a driver's habits and preferences. Other projects include an interactive guide for Ford's (F) car infotainment system and a loan origination system for Deutsche Bank (DB).
Last month it bought Excelian, a private U.K. systems integrator and technology consulting company that specializes in trading and risk management software.

Luxoft triggered the eight-week-hold rule recently after its stock ran up more than 20% in less than three weeks after breaking out from a long base. It's up 13% from the 43.67 buy point and is in the fifth week of the eight-week period.

Paycom Software (PAYC) showed similar price action as it rallied 21% past a 28.94 double-bottom-base buy point initially cleared Jan. 28. The stock, which recently found support at its 10-week moving average, is trading 10% above the entry. The company, which debuted April 15, makes cloud-based human resources management software. Competitors include Automatic Data Processing (ADP) and Workday (WDAY).Many leaders making the Stock Spotlight are well-known names that have received extensive coverage but are overextended for the time being.
